Collection of Ancient and Modern Books: Complete Record of the Medical Section, Volume 175

Back and Spine Gate

Huangdi's Suwen

Discussion of the True Words of the Golden Coffer

The back represents Yang, and within Yang, it is the essence of Yang, which is the heart. The back represents Yang, and within Yin, it is the essence of Yin, which is the lungs. 【Note: The heart is a Yang organ located in the upper burner, thus it is the essence of Yang. The lungs are a Yin organ also located in the upper burner, thus they are the essence of Yin.】

Discussion on the Distinction of Yin and Yang

When two Yang and one Yin give rise to illness, it leads to fright, back pain, frequent yawning, and frequent sighing, known as wind syncope. 【Note: Two Yang and one Yin refer to the conditions of Yangming and Jueyin. The back represents Yang, and Jueyin governs the spring Yang Liver Wood, hence it causes back pain.】

Discussion on the Essentials of the Pulse

The back is the organ of the chest; when the back curves, the shoulders follow, indicating the organs may be failing. 【Note: Shoulders and back are Yang, while the chest and abdomen are Yin. Yang pertains to organs, while Yin pertains to the viscera. The heart and lungs reside in the chest, and their acupoints correspond to the shoulders and back, hence the back is considered an organ of the chest.**[1p]
Discussion on the True Discomfort of the Jade Machine

In winter, if the pulse is excessive, it leads to discomfort (and irritability), pain in the spine, and a lack of energy, making one reluctant to speak; if it is insufficient, it causes a feeling of anxiety as if suffering from hunger, coldness in the middle, pain in the spine, fullness in the lower abdomen, and changes in urination. 【Note: The kidneys are the source of vital energy and govern closure and storage. If excessive, energy leaks out, harming the foundation, leading to lethargy and reduced energy. Insufficient yang energy causes pain in the spine. The heart governs speech, and since the root energy is damaged, one loses the desire to speak. If the pulse is insufficient, the interaction of water and fire energies between the heart and kidneys is compromised, leading to a feeling of anxiety similar to that of hunger. In the coldness of the middle, at the end of the rib bones above the kidneys, the deficiency of kidney yang causes this coldness. The kidneys are connected to the bladder; if the kidneys are weak, they cannot transform properly, leading to changes in urination and fullness in the lower abdomen.】

In spring, if the pulse is insufficient, it causes chest pain that radiates to the back, and fullness in both sides below. 【Note: The yang energy of spring wood arises from the yin of the kidney water. The deficiency of yin energy results in insufficient yang, leading to chest pain radiating to the back. The sides are the area of the liver and kidneys; when the vital energy is deficient and cannot express outwardly, it results in internal fullness.】

In autumn, if the pulse is excessive, it leads to rebellious qi and back pain with irritation. 【Note: The lungs govern the qi of the entire body; excessive energy results in rebellion outward, leading to back pain. The lung's acupoint is located at the shoulder and back.】[2p]

Discussion on the Principles of Qi and Pathology

For those with heart ailments, there is pain in the chest, fullness in the sides, pain below the ribs, pain between the shoulder blades, and pain in the inner arms.
Note: The pathway of the Heart Channel (hand Shaoyin) begins in the heart, runs upward alongside the throat, exits beneath the ribs, follows the inner arm down to the middle of the elbow, and continues along the inner side of the arm. The pathway of the Small Intestine Channel (hand Shaoyang) ascends the upper arm, follows the inner shoulder, exits at the shoulder joint, and circles around the shoulder blade. When these two channels are filled with qi, pain results. Fullness in the sides is due to the branches of the Shaoyin being filled and causing pain below the ribs.

For those with lung ailments, symptoms include wheezing, coughing, and reversed qi, along with pain in the shoulders and back, profuse sweating, and pain in the buttocks, thighs, knees, and feet.
Note: The lungs govern qi and derive their origin from the kidneys; the kidneys are the root, and the lungs are the branch. The qi of the mother and son channels is interconnected. Therefore, the pathway of the Foot Shaoyin channel runs directly from the kidneys, penetrating the diaphragm, entering the lungs, and circling the throat, alongside the base of the tongue. When this qi is disrupted, it causes wheezing and coughing. The lung's acupuncture point is in the shoulder and back area; when qi is reversed upwards, it causes pain in the shoulders and back, leading to sweating; when reversed downwards, it causes pain in the buttocks, thighs, knees, etc.[3p]
The Chapter on Blood and Qi

To understand the points on the back, first measure the space between the two nipples. Then use another piece of grass to measure this space, halving it, and use the two ends as supports. Next, position this measurement to assess the back, ensuring one end is above, aligned with the spinal prominence, while the two ends below align with the lower end, which corresponds to the Lung point.

[Note: This discussion pertains to the method of identifying five points. The points associated with the five organs are all located on the back, as the back is the hollow of the chest. Therefore, the measurement of the two nipples is first established before determining the points on the back. By using grass to measure the distance between the nipples and halving this, we create three key points: one above aligned with the spinal prominence, and two below that support the lower end, which represents the Lung point.][4p]
On Malaria

Evil qi enters the Wind Palace, descends along the body, and the protective qi gathers in the Wind Palace for a day and night. The next day, it descends to a certain level; therefore, it manifests later. This first affects the back. [Note: This indicates that the evil originates in the Wind Palace and affects the spaces in the back, which leads to an early or delayed onset of illness.] When it strikes the back, the qi reaches the back and causes illness. [Note: When it strikes the back, the evil resides in the spaces of the back. The protective qi encounters the evil, hence the onset of illness.]

On Pain

When cold qi invades the pulses at the back acu-points, the pulse becomes weak. A weak pulse leads to deficient blood, and deficient blood results in pain. Because the back is associated with the heart, they reinforce each other, causing pain. Pressing on it brings forth heat, and when heat arrives, the pain stops. [Note: The pulses at the back acu-points refer to the Foot Taiyang pulse, which runs along the back, with the five organs and six bowels associated with the Taiyang meridian, hence it is called the back pulse. The blood and qi of the organs converge at the acu-points, so when cold invades, the pulse weakens, leading to blood deficiency, and thus, pain arises.][5p]

Discussion on Wind

The condition of kidney wind is characterized by back pain that prevents one from standing upright.
Note: The kidney governs the bones; therefore, back pain prevents upright posture.

Treatise on Pulses

The so-called "strongly pulling upward" of the taiyang (greater yang) is due to the yang energy rising vigorously and contending, hence it is strongly pulling upward.
Note: The strong upward pull refers to the head and neck being tense, pulling towards the shoulders and back. The pulse of the taiyang ascends from the forehead to the crown, diverging from the crown to the nape, and pressing against the lower back, with the yang energy being vigorous and agitated above, causing the strong upward pull.

Discussion on the Qi Office

The governor vessel emerges from the large vertebra at the base of the neck down to the tailbone and the fifteen points at its sides, reaching the sacrum, encompassing a total of twenty-one segments, pertaining to the spinal vertebrae.
Note: From the large vertebra to the tailbone is measured as thirteen points, plus the two adjacent points, totaling fifteen points. The large vertebra is located at the prominent bony area at the back of the neck, with the Tao Dao located between the large vertebra and the segment below, the Shen Dao located between the fifth and sixth segments, Ling Tai between the sixth and seventh segments, Zhi Yang between the seventh and eighth segments, Jin Suo between the eighth and ninth segments, Zhong Gu between the eleventh and twelfth segments, Xuan Shu between the thirteenth and fourteenth segments, Ming Men between the fourteenth and fifteenth segments, Yang Guan between the sixteenth and seventeenth segments, Yao Shu between the twenty-first segment, Chang Qiang at the end of the sacrum, and Hui Yang at both sides of the tailbone, belonging to the taiyang bladder meridian. From the large vertebra to the sacrum comprises a total of twenty-one segments, plus the three segments above the neck, making a total of twenty-four segments, which is said to correspond to the twenty-four qi.[6p]
Theory of Symptoms and Diseases

Spleen diseases cause body pain and heaviness. On the first day, there is bloating; on the second day, pain in the lower abdomen, waist, spine, and aching limbs; on the third day, pain in the back (muscles) and urinary blockage. If this continues for ten days, death ensues. In winter, people become stable; in summer, they eat late.

Note: When the disease first affects the spleen, body pain and heaviness occur. On the first day, it affects the stomach, leading to bloating. On the second day, it affects the kidneys, resulting in pain in the lower abdomen, waist, spine, and aching limbs. On the third day, it affects the bladder, causing back pain (muscles) and urinary blockage, and if this persists for ten days, death follows. Ma Shi states: in winter, stability lies during the pig hour, signifying the decline of earth and the dominance of water; in summer, late eating occurs during the tiger hour, where wood flourishes and earth is exhausted.*

Kidney diseases also result in pain in the lower abdomen, waist, and spine, with aching limbs. After three days, back pain (muscles) and urinary blockage occur. After three days, abdominal bloating arises, and after three days, there is pain in both sides of the body. If it continues for three days, death ensues. In winter, it occurs early in the morning; in summer, it occurs late in the afternoon.[7p]
The illness first manifests in the kidneys, leading to pain in the lower abdomen and lower back, followed by pain in the shoulders and bladder, and then difficulty in urination after three days. After another three days, the stomach will experience bloating, and after three days, pain will occur in the liver and sides. In winter, the major bright period is at Chen; the earth is strong and the water is subdued. In summer, the end of the day is at Hai; the water is exhausted and cannot nurture anything.

In the case of stomach illness, there is bloating and heaviness, with pain in the lower abdomen and lower back after five days, and after three days, pain in the shoulders and difficulty in urination. After five days, the body feels heavy, and if it continues for six days, it leads to death. After midnight in winter, the earth weakens and the water dominates. During the brilliant summer day, it is the time governed by Yangming, where the earth is exhausted and cannot produce.

The illness first manifests in the stomach, hence the bloating occurs. After five days, it affects the kidneys, causing pain in the lower abdomen and lower back, and after three days, it moves to the bladder, resulting in shoulder pain and difficulty in urination. After five days, it reaches the spleen, leading to a heavy body, and if it persists for another six days, it results in death. After midnight in winter, the earth is defeated and water triumphs. In the summer sun, it is a time when Yangming is in control, leading to the collapse of earth and the inability to generate life.[8p]
The Classic of the Sinews

The Treatise on the Disease Forms of the Organs and Viscera due to Evil Qi

When evil qi enters a person, it rides upon the void, penetrating the chest and back, as well as the sides. [Note: The collateral of the three yang channels of the hands and feet all ascend from the neck to the head and face. The chest and back, as well as the sides, also follow from the head and neck down to the chest and shoulders.] When the heart pulse is slightly rapid, it leads to heart pain radiating to the back; if it is slightly large, it leads to heart obstruction radiating to the back, accompanied by profuse tears. [Note: Various rapid pulses represent cold, while the heart is the organ of fire. Slight cold merely affects the boundaries of the heart, thus causing heart pain that radiates to the back; if more pronounced, it becomes excessive; slight excess reverses below the heart, leading to heart obstruction radiating to the back, causing the heart essence to rise with the qi to the eyes, resulting in tears.] When the lung pulse is slightly rapid, it indicates lung cold heat, laziness, coughing up blood, and radiating to the lower back, chest, and if there are nasal polyps, nasal obstruction; when slightly large, it indicates lung obstruction, radiating to the chest and back, causing aversion to sunlight. [Note: Lung cold heat refers to cold or heat on the skin. Cold on the skin results in slight rapidity. The lungs govern qi; thus, laziness and coughing up blood radiate to the lower back, chest, and nose, as if there were polyps causing obstruction, all due to deficiency and cold of lung qi. When qi is mildly excessive above, it indicates lung obstruction radiating to the chest and back, as the qi rises from below. With diminished yin blood, there is an aversion to sunlight, as metal fears fire.] When the kidney pulse is markedly slow, it leads to a bent spine.[9p]
The Governing Vessel is associated with the kidneys and runs along the spine. If it becomes relaxed, the spine may become bent.

The Bladder channel of the Foot Taiyang causes headaches when in motion, with symptoms such as feeling like the eyes are popping out, neck tension, back pain, a feeling of fracture in the waist, inability to bend the thigh, knots in the knees, and splitting pain in the ankles, which leads to ankle cramping. This channel governs diseases related to tendons, such as hemorrhoids, malaria, mania, headaches in the temples and neck, yellowing of the eyes with tears, nosebleeds, and pain in the neck, back, waist, buttocks, knees, and feet, to the point that the little toe is unusable.

The Taiyang energy stems from the water of the Bladder, making it the governing energy of all Yang. The gentle quality of Yang nurtures the tendons, hence the diseases related to the tendons manifest as hemorrhoids. If the channels sink and are thin, it results in malaria, while reverse flow downwards leads to epilepsy and mania. Symptoms such as headaches, neck pain, eye issues, back and knee pain are all conditions resulting from pathways in the channels.

The Foot Shaoyin channel runs along the spine and is associated with the kidneys, connecting to the Bladder. The differentiation of the Governing Vessel is termed "Changqiang," which runs alongside the spine up to the neck and is situated between the shoulder blades; when it is full, the spine is strong.[10p]
Chapter on Meridians and Tendons

The tendons of the Foot Taiyin attach to the spine. Their disorders cause pain radiating down to the navel, pain in the flanks, and pain within the spine. The tendons of the Foot Shaoyin run along the spine, hugging the spleen, rising to the nape, and joining with the tendons of the Foot Taiyang.

Chapter on Bone Measurements

From the hairline at the nape down to the vertebrae of the back measures two and a half inches; from the lumbar vertebra down to the sacrum, there are twenty-one segments measuring three feet in total. Each of the upper segments measures one inch and four and one-fourth tenths. The peculiar fraction is counted at the bottom; thus, the seven segments above the lumbar vertebra measure seven inches and nine tenths.

[Note: This is the measurement of the bones of the spine. The distance from the nape down to the vertebrae of the back, measured from the hairline at the back of the head to the largest vertebra of the back, is two and five-tenths inches long. The lumbar vertebra is the spinal vertebra. From the largest vertebra of the back, tracing down along the lumbar vertebra to the sacrum, there are twenty-one segments totaling three feet in length. Each upper segment measures one inch and four-tenths of a cent, with the peculiar fraction of nine-tenths counted at the lower segment. Thus, counting the segments above the lumbar vertebra, there are seven segments each measuring one inch and four-tenths of a cent, so seven make seven inches and four to seven make eight-tenths, totaling nine inches and eight-tenths. Moreover, each segment adds one-tenth, yielding a total of nine inches, eight-tenths and seven-tenths, hence saying seven-tenths of nine inches and eight-tenths.]

Chapter on Nutritional Qi

Nutritional Qi circulates from the spine down to the tailbone; it also moves through the Sanjiao (Triple Burner), enters the gallbladder, and radiates out to the flanks, continuing to circulate through the spine into the sacrum.

Chapter on Epilepsy and Madness[11p]
The onset of madness begins with stiffness, leading to pain in the spine.
[Note: Pain in the spine indicates that cold qi has settled in the earth. The spine refers to the back. The Book of Changes states: "Stabilize the back; stability is like a mountain, stopping and not moving, thereby becoming the high elevation of Kun."]

Heart pain is related to the back.
[Note: The back is yang, and the heart is the sun among the yang, hence the correspondence and resultant pain between the heart and back.]

When yin and yang are not in harmony, fluids overflow and flow downward into the yin, causing both marrow and fluids to be depleted and descend. Excessive descent leads to deficiency, resulting in pain in the lower back and soreness in the shins.
[Note: The disharmony of yin and yang refers specifically to the imbalance between the lesser yin and the greater yang. When the energies of yin and yang are not harmonious, the fluids and essence do not unify, causing the fluids to overflow outside the bones and downward into the yin. When fluids overflow outward, both marrow and fluids decrease and descend, leading to an inability to rise. Excessive downward flow results in weak bones, causing pain in the lower back and soreness in the shins.]

Those with thick shoulders and backs have strong lungs, while those with thin shoulders and backs have brittle lungs. A thick back indicates proper lung alignment, whereas a sparse side indicates a tilted lung.
[Note: The lungs reside within the shoulders and chest, thus observing the shoulders and back reveals the status of the lungs' strength and alignment. As Ni Chong stated: The lungs belong to heaven, covered by a canopy above; the back is yang and shapes the body above, hence the lung points are located at the shoulders and back.][12p]
Chapter on the Back Shu Points

The Yellow Emperor asked Qi Bo: "I wish to understand the Back Shu points of the five zang organs." Qi Bo replied: "The great shu point of the back is located at the end of the blade bone; the lung shu is between the three jiao; the heart shu is between the five jiao; the diaphragm shu is between the seven jiao; the liver shu is between the nine jiao; the spleen shu is between the eleven jiao; the kidney shu is between the fourteen jiao. Each point is located three cun away from the spine. To validate their efficacy, press on these locations. If you feel pain and it relieves the tension at the center, then that is the shu point."

Note: "Jiao" refers to the vertebrae where the spinal joints intersect, along which the Governing Vessel runs. The great shu is on either side of the first vertebra. By first mentioning the great shu when asking about the five zang, it refers to the apex of the bone at the back of the neck, where the Governing Vessel runs along the first vertebra of the spine.

Chapter on the Defensive Qi

The source of the Foot Shaoyin is located three cun above the inner ankle, marked by the back shu and the two meridians beneath the tongue. The source of the Foot Jueyin is at five cun above the interspace, marked by the back shu. The source of the Foot Taiyin is four cun above the center of the Zhongfeng point, marked by the back shu and the root of the tongue. The source of the Hand Shaoyin is at the tip of the wrist bone, marked by the back shu.

Qi in the chest stops at the chest and back shu; Qi in the abdomen is also stopped at the back shu.[13p]
Jade Tablet Chapter

Coughing up blood, fullness in the chest pulling to the back, pulse thin and rapid, indicative of rebelling energy.

Five Sounds and Five Tastes Chapter

The Chong and Ren vessels both arise from within the womb, and ascend along the back.

Cold and Heat Diseases Chapter

The five organs have five sections in the body: the first is the lower abdomen, the second is the calves (the calves are related to the spleen); the third is the back; the fourth corresponds to the associations of the five organs; the fifth is at the neck. If there are carbuncles or sores in these five sections, it results in death.

Those external conditions, such as skin being yang and bones being yin, indicate that carbuncles arise between the skin, flesh, and bones. This suggests that each of the five organs has five sections, and if the yin and yang of one section are not harmonious, it leads to stagnation and results in carbuncles. The "lower abdomen" relates to the kidney, the "calf" relates to the spleen, the "back" corresponds to the lung, while the associations of the five organs refer to the five vertebrae's heart associations. The "neck" corresponds to the liver. The classic text states: the emergence of carbuncles does not originate from external factors but from accumulated subtleties. Therefore, if there are carbuncles in these five sections, it signifies a gradual accumulation of toxic stagnation from the five organs, manifesting externally due to disharmony in blood and qi, resulting in death if present in these areas.[14p]
Jinkui Yaolue [Han Dynasty, Zhang Ji]

Back Pain

For the illness of chest blockage, characterized by wheezing, coughing, spitting, pain in the chest and back, shortness of breath, a deep and slow pulse at the cun position, and a tight and rapid pulse at the guan position, use a decoction of Luo Han Qi Bai and white wine as the principal remedy. If there is chest blockage causing inability to lie down, and heart pain radiating to the back, use a decoction of Luo Han Qi Bai and Ban Xia as the principal remedy. For heart pain radiating to the back, and back pain radiating to the heart, use Wu Tou and Chi Shi Zhi pills. If there is cold in the heart, the person suffers from heart pain similar to eating garlic; if severe, heart pain radiates to the back, and back pain radiates to the heart, resembling poison. If the pulse is floating, recovery will follow self-vomiting.

For upper abdomen diseases, when phlegm causes fullness, wheezing, coughing, vomiting, and if accompanied by chills, fever, back pain, and lower back pain, with tears streaming from the eyes, the person may experience tremors and spasms, suggesting there may be concealed drinking.

Zhongcangjing [Han Dynasty, Hua Tuo]

Pain related to the organs, deficiency, excess, and cold

When the heart pulse is slightly rapid, and heart pain radiates to the back, there is no food intake; if it is slightly stronger, it leads to back pain and excessive tearing. Overactivity of the lungs causes reversed qi with chest fullness and back pain; if deficient, it leads to shoulder and back pain. Cold in the upper jiao impedes food intake, resulting in vomiting sour fluid, radiating chest and back pain, dryness of the throat, and inability to take in fluids.[15p]
Thousand Gold Prescriptions [Tang, Sun Simiao]

Bladder Excess Heat

When the pulse is strong in the middle of the right wrist, it signifies excess yang, particularly affecting the foot taiyang channel. The illness manifests as difficulty urinating, dizziness and pain in the head, a feeling of fullness, and rigidity in the back, which is termed "Bladder Excess Heat."

Back Disorders

Any person who consumes metals or stones must labor their entire body and not indulge in comfort. Those who do otherwise often experience agitation. Furthermore, one must not excessively warm themselves according to their liking. It is necessary to resist desires for warmth and seek the cold; although this might cause discomfort at the time, it will ultimately be beneficial for the body and eliminate concerns of agitation.

Complete Book of Sores and Ulcers [Jin, Dou Hanqing]

Back Disorders

The emergence of sores on the back results from accumulated toxins in the organs. If the righteous qi is strong, the condition lingers; if the original qi is weak, it tends to worsen by night. The sores appear like an arrow, small outside but large within. If contained properly, they will heal; if not, they can lead to death. For treatment, ginseng and astragalus should be the primary herbs; this principle remains unchanged for centuries. If an abscess appears on the back, measuring a foot wide and an inch deep, even if it ruptures down to the bone, as long as the membrane is not pierced, it is not fatal. This condition relates to the six qi and seven emotions or may arise from diet; its toxins accumulate in the spleen and abdomen. Medications should first eliminate the toxins in the spleen and abdomen, applying internal and external treatments to ensure safety.[16p]
Fish Spine Boils

Fish spine boils occur due to accumulation of cold in the internal organs and deficiency of kidney Yang, causing virtual heat to transmit through the meridians and spine. This can appear anywhere in the body, initially resembling sores. When they burst, yellow fluid flows out, forming white blisters that look like fish spines. If not treated promptly, the flesh may rot and pus may flow, making survival difficult. First, take the Shen Gong Huo Ming Decoction, then use Gui Qi Tiao Rong Decoction or Shen Qi Nei Tuo Powder. Externally, apply Detoxifying and Moisturizing Powder, or use Jin Si Ointment. Washing with pig trotters broth or using decocted Earth Bone Bark is particularly effective.

Double-Ended Hair

In cases of double-ended hair, which is small at both ends and scattered around the sides, this is caused by body weakness from drinking alcohol. It results from a conflict between Qi and food, leading to Yin deficiency. Due to Qi deficiency, the hair opens and widens, necessitating urgent internal medicinal treatment for resolution, and it’s advisable to also tonify Yang. The treatment method is similar to that for back and shoulder sores, with adjustments to the formula as needed.

Kidney Shu Hair

Kidney Shu hair is associated with Yin, often overlooked. It occurs due to summer dampness and anger, as well as drinking hot alcohol. This injures the internal kidneys, allowing toxic substances to flow into them. Quickly detoxify the internal kidney poison, attacking both internally and externally. If the physician is slow in treating the membrane, survival is unlikely. Completely avoid anger and sexual activity; even slight transgressions should not be treated. The treatment method is the same as for back boils, but supplement the kidneys with ingredients like Huang Lian, Zhi Mu, Myrrh, and Guang Jiao.[17p]
Heart Fire Disorder

Heart fire disorder is difficult to treat. The heart is the ruler's office, from which spirit and clarity emerge. When calm and empty, how can illness arise? If the heart is upset, various illnesses will emerge. Conditions that manifest in the hands and feet all stem from heart fire. Therefore, when symptoms arise from the heart, they manifest in the back, opposing the heart; this is termed heart fire disorder. Due to the excess heart fire, heat energy accumulates in that area. As the toxicity increases, it is urgent to use medications that clear and regulate the heart fire. Careful intention must be applied, akin to military strategy, to have a chance for recovery. One must control their temperament; a single burst of anger can hinder recovery. Those symptoms arising on the side of the heart can also be treated. It is advisable to take Huang Lian Jiedu Decoction, Hu Xin San, and La Fan Wan, day and night.

Scattered and Flowing Qi Disorder

This condition arises between the shoulder blades, where if the qi and blood are unbalanced, the meridians obstructed, and one is affected by external elements and internal emotions, toxic qi becomes stimulated by wind and heat, causing it to disperse. This occurs due to excessive wind generating heat; when heat is extreme, qi becomes overloaded and scatters. Urgent relief is needed to disperse the wind and settle the heat to allow qi to naturally rest. If the vital energy is strong at the onset, one should promptly apply moxa on seven spots, apply medicine around the area, and take a decoction of twenty-four herbs for dispersing qi; recovery is almost certain. If the symptoms flow into the hands, feet, or legs, there is no doubt of a grim outcome.[18p]
Linked Pearls Disease

This illness manifests with swelling of the scrotum, difficulty urinating, and abdominal distention and pain. This ulcer originates from excessive sexual desire, resulting in drunkenness and indulgence in sexual activities, which harms the kidney's water. Those afflicted with this illness will develop a series of symptoms, causing dryness of the mouth, chills and fever throughout the body, and pain in all joints. It should be treated with the Ten Marvels Powder and Liquor-Cooked Powder. If the affected area has good flesh with red and swollen edges that look like fire, use a magnetic stone to draw out the bad blood, followed by applying a mixture of chicken egg and frankincense powder. Regularly use banana root juice to moisten the area to enhance the effectiveness of the medication.

Honeycomb Disease

This illness presents as dark blue or blackened flesh that is significantly depressed in the center, surrounded by hard, reddish-purple tissue. It is caused by wind-venom damaging the pores. If the disease erupts, it can heal, but if it does not, it can lead to death. This toxicity arises from a rich diet, excessive warmth from heavy bedding, drunkenness, and indulgent sexual activity, causing the five organs to accumulate toxins that do not flow, eventually forming a carbuncle, resulting in mental confusion, restless nights, frequent urination, and loose stools. If this illness causes a series of symptoms on the left side, the outcome is death. The treatment should involve the internal use of the Ten Clear Powder and taking Wax Alum Pills five times daily. Once pus begins to form, take medication to expel the pus while supplementing with the Ten Clear Powder, and mix in Mu Xiang and Pangolin scales, continuing to apply Gold Silk Ointment.[19p]

Jìng Tǐ Fā (Sudden Outbreak)

This poison appears between the shoulder blades, arising in the hot summer when the hollow body absorbs foul qi, causing the stomach qi to deteriorate, leading to vomiting and nausea. If untreated, the poisonous qi enters within, making recovery difficult. Quickly take乳香托里散 (Mother of Pearl Base), then take五香连翘散 (Five Spice and Forsythia Powder) and蜡矾丸 (Wax and Alumen Pill), apply金丝膏 (Golden Silk Ointment) externally, and consume忍冬酒 (Honeysuckle Wine) three times a day.

Lián Zǐ Fā (Lotus Seed Outbreak)

This sore arises in the right shoulder region, as the poisoned qi threatens to reach the heart. It is necessary to disperse the poison with medicine, applying local treatment to prevent it from attacking the heart. If it reaches the midsection and causes swelling throughout the back, it may be irretrievable. For those with minor symptoms, treatment is possible. All sores that cause pain and itching are related to the heart, as the heart generates blood and circulates qi, which governs pain. Treat all sores with topical medicine and puncture with large needles three or four times, using前化毒消肿散 (Detoxifying and Swelling-Reducing Powder), adding extra astragalus from千金内托散 (Thousand Gold Inner Prescribing Powder), along with护心散 (Heart-protecting Powder) and蜡矾丸 (Wax and Alumen Pill). This must be done consistently.

Shàng Zhōng Xià Sān Dā Shǒu (Upper, Middle, Lower Triple Hand)

This poison lies in the five organs and six bowels, with toxic heat from worry and anger, harming the lung channels, accumulating into poison. This is a severe condition. Use medicines for brain abscess and back abscesses to treat it similarly, while regularly taking忍冬酒 (Honeysuckle Wine) and蜡矾丸 (Wax and Alumen Pill).[20p]
Upper, Middle, and Lower Back Pain

Upper back pain is related to the Taoist meridians, primarily affecting the lungs and liver. This condition can be caused by emotional distress leading to anger, which can injure the liver and result in toxins accumulating in the back. This is a serious condition. First, administer the Detoxifying Flowing Qi Decoction; next, use the Heart Protecting Dispersion; and finally, treat it with the Internal Flowing Qi Decoction.

Middle back pain is linked to the Spirit Hall and Spiritual Path meridians, causing heart toxicity. The heart's blood cannot return to the liver, resulting in stagnation of Qi and blood in the back, damaging the liver meridian. This is a severe condition. Herbal decoctions should be used to administer the Detoxifying Flowing Qi Decoction.

Lower back pain involves the Spleen and Liver meridians, causing stagnation within the internal organs and damaging three meridians. This represents the condition of the three toxins. First, use the Detoxifying Flowing Qi Decoction; then apply the Ginseng Internal Dispersion, and for external application, use surrounding medicinal herbs.

Phlegm Accumulation

What is meant by phlegm accumulation? It arises from the influences of the six energies and seven emotions, leading to phlegm that cannot circulate, becoming trapped between the shoulder blades and resting within the meridians. The back is a significant area, and over time this can lead to the formation of a pouch, connecting internally to the organs and externally to the skin. It should be treated promptly. The shape may vary - it could be round, oblique, or resemble a grain bag, and feel hard like a stone. For treatment, apply surrounding herbs externally and take 40 to 50 doses of the Ginseng Internal Dispersion. Once the vital energy is sufficient, one may use purgatives, leading to the elimination of several liters of phlegm and achieving recovery.[21p]
Three String Poison

This condition arises on the upper and lower back. Although its appearance is uniform, the skin in the center is fine, but the internal flesh is rotting. It initially presents as red and is not too painful, gradually worsening over time. The origin of this condition is attributed to influences from the six Qi and seven emotions, as well as exposure to severe cold and extreme heat, causing toxic accumulation in the organs. It may also afflict older men and women who are usually calm and silent, likely due to habitual sitting or lying in damp conditions. If there are no external symptoms, it can survive. However, if there is a decrease in appetite, diarrhea, or fever, survival becomes difficult. The treatment approach is similar to that used for back abscesses.

Kidney-Related Anger Causing Spleen Abscess

This condition occurs with dual eruptions at the lower back's kidney points due to consuming hot wine during intercourse, combined with anger that harms the liver and causes dampness. External Yang manifestations are treatable. If the phlegm causes Yin damage to the kidney membrane, and the pus is thin, it indicates weakness and is hard to treat. If older women, who are generally warm-tempered, regulate their diet and are not troubled by emotional disturbances, also suffer from this condition, it is likely due to dampness from the ground or bathing in cold water during hot months. Spleen abscess appears between the left shoulder blades; when it first manifests, it can be treated with moxibustion. Quickly taking a decoction to disperse it and sweating it out can help. The treatment method with medications is the same as before. Wax alum pills are very suitable for use.[22p]
Blood Sores and Flowing Abscesses

This condition often occurs in people of a robust build, particularly those who enjoy consuming fried, roasted, or sugary foods. The abscess may be large, resembling a chicken egg, and it appears swollen but not red, lying between the meridians, flowing into the joints and causing widespread aches and pains. To treat this, use internal powders combined with papaya, white peony, and forsythia, and additionally take frankincense heart-protecting powder and alum pills; apply external dressings promptly. When administering medication, be mindful of the symptoms and do not strictly adhere to formulas.

Navel-Related Poison

Abscesses occurring in the lumbar region between the kidneys can result in swelling along the back, also referred to as "navel abscess" or "seasonal kidney." This condition impacts the heart and can last thirty days, after which it may be punctured. If the pus is red-white, survival is likely; if it is blue-yellow or purple, and accompanied by hallucinations, it indicates internal kidney pain. Transitioning to thirst indicates dire conditions. A substantial intake of ginseng and astragalus internal formulas, along with rehmannia, coptis, and ophiopogon for nourishing kidney water, is recommended.

Back Sores[23p]
Whenever fever occurs, it is called a back sore; if there is no fever, it is all boils. If there are internal hidden symptoms in the five organs, they manifest as dullness without heat.

Abscesses on the back with hidden symptoms have a flat head directed inward, are dull and painless, the whole body and the affected area are not hot. One should take Angelica wine to expel pus, and use internal tonics like San He San and an enhanced version of Jin Zheng Qi San as supplements, along with rice flour, pig's feet, and buttock meat for nourishment. Buckwheat flour can help generate heat and can be cooked. If it does not generate heat, one can use slices of pangolin head, dip them in vinegar and fry until burnt, mixed with two and a half qian of ground human teeth.

This mixture can be made into two portions, using spicy cinnamon, Angelica, and Ephedra boiled in wine for oral intake; externally, ginger juice mixed with flour can be thickly applied to the affected area.

When abscesses occur on the head, sideburns, eyebrows, and chin, and on the back, these are considered the five abscesses, which are particularly dangerous. Their symptoms often cause headache, nausea, chills and fever, breathlessness, and cramps, and require Wu Xiang San or Wu Xiang Tang.

To investigate the cause of the illness, there may be wind, qi, food, drug toxicity, or physical strain. Wind tends to cause itching, qi often causes pain, food leads to chills and fever, drug toxicity results in hardness, and strain leads to weakness. Wind, qi, and food accumulation are easier to treat and require Er Xiang San. Drug toxicity combined with strain is more complicated to heal.[24p]

Wind in the kidney leads to spinal pain, making it difficult to stand upright. When cold enters the meridians, it causes stagnation and tears, hindering the flow of qi, resulting in pain pulling between the heart and back. If qi travels up to the wind palace, it results in "wind in the brain," causing cold sensations in the back.

Back Ulcer

Stagnant Qi Causes Pain[25p]
The "Pulse Classic" states: Wind-cold leads to sweating, shoulder and back pain, and incomplete urination. When wind-heat invades the lungs, it severely obstructs lung qi. One should expel the wind-heat and promote qi; Fangfeng Decoction is the main remedy. For shoulder and back pain, do not look back; this is due to qi stagnation in the Taiyang channel, and one should disperse it with wind herbs.

As for the back abscess, it first appears the size of a millet grain, itchy and painful with a distinct feeling. If touched and ruptured, it will expand and exhibit a red, swollen, and heavy sensation, pulling and causing pain in the ribs. After several days, the skin increasingly feels hot, with chills and thirst. The swelling spreads, with pus oozing, and if it does not rupture for days, and suppression leads to bleeding, it is called a back abscess.

There can also be an initial stage with no head, swelling three to four inches wide, first felt as dull pain; after several days, if the skin appears smooth and soft, it can lead to fever, chills, headache, and thirst; this is called a back boil. This condition is particularly severe. The initial formation of these abscesses is mostly due to rich foods and thick clothing. Thick warm clothing invites cold easily, while excessive rich foods create heat within the five organs. When the organs accumulate heat, blood flow is obstructed and toxic qi stagnates. The pathogenic qi is trapped, heat attacks the blood, and when the blood stagnates, it leads to meat rotting into sores. A mild case is a furuncle, a severe one is a boil, and a deep case is an abscess. There are also instances where the condition arises from the use of metals or stones, as well as cases where individuals who have never taken such substances still develop this illness. This is attributed to ancestral toxic influences being passed down. Once this disease first emerges and is recognized as an abscess, prompt treatment is advisable.[26p]
If one has strong passion, they should take Five-Spice Lianqiao Decoction and Loushu Decoction. For those under fifty, robust and young, they may take Wuli Dahuang Decoction or Huadu Wan, to promote the flow and support organ function. For lesions, use a remedy like Zhui Du San and apply warm poultices, along with Tanshong Decoction and Huidu Decoction for cleansing. Such treatments are to be administered while awaiting the formation of pus. Prior to this, do not use various medicines for healing, to settle the patient's mind; be careful not to provoke anger. Once the pus has formed and ruptured, it is advisable to take Five-Spice Decoction, along with Neituoli San, Fuling Decoction, and Danggui Neituoli San. If there is unquenchable thirst, take Zhuye Huangqi Decoction or Ruxiang San. Do not induce great heat; avoid bitter cold drugs such as Dahuang and (Shibu) Nitre. If taking purgative medicines results in persistent diarrhea, it can be fatal. If there is still necrotic tissue in the wound and the pus is not flowing well, use destructive medicines, or apply a binding agent, topped with powdered deer antler mixed with vinegar to create a paste for application. As necrotic tissue recedes and healthy tissue gradually forms, use Shou Pus San and Cuixia San for binding. If the toxicity of the sore has not fully dissipated, be cautious not to use muscle-generating medicines too early; even if recovery seems possible, the problem is likely to recur. During this process, careful adjustment and timely considerations are crucial, taking care to safeguard and avoid potential mistakes.[27p]

Medical Guidelines
[Ming Dynasty, Lou Ying]

Aversion to Cold Associated with Fluid Disorder

Aversion to cold in the back indicates phlegm and fluid. Zhang Zhongjing states: if there is retained fluid under the heart, the person experiences aversion to cold in the back, feeling like ice; thus, Poria Pill is the remedy.

Pain Associated with the Lungs

Shoulder and back pain relates to the lung territory. The classic text states: "Western winds arise in autumn, and diseases are in the lungs, manifesting in the shoulders and back." Therefore, autumn conditions can lead to illnesses affecting the shoulders and back. Additionally, it is stated: "Excessive lung condition in autumn leads to illnesses that result in reversed qi, causing back pain and irritability.”[29p]
Conditions Related to Heat

The classics say: When the year is excessively hot, the people suffer from shoulder and back heat. It also states: In the presence of lesser yin affecting Heaven, where heat overwhelms, there are pains in the shoulder and back, especially in the area of the shoulder blade. Additionally, it mentions: When the year's metal is insufficient, diseases manifest internally in the chest and sides, externally on the skin. Treating these with cold remedies is the solution.

Hair Loss in the Back

To treat hair loss in the back, Sea藏 (a herbal remedy) uses the Deadly Dan and Cang Er formula. One utilizes rhubarb and oyster shell, while the other uses Cang Er, indicating a distinction between internal and external. Previously, using the Deadly Dan with two medicines shows their different effects; this is due to the changes in diet. The pulse can be deep and slippery, indicating that dampness from the ground affects the flesh and tendons; if the pulse is floating and slippery, there will be differences in discharge and hair loss.

Among humanity's greatest concerns, hair loss in the back is one of the five types:

  1. Yang toxin. This arises from wind and heat, either causing heat toxin to lead to excessive thirst or manifesting after suffering from cold damage, with residual yang toxin accumulating at the back. It does not matter how many vertebrae are involved; it simply arises from between the two sides of the spine and extends up to the waist, often presenting as heat throughout the back, red, purple, or flame-like, with pus that is hard to generate. Once formed, pain persists; when it seems to subside in a few days, it is merely a deceptive appearance. This is an internal attack causing flesh to sink, which cannot be treated.[30p]

  2. The second type is a toxic boil appearing on the back. This condition arises from cold energy and starts as small as millet grains. If emotions are unhappy, it causes dull pain directly in the chest, leading to heart disquiet and a heavy head, with chills and fever resembling malaria. After five to seven days, it will begin to swell and spread, making it difficult to contain. There is pus accumulating inside, deep and slow. If it hasn't broken out yet, it's best to urgently use tonic herbal medicine to nourish the qi and externally apply poultices to draw out the pus. If pus is observed, it is advisable to act quickly; if there is no pus, healing may occur on its own, but not until later.

  3. The third type occurs in individuals who frequently consume medicines made from metals or stones, resulting in toxicity and stagnation that causes boils. Initially, it manifests like a red rash, gradually opening up like a burn; the face turns crimson, and there is anxiety and restlessness within the chest, accompanied by extreme thirst and a preference for cold. These sores are difficult to form and, when they do, startle others more than those from either yin or yang toxins. Therefore, there is a prescription for antidotal medicine to treat the internal toxicity of metal and stone. A clear foundation needs to be established, and urgent treatment is necessary for safety.[31p]
    Fourth, there are those who suffer from toxic reactions in the back due to food and alcohol. This ailment is not acquired recently; rather, it results from long-term accumulation in the organs. When one is hungry and fatigued, they eat and then sleep; or they consume excessive amounts of rich, greasy, and cold food and drink, causing obstruction in the chest. With unchecked indulgence in the wind, the spleen's energy becomes deficient, unable to resist the accumulation, resulting in toxicity attacking the back. The pain does not discriminate by the number of vertebrae but begins as small lumps like marbles, later growing to the size of fists, hard as stone, causing widespread pain, stiff limbs, bitter mouth, dry tongue, abdominal distress, and difficulty with urination and defecation. After ten days, there may be swelling in the head, face, hands, and feet, alongside gastrointestinal leakage. The urgent pain signifies this condition. If there is a tendency to swell, immediate use of swelling-relief remedies is essential, and the issue must be treated without delay; pus and fluid should not be allowed to accumulate. Otherwise, neglect can lead to skin necrosis, bone injury, and muscle decay, resulting in increased pus production, internal disintegration from external pathogens, leading to death.

Fifth, there are those who suffer from toxic reactions in the back due to exposure to mountain miasmas and pestilential air.[32p]
Initially in the organs, as time passes, the Qi and blood become deficient and weaken. It begins with a swelling that is dark blue or black like a boot, accompanied by a hard pain, deeply affecting the muscles and bones, reaching the marrow. Pressing it feels like touching wood or stone; only by pressing harder can one feel a painful spot. After five to seven days, the toxic Qi rises, causing a shallow, swollen area that turns pale blue, resembling the effect of a punch. There may be chills akin to malaria, and symptoms of wind exposure, with the head shifting and the mouth skewed, hands and feet feeling cold and in reversal, the eyes appearing dark with excessive whites, sluggish. This indicates an internal struggle with evil Qi. It is urgent to expel three to five liters of clear blood to allow the yellow pus and white fluid to flow out. The skin remains neither relaxed nor slow but urgent; the swelling and pain do not cease until the color fades and the heat and pain finally subside. It’s advisable to urgently expel the pus and toxic Qi outwards, as it does no harm.

There may be abscesses or sores on the back, like the toxic Qi is fierce, and the onset resembles flames burning brush, making it prone to decay. It begins as small as a millet grain; in three to four days, it becomes red and swollen, as large as the palm of a hand, and within five to seven days, it can be as large as a bowl, making it easy to attack.[33p]
When the heat is intense and resembles a fire burning, the surface gradually breaks down and broadens, with internal swelling like the cooking of food. The external skin and flesh rot away, as if purple bruises are removed. There is a large amount of pus, and the swelling does not subside, with persistent pain. The patient experiences difficulty with eating and drinking, with symptoms of vomiting and shortness of breath. In cases where the condition is superficial and broad, it is especially advisable to use pus-generating medicinals to detoxify; usage will surely result in healing, as this represents a real yang syndrome.

In some cases, there may be one that is only the size of a teacup; this does not indicate a lack of size but rather that the toxic qi is deeply rooted, and there is internal deficiency close to the membranes. This must internally attack the viscera and then externally afflict the limbs, first targeting the head and face with superficial swelling, then affecting the hands and subsequently the two feet. If the face is swollen and the toxic qi disseminates into the limbs, the person may have a hoarse voice and gasp for breath, with darkened small eyes and swollen black fingers, dry and scorched without treatment, indicating a true yin syndrome of deficiency.

Whenever boils or abscesses first arise, with firm and swollen elevations, yet the toxic qi is shallower, this indicates disharmony in the six bowels leading to the boil, which is a yang symptom. Although the situation appears urgent, it is easier to treat.[34p]
If it first appears like a grain of millet, sometimes as large as a bean, and is level with the flesh, it may be red, occasionally causing itching and pain. During the itching, be careful not to scratch it open; this indicates a disorder in the five organs leading to a boil. Its symptoms are of yin nature, reflecting that toxic gas has accumulated deeply within. Though it progresses slowly, it is difficult to treat.

If it first appears as large as a broad bean, the body heats up; the area of the boil swells and is hot and painful. This is an external outbreak; even if it is as large as a basin, treating it properly will certainly lead to recovery—this is a manifestation of yang.

Alternatively, if the body does not feel hot and there is a sense of fatigue, the boil is also not warm. After several days, it gradually enlarges, without swelling or pain, sinking down and rotting. This indicates an internal outbreak; even immortals cannot remedy this—this is a manifestation of yin deficiency.

At first, when swelling occurs, treating it with moxibustion within three days will yield results. If pus forms within eight days and proper guiding techniques are applied, it will also lead to healing. If one engages in labor before it has healed, it will worsen. Care in diet will help in recovery. Managing emotions will also assist. Aggressive treatment of the swelling will lead to complications, as will rushed treatments. Disregarding the risk of it spreading will lead to improvement.

If one waits for the pus to come out on its own without any guiding treatment, it may lead to death. If there is no internal attack and guiding treatment is applied with the use of needles and moxibustion, recovery is possible; however, if internal issues have arisen and treatments are applied afterward, it may result in death.[35p]
When pus and heat pain are severe, those previously treated may survive; however, if the condition has progressed and becomes internal, death is certain. If pus forms but does not drain and only topical medicine is applied, death will occur. In cases of red or white dysentery with severe Qi stagnation, it indicates internal attack; treatment will be ineffective, and death is inevitable. Infected boils, if not treated, will have a survival rate of only five out of ten, while untreated carbuncles will have a mortality rate of ten out of ten. Those with mild swelling and pain sensitivity will surely die. Without encountering effective methods, one will die. If treatment does not adhere to the proper timing, death is assured. Those foolishly adhering to their own desires and indulging in their emotions will die.

In general, for boils and carbuncles on the back, regardless of size, whether painful or not, hot or cold, as long as the swelling increases to over one foot, if it is red and swollen with heat, immediate use of urgent remedies to reduce the red swelling should be applied without allowing drainage. Center treatment involves using remedies to draw out pus and disperse toxins, urgently expelling toxins while internally administering remedies to drain pus and consolidate toxins. Wait for the pus to form, then successively drain the abscess, observing the state of the sore's size and depth to allow the pus to release. If the pus flows abundantly, urgent internal nourishment is required; even if the abscess is opened with little pus, further draining and toxin expulsion is necessary.[36p]
Be cautious not to allow a swelling to recur; it is essential to alleviate pain and reduce swelling. If the patient feels light and comfortable, it indicates a favorable response to the illness. It is crucial to regulate diet carefully. When heat and toxins are prevalent, one may experience intense thirst and should avoid excessive consumption of cold water and cold drinks. This is due to toxic energies attacking the heart, leading to dry mouth and discomfort. Instead, one should use heart-nourishing medications to support the internal organs. Nourishing refers to ingredients like ginseng and astragalus, while expelling pus includes substances like soapberry thorns.

For furuncles, if they arise on the hip and back, particularly at the heart and pericardium points, if not needled within twenty days, it can be fatal. They can be needled after ten days. If the color is reddish-black with clear pus, it is untreatable.

For special furuncles, if they occur at the lung and liver points, if not needled, they lead to death within twenty days. They can be needled after eight days. If the color is deep red with hidden, pepper-like elevations, it is fatal.

For the dual-qi furuncle, which can be broad or small on the back, exhibiting swelling and heat, they can be needled after ten days. Expelling pus, regardless of how deep or shallow, is necessary. If the patient experiences thirst and fatigue, and no pus is observed within ten days, it is untreatable.

For tendon furuncles, if they occur on both sides of the spine along the large tendons, with a bluish color, they can be needled after eight days. If there is a boil in the large intestine, it can lead to death within ninety days.[37p]
Individuals with a consistently cold back often suffer from phlegm and dampness; they should take a decoction for phlegm combined with Suzi Decoction to relieve qi. If the back feels cold, it can have both yin and yang manifestations: in the case of a lesser yin pattern of cold damage, the back will feel unbearably cold while the mouth is warm; in the yangming pattern, the back feels cold and the mouth is dry. This helps distinguish between cold and heat. Heat in the back is attributed to the lungs, as the lungs are situated in the upper jiao, hence the heat manifests there.

For dampness, if the back is stooped and the feet have contracted rendering them almost useless, one can take a small amount of sweet hemp to be stewed with pig kidneys; if there’s vomiting and diarrhea, this will cure it.

Xue's Medical Case
The moxibustion method and medications:
The "Essentials" states: The classics say all pain, itching, sores, and lesions belong to heart fire. Previous practitioners noted that carbuncles and abscesses often occur in those who labor heavily in the stone industry. For anyone over the age of forty who develops sores on their back or elsewhere, it is advisable to calm the heart and seek early treatment. These symptoms are like a tiger entering a home; if handled poorly, they will harm the person. First, use internal remedies to disperse toxicity, followed by Lianqiao Wuxiang Decoction, and additionally use the method of moxibustion on the foot Sanli point, or moxibustion with garlic to expel the toxins. The presence of evil causes energy deficiency; if left unattended, the illness becomes severe. Therefore, if carbuncles or abscesses have not burst, internal organs are still harboring toxins, and not even a bit of heat-inducing medicine should be used. If the carbuncles or abscesses have burst, and the internal organs are already depleted, not even a bit of cold medicine should be used. It is also important to avoid plasters that may close up the pores.[41p]
If there is heat, thirst, and constipation, with a pulse that is deep, forceful, and rapid, it is advisable to use herbs like Da Huang to purge the toxins. Afterwards, use remedies such as Guo Lao Gao, Wan Jin San, Huang Fan Wan, or Yuan Zhi Jiu, choosing as appropriate.

Note: If the symptoms indicate heat toxins accumulated internally, with constipation but no deficiency of vital energy, it is best to use Da Huang and similar medicines to expel the heat and toxins. If there is deficiency in yin with an excess of yang, leading to insufficient essence and depleted qi, and weak spleen and stomach, warming tonics should be used to replenish the source.

If sores are not ulcerated or swollen but not festering, they still require warming and tonifying. If sores have already ulcerated, with swelling that persists and pain that does not stop, cooling remedies should still be applied.

In cases of acute illness with sufficient vital energy, treat the symptoms first; in cases of chronic illness with deficient vital energy, treat the root cause first. If the illness is acute and vital energy is even more deficient, it is essential to treat the root cause first while also managing the symptoms.[42p]
Generally, if there is swelling, pain, and thick, sticky pus, the vital energy is not damaged, and treatment is easy; if there is diffuse swelling, slight pain, and clear, thin pus, the vital energy is weak, and treatment is difficult; if there is no swelling or pain, or if there is diffuse swelling that is dark in color and unrelieved, it arises from Yin, and the vital energy is severely deficient, thus it should not be treated.

If there is swelling, pain, and high elevation, first use the Xianfang Huo Ming Decoction, then use the Tuo Li Xiao Du Powder. For diffuse swelling and slight pain, it is advisable to use the Tuo Li Powder; if there is no response, add ginger and cinnamon. If pus is discharged but there is pain, it indicates deficiency of Qi and blood, use the Ba Zhen Powder. If there is no pus, no necrosis, it indicates deficient Yang Qi, use Si Jun Powder plus Gui, Qi, and cinnamon. If there is no generation of flesh, no retraction, it indicates deficient spleen Qi, use the Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction plus ginger and cinnamon. If there is fever in the afternoon and internal heat, it indicates deficiency of Yin blood, use Si Wu Decoction plus ginseng and Atractylodes. If there is a desire to vomit or actual vomiting, it indicates deficient stomach Qi, use the Liu Jun Decoction plus roasted ginger. If there is spontaneous sweating or night sweats, it indicates deficiency of the five organs, use the Liu Wei Wan plus Schisandra.[43p]
When there is little food intake and physical weakness, it indicates a deficiency of the spleen and qi. One should use "Buzhong Yiqi Decoction" and add Poria and Pinellia. If there are symptoms of wheezing and coughing, it indicates deficiency of the spleen and lungs. In this case, one adds wheat and five-flavor fruit to the previous decoction. For nausea and reduced appetite, it indicates deficiency of the spleen and stomach, thus "Ren Shen Li Zhong Decoction" should be used. For abdominal pain and diarrhea, indicating cold deficiency of the spleen and stomach, use "Fu Zi Li Zhong Decoction." For distension in the lower abdomen and swelling in the lower legs, indicating weakness of the spleen and kidneys, use "Shiquan Dabu Decoction" with additions of spiny date, yam, and cinnamon. For diarrhea with cold feet, also indicating weakness of the spleen and kidneys, add cinnamon and aconite to the previous medicine. For thirst accompanied by heat and urinary difficulty, it indicates kidney yin deficiency fire; one should use the modified "Eight Flavors Pill." For wheezing and urinary difficulty, indicating deficiency fire of the lungs and kidneys, use "Buzhong Yiqi Decoction" combined with the modified "Eight Flavors Pill." All these variations are caused by depletion of the vital energy, a result of inadequate preemptive supplementation. Therefore, Master Danxi stated: "Whenever one sees swelling and pain, and the pulse indicates weakness, one should supplement; if there is no deficiency of qi and blood, one can ensure a good outcome." This statement is profound! It is essential to adapt treatments to the differing conditions of deficiency and excess throughout history and apply treatments according to the times, which can lead to slight differences.[44p]

Life and Death Signs

Question: Some illnesses are severe and lead to death, while others are mild yet still result in death. How can one differentiate between conditions that indicate life or death?

Answer: If there is an abscess on the back that penetrates the internal membrane, it is a sign of death; this refers to the area above the liver. If there is yet no penetration but the face turns blue and the lips black, with dark stool, it indicates death; this refers to organ deterioration with stagnant blood.

There are various causes for the conditions mentioned, including weakness of the original qi leading to internal toxicity, initial manifestations that fail to promote internal harmony, excessive toxicity that fails to dissipate, weakness that fails to be replenished, formation of pus that fails to be drained, and corruption leading to failure in nourishment. If the abscesses are due to damp-heat obstruction, the use of Huanglian Jiedu San and Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang is advised to eliminate dampness and toxins, bolster the spleen and lungs, and nourish the water of the kidneys.[47p]

Generally, the formation of sores and ulcers arises from improper gastric qi; the rupture of sores and ulcers stems from the corruption of gastric qi; the healing of sores and ulcers depends on the nourishment of gastric qi. Three Causes of Separation

Chen Wuze states: Those who develop back pain are influenced by three causes. The discussion states: boils, sores, and tuberculosis, regardless of whether they are due to deficiency or excess, cold or heat, all arise from stagnant qi. The classic text also states: qi accumulates in the meridians, thickening with blood, causing blockage that leads to boils and sores. It does not mention that heat must be present later for boils to form; rather, this is a result of internal causes such as pent-up emotions—joy, anger, worry, or thought.

When the body has heat and is struck by wind and cold, the blood vessels become congested and fail to flow, resulting in heat accumulation and blockage. There are also cases where yin deficiency and yang qi converge, causing cold to transform into heat, leading to decay of flesh into pus; this, too, arises from external causes of cold, heat, wind, or dampness.

Moreover, ingesting certain elixirs or consuming overly heated wine, using thick bedding, or exhausting oneself sexually—all of these lead to empty yang and disrupted qi’s adjustment. Hence, it is understood that the three causes are comprehensive. However, while the three causes are classified, the variations in the pathogens that affect skin, surface, or internal conditions are not distinctly outlined, therefore the treatment methods cannot be thoroughly detailed.[51p]

Overview of Back Sores

Back sores are associated with the Governing Meridian and the Bladder Channel. They can arise from various causes: excess heat due to Yin deficiency, consumption of rich foods and alcohol, emotional distress, or heat toxins from minerals.

If there is significant swelling, redness, and pain, with a strong and rapid pulse, this indicates heat toxin, which is easier to treat. If there is diffuse swelling with slight pain, a dark color, and despite a rapid pulse it feels weak, this indicates Yin deficiency, which is more difficult to treat. If there is no swelling or pain, or diffuse swelling with a dark color and a weak, thin pulse, this indicates severe Yang deficiency and is particularly hard to treat.

For individuals with back sores, it is difficult to conceal the symptoms. Use about ten douts of mung bean and make a large bag to hide it, which will naturally cool the heart and calm the body.

If there is swelling and pain, accompanied by chills and fever, while appetite remains unchanged, this indicates excess of both form and spirit. Start with the Immortal Vitality Decoction, followed by the Elimination of Toxins Powder for resolution.

For headache and stiffness as a surface condition, take one or two doses of Ginseng Poison-Dispelling Powder first. For cramping pain, use Honeysuckle Powder or Sophora Flower Wine, or the effective Elimination of Toxins Powder.

For pain and hard swelling with a solid pulse, employ cooling drinks, Immortal Vitality Decoction, or Bitter Root Pills. If there is hard swelling with a wooden feeling, pain, heat, restlessness, cold drinks causing constipation, and a deep solid pulse, then use the Internal Clearing Huanglian Decoction or a cooling drink.[52p]
The stool has been released, and if pus is desired, use the Immortal Formulation for Vitality Drink, Toli Powder, and Lapis Aluminis Pill, and externally apply the Divine Efficacy Ointment. If there is mild swelling and slight pain or the color is not red, accompanied by little appetite and thoughts, this indicates deficiency in both form and qi, and Toli Powder should be used to replenish. If there is no pus or if pus forms but does not rupture, it indicates yang qi deficiency; therefore, Toli Powder should be increased with cinnamon, ginseng, and astragalus. If pus emerges but causes pain again or if the pus is clear and thin, it indicates deficiency in both qi and blood, and Ba Zhen Decoction should be used. If there is aversion to cold and a cold body, or if it does not contract, it signifies yang qi deficiency; thus, Shi Quan Da Bu Decoction is recommended. If there is heat in the afternoon or heat inside, or if it does not contract, it signifies yin qi deficiency; therefore, Si Wu Decoction plus ginseng and atractylodes should be used. If there is nausea and a desire to vomit or if it does not contract, it indicates stomach qi deficiency; in this case, Liu Jun Zi Decoction plus roasted ginger should be taken. If there is little appetite and fatigue, or if it does not contract, it indicates spleen qi deficiency; thus, Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction with poria and half summer should be used. If the meat is red and does not contract, it indicates blood heat; Si Wu Decoction should be increased with gardenia and forsythia. If the meat is pale and does not contract, it indicates spleen deficiency; Si Jun Zi Decoction should be added with wine-fried peony and woodshop. If there is frequent urination, it indicates kidney yin deficiency; Jia Jian Ba Wei Wan should be added. If there is high swelling, pain, and a floating pulse, it signifies an invasion of the exterior; thus, it should be treated with Toli. If there is pain that is stubborn or there is dryness in the throat, it indicates fire in the upper; therefore, it should be purged.[53p]
If there is swelling and pain, or no pus forms, it indicates the stagnation of evil qi, and it should be resolved. If there is swelling and pain accompanied by chills and fever, it signifies heat, and it should be cleared. If there is no pus, or it does not break or constrict, it indicates deficiency of yang qi, and it should be tonified. If the affected flesh does not decay, or if toxins accumulate without resolution, it indicates deficiency of yang qi, and yang qi should be supported. If there is a lot of pus or clear pus, it indicates deficiency of both qi and blood, and it should be replenished vigorously.

If the right guan pulse is weak and the muscles grow slowly, one should strengthen the spleen and stomach. If the initial condition has not surfaced, but there are chills, fever, pain, and thirst with a preference for cold drinks, this indicates latent evil qi; the remedy is Xianfang Huomailing Decoction. If there is dry mouth and thirst, diffuse swelling with slight pain, this indicates deficiency of original qi; the remedy is Tori Xiaodu Powder. With little appetite and thought, with fatigue in the limbs, this indicates weakness of the spleen and stomach; the remedy is Liu Junzi Decoction. If symptoms persist, add ginger and cassia. If there are those who are in critical condition, it indicates excess of evil qi and deficiency of true qi, preventing it from surfacing, typically seen within a ten-day period.

If the condition has already emerged, use Tori Xiaodu Powder. If there is no decay or suppuration, use Tori Powder; if it is unresponsive, urgently warm and tonify the spleen and stomach. If there are critically ill individuals, it indicates that true qi is deficient and cannot decay, typically seen within a two-week period.

If there is already decay and suppuration, use Tori Powder to generate flesh. If it is unresponsive, urgently warm and tonify the spleen and stomach.[54p]
If there are deaths, it is due to weak Qi of the spleen that cannot consolidate. This condition can be observed over the course of a month. Although these three indicators are not found in classical texts, I have treated and verified them through experience.

When treating the initial stage of a carbuncle that has not formed pus, first apply black gold ointment or aid-life ointment to the affected area a few times to counteract the prevailing condition, and then take the Immortal Vitality Decoction. If appetite is low or the patient is not fond of flavorful foods, use Six Gentlemen Decoction with added sweet basil and take three to five doses. If the outer skin is corrupted, wash it with the arsenic detoxifying powder, applying black gold ointment to the corrupted area daily. When a sore appears, use a piece of paper twisted to dip into black gold ointment and insert it into the sore. If there is pus trapped between the muscle membranes causing swelling and pain, use a needle to draw it out, removing any obstructing rotten flesh. If there is necrotic flesh that is corrupted, wash it with pig's foot broth. If the pus is thick and painful, while the patient maintains normal eating habits, and the necrotic flesh is naturally decaying, use disinfectant medications along with medicines to remove toxins, and continue applying black gold ointment. If the necrotic flesh has separated from healthy tissue, remove it. If the pus is neither thick nor thin, presenting slight pain and decreased appetite, and the necrotic flesh is decaying slowly, apply moxa to the affected area using mulberry wood and treat with medications that support the interior. If the necrotic flesh does not decay or the pus is clear and thin, and there is no significant pain, take large tonic prescriptions and continue using mulberry wood moxa to replenish the Yang energy and dissipate stagnated toxins, allowing the flesh to decay naturally.[55p]
Medical Principles: Six Essentials

Pain Causes

For those who suffer from waist and back pain due to prolonged reading or sitting in games, it is associated with deficiency. The main treatment is Shenqi Decoction, along with Bawei Decoction. Overweight individuals with phlegm, particularly older ones who experience pain alleviated by hitting, are attributed to phlegm and deficiency; they should focus on eliminating dampness and phlegm while also tonifying the spleen and kidneys.

After excessive drinking or eating, if pain occurs with a desire to be hit, it is due to the spleen's inability to transport, leading to damp heat. One should regulate their diet. Slim individuals often suffer from blood deficiency and Yin deficiency, and they cannot indulge in alcohol or rich foods as a result. Nourishing blood and clearing heat can be achieved with Siwu Decoction, Jiuqing (Wine with Scutellaria), Lian, and paeonia.

For back pain, one should add Qianghuo and Fangfeng to guide treatment along the meridians; overweight individuals should minimize the use of Fuzi. Individuals with a history of deficiency, as well as those recovering from illness or childbirth, may experience heart pain or radiating pain to the sides of the chest or back. This is due to the reversal of vital energy; one must guide it back to the source and should not further relax or press, as it will lead to increased pain.

Those who sweat excessively often suffer from this condition and should focus on warm supplementation. Being bound by pain prevents effective treatment; sweat is the liquid of the heart, and if excessive, it depletes heart fluid and leads to insufficient Yang energy, resulting in pain.[56p]
