旧有用鸡冠剪血滴于疽上者，有酢煮雄艾敷围者，猪脑热药敷围者，神灯火气灼照者，此数法皆阴疽之用。予虽尝用，未见其实。但阴疽不起者，如树木之根坏，强力培植枝叶，而终无发生之理。予尝据理用药，固有得其生者，十中三四。譬之稼穑，先疏其土，通其地脉，助其根本，回其阳气，此四者缺一不可。用苍朮、厚朴、茯苓、陈皮疏其上，川芎、当归、柴草、红花通其脉，人参、黄芪、枸杞、山萸助其本，附子、木香、甘草、独活回其阳。如此用之，但根本内有一脉未绝之气，服之俱可得生。又验其手足温暖，疮便发热，渐作臖肿，复生疼痛，色暗得活，坚硬得腐，胃气得回，此是药之效验，必在三服中应之为吉。外兼照法接助回阳，此通治阴疽之大法也。[113p]

In the past, methods such as using a chicken comb to cut and let blood drip onto the sore, applying vinegar-boiled male mugwort, using pig brain heat medicine as a poultice, and using divine lamp heat to cauterize were all treatments for yin sores. Although I have tried these, I have not seen significant results. However, when a yin sore does not develop, it is like the roots of a tree becoming rotten; cultivating the branches and leaves vigorously does not lead to growth. I have tried using medications according to principle, and it is true that out of ten cases, three or four can recover.

This is akin to agriculture: one must first loosen the soil, unblock the land veins, support the roots, and revive the yang energy. Each of these four steps is essential. Use astragalus, magnolia bark, Poria, and dried tangerine peel to unblock the upper part, and use light artemisia, angelica, chaff, and safflower to open the veins. For the roots, use ginseng, astragalus, goji berries, and mountain cornel to support them, while aconite, lemongrass, licorice, and angelica can revive the yang. If used in this way, as long as there is still a pulse of vitality within the roots, taking these can lead to recovery.

Moreover, if the hands and feet feel warm, the sores produce heat, gradually swelling occurs, and the pain returns, with dark colors indicating vitality and hardness indicating decay, while stomach energy is restored, then this is a sign of the efficacy of the medicine. It should manifest as auspicious within three doses. Additionally, externally, complementary methods to assist in reviving yang are to be combined, as this constitutes the great method for treating yin sores.[113p]

　　神灯照法　治发背初起，七日前后，未成者自消，已成者自溃，不起发者即发，不腐溃者即腐，诚为良法也。　　雄黄　朱砂　血竭　没药各二钱　麝香四分　　右五味，研为细末，每用三分，绵纸裹药为捻，长约尺许，以真麻油润透，燃如灯火，离疮半寸许，自外而内，周围徐徐照之，火头向上，药气入内。疮毒随火解散，自不内侵脏腑。初用三条，渐加至四五条，候疮势渐消渐减，熏后随用敷药。如已溃大脓发泄时，不必用此照敷，只宜用膏药盖贴。[114p]

Chonghe Gao is used to treat carbuncles that manifest on the back, particularly when there is disharmony between yin and yang, and when the distinction between hot and cold is unclear. It should be applied as follows:

Zhu Ba Tong is used for carbuncles that have matured; when they are about to burst, if the pus and toxins do not expel outward, it will lead to internal issues, resulting in irritability and a feeling of heaviness as if bearing a stone. Without this method of extraction, it is difficult for toxins to exit.

Ingredients include:

  • Notopterygium incisum
  • Angelica pubescens
  • Perilla leaves
  • Mugwort
  • Fresh calamus
  • Liquorice
  • Angelica dahurica, each 15 grams (5 qian)
  • 20 stalks of scallions
  • A piece of fresh bamboo roughly the thickness of 3-4 cm (1.2-1.5 inches) and about 18 cm (7 inches) long, leaving a joint at one end. Remove the outer green with a knife, leaving a white inner section about 0.3 cm (1/10 inch) thick. Drill a small hole near the joint, tightly sealing it with a willow stick. Place the powdered herbs inside the tube, sealing the open end with scallions. Place the tube horizontally in a pot, weighting it down to prevent it from floating. Use 10 bowls of clear water to boil the tube until the medicine is richer and thoroughly cooked, and then remove it for future use.[117p]

再用铍针于疮顶上一寸内，品字放开三孔，深入浅寸，约筒圈内，将药筒连汤，用大磁钵盛贮，患者榻前将药筒倒出，急用筒口乘热，对疮合上，以手捺紧，其筒自然吸住。约待片时，药筒已温，拔去塞孔木条，其筒自脱。将器倒出筒中物色，看其何样，如有脓血相粘，鲜明红黄之色，约有一二杯许，其病乃是活疮，治必终愈。如拔出物色纯是败血，气秽紫黑，稀水而无脓意相粘者，其病气血内败，肌肉不活，必是死疮，强治亦无功矣。此法家传，屡经有验。如阳疮易溃易脓之证，不必用此，以伤气血。只可用之于阴疮，要在十五日前后，坚硬不溃不脓者行之最当。此法的有回天之效，医家不可缺也。[118p]

Using a beryllium needle, place it within an inch above the top of the sore, and create three openings in a pattern. Insert it to a shallow depth, approximately within the boundary of the tube. Connect the medicinal tube to the decoction and store it in a large ceramic bowl. In front of the patient, pour out the contents of the tube and, while hot, apply the open end of the tube to the sore, pressing it down firmly with your hand, allowing it to naturally adhere. After a while, when the tube has warmed, remove the wooden plug from the hole, and the tube should come off by itself.

Examine the contents poured out of the tube. If you see a mixture of pus and blood that is bright red and yellow in color, roughly equivalent to one or two cups, this indicates an active sore, which will definitely heal with treatment. However, if the contents are purely decomposed blood, with foul, dark purple-black characteristics, thin and watery without signs of pus, this indicates that the energy and blood are severely depleted inside, with non-vital muscle tissue, signifying a dead sore, which cannot be cured even with forceful treatment.

This method is a family tradition and has been verified many times. For sores that easily rupture and produce pus, this method should not be used, as it would harm the energy and blood. It can only be applied to stagnant sores, ideally those that are firm, don’t rupture, and don’t produce pus about fifteen days prior. This method has the potential to restore vitality, and it is essential for practitioners of medicine to know it.[118p]

　　援生膏　治一切恶疮初起，点破虽未全消，亦得以杀其毒。　　雄黄五钱　轻粉　蟾酥各三钱　乳香　没药　血竭各一钱　麝香五分　　右用荞麦秸灰，或真炭灰一斗二升，淋灰汤八九碗，将栗柴或桑柴文武火煎作三碗，以备日久药干添用。取二碗盛于磁器内，将前药碾为极细末，入灰汤内用铁杆或柳枝顺搅，再入好细石灰一升，再搅匀，过一宿，却分于小磁罐收贮。凡遇诸恶疮，点当头一二点，一日换二次，次日又二次。须出血水为妙。如药干却加所存灰汤少许调之。
　　神功散　治发背一切疮疡，不问阴阳肿溃，并效。　　黄蘗炒　川乌炮
　　右另为末，各等分，用唾津谪敷患处，并涂疮口。一道人不问阴阳肿溃，虚实痛否，此药用漱口水调搽，不留疮头，日易之，内服仙方活命饮甚效。[121p]

The area where there is swelling should be treated to detoxify it; applying on bruised flesh will cause it to whiten. Adding a little frankincense is also effective. If the remaining toxins are deeply embedded and cannot be contained, it would be appropriate to dress it in this manner, preventing it from turning into a discharge.

Yuan Sheng Ointment treats all newly occurring malignant sores. Even if they have not fully disappeared after breaking, it can still kill the toxins. The formula consists of: Five qian of realgar, three qian each of light powder and toad venom, one qian each of frankincense, myrrh, and dragon’s blood, and five fen of musk.

Take one dao (approximately 67 liters) of buckwheat stalk ash or true charcoal ash, mix eight to nine bowls of ash soup, boil three bowls using chestnut wood or mulberry wood over moderate and strong heat for a long time to prepare. Take two bowls and place them in a ceramic container, grind the previous herbs into very fine powder, and mix them into the ash soup using an iron rod or willow branch while stirring. Then add one liter of good fine lime, mix well, and let it sit overnight. Afterwards, portion it into small ceramic jars for storage. For all malignant sores, apply one or two dots to the affected area, changing twice a day, and another two times the next day. It is ideal to draw out blood and water. If the medicine dries out, add a little of the reserved ash soup to adjust.

Shengong Powder treats all wounds and sores on the back regardless of their nature, whether inflamed or ruptured. Use fried berberine and prepared chuanwu in equal parts.

Mix into a powder and apply using saliva on the affected area, as well as on the wound opening. This remedy works regardless of the type of swelling or its condition, and whether there is pain or not. This medicine can be diluted with mouthwash for topical application, ensuring it does not remain on the sore. Change it daily, and for internal use, the "Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin" is very effective.[121p]

Immortal's Vitality Decoction

Treats all types of ulcers. For those not yet suppurated, it aims to resolve from within; for those already suppurated, it will cause them to burst. It is also a holy medicine for draining pus, relieving pain, and disinfecting.

Ingredients:

  • Cooked pangolin scales (stir-fried until yellow)
  • Licorice root (節)
  • Fangfeng (防风)
  • Myrrh (沒藥)
  • Red peony (赤芍)
  • Angelica dahurica (白芷)
  • Soapberry (皂刺, stir-fried until yellow)
  • Angelica sinensis (归尾)
  • Frankincense (乳香), each one piece
  • Tianhuafen (天花粉) and Fritillaria (贝母), each eight parts
  • Honeysuckle (金银花) and dried tangerine peel (陈皮), each three parts

Prepare one dose, mix with a bowl of wine, seal the bottle mouth with paper to prevent air leakage, and simmer over a slow fire until it boils several times. Strain out the dregs and divide according to the patient’s condition, taking it before and after meals. If able, having two to three more cups of wine is even better.

Divine Efficacy Decoction

Treats carbuncles and furuncles, as well as all swollen and painful toxins, accompanied by chills and heat.

Ingredients:

  • Astragalus (黄芪) mixed with salt water and stir-fried
  • Honeysuckle (金银花)
  • Angelica sinensis (当归)
  • Phragmites (粉草), each one piece

Prepare one dose, mix with a cup of wine and a cup of water, and simmer down to one cup. Divide according to the patient’s condition, taking it before and after meals. After a while, take another dose and apply it to the affected area. It can be used regardless of the size and condition of the swelling, suitable for old and young, whether weak or strong. As a powder mixed with wine, it is especially effective.

Treats carbuncles, restlessness due to consuming cold drinks, renal pain, and fullness in the pulse, constipation, and hematuria.

Prepare one dose, using two cups of water, and simmer down to 80% (one and a half cups). Take before meals.[122p]

Complete Record of Medical Works, Volume 178

Back Gate

Single Prescription

For back sores: Take wall soil that has been smoked for many years and yellow vine, grind them into powder, mix with ginger juice, and apply. Additionally, take a decoction of fragrant grass and drink one qian. The wall soil should be from the east and face the sun.
—(From "Proven Experience Prescriptions")

Another prescription: Take the mud from the bottom of a latrine, dry it in the shade, grind it into powder, and mix with fresh water to apply; the pain will stop immediately.
—(From "Shi Zhen")

For impending severe back pain: Take powdered dragon liver and mix it with wine to apply thickly; once it dries, replace it, and when it’s evened out, it will stop.
—(From "Qian Jin Prescriptions")

For boils and back pain: Grind vinegar and mix it with dark ink to apply around the sore, and use pig bile in the center. When it dries, apply again; it will dissipate overnight.
—(From "Zhao's Formula")

Another prescription: Take dust from the kitchen and grind it into powder, then mash with very tender green onions to create a paste for application, keeping it on top. Change it daily, moistening with water if it dries out.
—(From "Simplified Collection Prescriptions")

Another prescription: Use three taels of licorice, lightly roasted, and immerse it in a bucket of one dou of wine. Add one pound of black lead, melt it, and mix it with the wine; do this nine times, then strain. Drink and get drunk; you will be cured.
—(From "Proven Experience Prescriptions")

For severe sores and various boils: Use two taels of fine white powder and three taels of pure sesame oil, simmer on low heat while stirring urgently with willow branches until it forms beads when dripping. Add a little white glue powder, place in a container, soak in water for two days, and apply with oil paper; this is called the divine responding ointment.
—(From "Straightforward Prescriptions")[124p]

　　发背初起：铁浆饮二升，取利。 【 《外台秘要》】
　　疽疮发背：银朱白矾等分，煎汤温洗，却用桑柴火远远灸之，日三次，甚效。 【 《救急方》】
　　麦饭石膏，治发背疮甚良，乃中岳山人吕子华秘方。取麦饭石，石大小不等，或如拳，或如鹅卵，或如饼，大略状。如握聚一团，麦饭有粒点，如豆如米，其色黄白，但于溪间麻石中寻有此状者，即是。取此石碎如棋子，炭火烧赤，投米酢中浸之，如此十次，研末筛细，入乳钵内，用数人更碾，五七日，要细腻细面，四两；鹿角一具，要生取连脑骨者，其自脱者不堪用，每二三寸截之，炭火烧，令烟尽即止，为末研细，二两；白蔹生研末二两，用三年米酢入银石器内煎，令鱼目沸，旋入药在内，竹枝子不住搅，熬一二时久，稀稠得所，顷在盆内待冷，以纸盖收，勿令尘入。用时以鹅翎拂膏，于肿上四围赤处尽涂之，中留钱大泄气。[125p]

For the initial onset of a back abscess: take two sheng of iron soup, and it is beneficial.

For carbuncles and sores on the back: mix equal parts of vermilion and white alum, boil in water, and wash the affected area while using mulberry wood to perform distant cauterization three times a day, which is very effective.

For treating back sores, Mica stone powder is very good; it is a secret recipe from the hermit Lü Zihua of Mount Zhongyue. Take Mica stone, which varies in size - some are like fists, some like goose eggs, others like cakes, generally resembling a gathered mass. The stone has small grains that appear like beans or rice, and is either yellow or white; it can be found among the gravelly stones in streams. Crush the stone into pieces the size of chess pieces, then heat it in charcoal until it glows red. Soak it in rice vinegar for ten times, then grind it into a fine powder. Place it in a mortar and grind further for five to seven days until it reaches a very fine texture, amounting to four ounces; take one set of deer antlers, preferably fresh with the brain bone intact; those that have shed are not usable. Cut them into two or three-inch pieces, char them until the smoke stops, then grind into a fine powder, amounting to two ounces; take two ounces of white peony root, grind it into powder, and boil in three-year-old rice vinegar inside a silver vessel, bringing it to a boil; then add the other powdered ingredients while stirring continuously with a bamboo branch. Cook for one or two hours until the desired consistency is achieved, then cool in a basin, covering it with paper to keep out dust. When using, apply with a goose feather over the swelling and the surrounding areas that are red, leaving an area the size of a coin to allow for air escape.[125p]

如末有脓即内消，已作头即撮小，已溃即排脓如湍水。若病久肌肉烂落，见出筋骨者，即涂细布上贴之，干即易，逐日疮口收敛。但失陷下穴者，即无不瘥。已溃者，用时先以猪蹄汤洗去脓血，故帛拭干，乃用药。其疮切忌手触动嫩肉，仍不可以口气吹风，及腋气月经有孕人见之，合药亦忌此等。初时一日一洗一换，十日后二日一换。此药要极细，方有效。若不细，涂之即极痛也。此方孙真人《千金》月令已有之，但不及此该悉且尽。又北齐马嗣明治杨遵彦背疮，取粗黄石如鹅卵大者，猛火烧赤，纳浓酢中，当有屑落酢中，再烧再淬石至尽，取屑日干，捣筛极细末，和酢涂之，立愈。刘禹锡《传信方》谓之炼石法，用敷疮肿无不验。[126p]

If there is pus, it can be dissipated within; if it forms a head, it should be pressed small; if it has burst, the pus should be expelled like rushing water. If the illness has lasted long and the flesh is rotting away, exposing the tendons and bones, then apply fine cloth to cover it, changing it when dry, with the wound gradually closing day by day. However, if it has sunk into a cavity, it will not heal. For those that have burst, first wash away the pus and blood with pig’s hoof broth, then dry the area with cloth before applying medication. It is crucial to avoid touching the tender flesh with hands and do not blow air from the mouth onto it. Also, avoid contact with the scent of armpits, menstruating women, and pregnant individuals; these are to be avoided in conjunction with medication. Initially, wash and change once a day; after ten days, change every two days. The medication must be extremely fine to be effective. If not finely ground, application will cause extreme pain. This method has been noted in Sun Zhenren's "Qianjin" and is comprehensive in detail. Additionally, during the Northern Qi era, Ma Siming treated Yang Zunyan's back sore by taking coarse yellow stone, about the size of an egg, heating it strong fire until red, immersing it in strong vinegar, allowing impurities to fall into the vinegar, then heating and steeping it until finished. The resulting particles should be sun-dried, ground to an extremely fine powder, mixed with vinegar, and applied, leading to immediate healing. Liu Yuxi's "Chuanxin Fang" referred to it as the stone refining method, validated for treating swellings and sores.[126p]

For back abscesses: Crush fresh sweet flag and apply; for dry sores, use the powdered form and mix with water to apply.

At the beginning of a back abscess, with swelling, redness, and heat: Crush purple back duckweed, mix with egg white for application.

For back abscesses: Use powdered stone bristlewort, fried, mixed with cold wine for internal consumption.

For boils and abscesses on the back, and all kinds of swelling and toxic conditions: Use two liang each of buckwheat flour and sulfur, grind into powder, mix with well water to form cakes, and dry them. For each use, grind a cake with water to apply. If it hurts, it should alleviate the pain; if it doesn’t hurt, it should induce pain, leading to healing.

Another method: Fry glutinous rice flour until black, mix with egg white, apply it on the affected area and cut a hole for the sore to breathe. Once it dries, it's easy to remove and very effective.[136p]

　　背疮热肿：蕺菜捣汁涂之，留孔以泄热毒，冷则易之。 【 《经验方》】
　　发背恶疮：重阳日收老茄子百枚，去蒂四破切之，硝石十二两捣碎，以不津器先铺茄子一重，乃下硝石一重，如此间铺，令尽，以纸数层密封，安置净处，上下以新砖承覆，勿犯地气，至正月后取出，去纸两重，日中曝之，逐日如此，至二三月度，茄已烂开，瓶倾出，滤去滓，别入新器中，以薄绵尽头，又曝至成膏，乃可用。每以酒调半匙，空腹饮之，日再。更以膏涂疮口四围，觉冷如冰，疮干便瘥。其有根本在肤腠者，亦可内消。若膏久干硬，即以饭饮化动用之。【 《图经本草》】
　　痈疽发背，大如盘，臭腐不可近：桐叶酢蒸贴上，退热止痛，渐渐生肉收口。极验秘方也。【 《医林正宗》】　　发背散血：槐花菉豆粉各一升，同炒象牙色，研末，用细茶一两，煎一碗，露一夜，调末三钱敷之，留头。勿犯妇女手。【 《摄生妙用方》】[137p]

Boil on the Back: Apply juice of wild ferns, leaving an opening to release heat and toxins; change when cool.

Malignant sores on the back: On the Double Ninth Festival, gather one hundred old eggplants, remove stems, cut into four pieces. Crush twelve taels of saltpeter. In a dry container, first layer with eggplant, then add a layer of saltpeter like this until used up. Seal with several layers of paper, place in a clean location, and cover with new bricks to avoid contact with ground moisture. After the first month, take it out, remove two layers of paper, and expose to sunlight at noon. Do this daily until two or three months pass; the eggplant will decay. Tilt the bottle to pour out and filter out the residue, transferring the liquid into a new container. Use fine cotton to absorb the end and continue exposing it to sun until it forms a paste, which is then ready for use. Mix half a spoon with wine and drink on an empty stomach twice a day. Also apply the paste around the sore, and it will feel cold like ice; when the sore dries, it will heal. If there is a root in the skin and pores, it can also be resolved internally. If the paste dries and hardens, use rice wine to dissolve it for application.

For abscesses on the back, large as a plate and foul-smelling: Steam with catalpa leaves and apply, which will reduce heat and pain, gradually promoting new tissue growth to close the wound. This is a highly effective secret recipe.

For blood dispersion on the back: Combine one sheng each of sophora flower and polygala powder, fry until ivory-colored, and grind into a fine powder. Use one tael of fine tea, simmer to make a bowl, let it steep overnight, then mix three qian of the powder and apply, leaving the head intact. Avoid contact with the hands of women.[137p]

　　痈疽发背：榆根白皮切，清水洗，捣极烂，和香油敷之，留头出气。燥则以苦茶频润。不粘更换新者。将愈，以桑叶嚼烂，随大小贴之，口合乃止，神效。【 《救急方》】
　　痈疽发背：巴豆树根掘取洗捣，敷患处，留头，妙不可言。收根阴干，临时水捣亦可。【 《经验方》】
　　发背初生，一切痈疽皆治：单用紫荆皮为末，酒调箍住，自然撮小不开，内服柞木饮子，乃救贫良剂也。【 《仙传外科》】
　　痈疽发背：用豮猪腰子一双，同飞面捣如泥，涂之即愈。
　　槐花酒，治发背一切疮毒，不问已成未成，但臖痛者并治之：槐花四五两，微炒黄，乘热入酒二锺，煎十余沸，去滓热服。未成者二三服，已成者一二服。又洽湿热疮疥，肠风痔漏，诸疮作痛，尤效。　　又方：用乱发烧灰，酒服方寸匕。[138p]

Boils and sores on the back: Take the white skin of elm roots, cut it, wash it in clear water, pound it until extremely fine, mix with fragrant oil and apply it, leaving the head exposed for breathing. When healing, chew mulberry leaves until soft and apply them according to the size, stopping when the mouth is closed; it is remarkably effective.

For boils and sores on the back: Dig up the roots of the castor bean tree, wash and pound, and apply to the affected area, leaving the head exposed; it is indescribably effective. Collect the roots, dry them in the shade, and pounding them with water at the time of use is also acceptable.

For newly developing sores and boils: Simply use powdered purple osmanthus bark mixed with wine to keep them small and prevent them from opening. Internally take dowry oak decoction; it is a remedy for the poor.

For boils and sores on the back: Use two pig kidneys, pound them with flour into a paste, and apply it to heal.

Sophora flower wine treats all types of sores and toxins on the back, regardless of whether they are formed or not; any painful ones should also be treated. Use four or five taels of sophora flowers, slightly fry until yellow, then infuse in two bowls of wine, boil for over ten minutes, then strain and take warm. For unformed sores, take two or three doses; for formed ones, take one or two doses. It is also excellent for damp-heat sores and scabies, intestinal wind, hemorrhoids, and other painful sores.

Another recipe: Use ashes from burnt hair, take with wine in a spoonful.[138p]

　　又方：猪脂敷上，日四五度，亦治发乳，救急方云；取猪羊脂切作片，冷水浸贴上，暖即易之，五六十片瘥。若初贴少许即寒，寒定好眠，甚效。　　又方：三年酢滓，微火煎。令稠，和牛脂敷上。　　又方：猪、狗牙烧灰，酢和敷上，日三四易。　　又方：古蚌烧灰，鸡子白和敷之，日三易。
　　远志酒，治一切痈疽发背疖毒恶候，若有死血阴毒在中则不痛，敷之即痛；有忧怒等气积而内攻，则痛不可忍，傅之即不痛；或蕴热在内，热逼人手，不可近，敷之必清凉；或气虚血冷，溃而不敛，若七情内郁，治之必愈。用远志不以多少，泔浸捶去心为末，酒一盏，调末三钱，澄清饮之，以滓敷于患处。【 《医学纲目》】

Use Yuan Zhi without measuring, soak in water and pound it into a powder, take a cup of wine, mix with three qian of the powder, and drink the clear solution while applying the residue to the affected area.

To treat the initial swelling of boils or ulcers on the back: Use two taels of slaked lime and one tael of Asarum, grind into coarse powder, mix with hot vinegar and apply to the affected area. After it dries, reapply; do this three times and the swelling will subside.[139p]

　　有人患背疽，已溃如碗面大，视五脏仅膈膜耳，自谓必死。用大鲫鱼一枚，去肠脏，以羯羊粪入其中，烘焙焦黑，极燥，为细末，干掺之，疮口遂收，后竟无恙。此方累用有效。须候脓少欲生肌肉时用之。　　又方：治背疽久不收口，用川椒去目炒黑一钱，定粉风化硝各二钱，白矾二钱半，乳香没药各一钱，共为末掺之。

　　发背：用金银藤取五六两捣烂，入热酒一锺，搅匀取汁，酒温服，滓罨患处，四五服立效。【 《赵氏医贯》】[140p]

A person suffered from a carbuncle on the back, which had ulcerated to the size of a bowl. He thought he would surely die as it only exposed the diaphragm and the five internal organs. A method was used involving one large crucian carp, with its intestines removed. Sheep dung was placed inside, baked until charred and extremely dry, and then finely powdered and applied. The wound eventually closed and he was left unharmed. This method has been effective when used repeatedly. It is best applied when the pus is reducing and new flesh is desired.

Another method for treating a carbuncle that has not healed: roast a set amount of Sichuan pepper until black, use two weights each of powdered wind-blown salt and white alum, and one weight each of myrrh and frankincense, then mix into a powder to apply.

To treat an ulcerated sore on the back where flesh is growing rapidly but the skin isn’t covering it, and is stiffening at the slightest breeze: grind cold water stone into a fine powder and apply to the sore. Then apply a fine powder of verdigris on top, and the flesh will stop becoming stiff.

For all types of back boils and unknown swellings: in the third month, gather shrimps and put them in a jar. Grind one tael each of realgar and vermilion into fine powder, add it to the jar, and expose it to sunlight. Retrieve it by the Dragon Boat Festival for use. If applied to a sore, grind it with water and dot it on, and it will instantly diminish.

For carbuncles on the back: fry the seeds of cocklebur until yellow, remove the thorns, fry again until dark yellow (avoiding wind), then grind to a fine powder. Take five qian with hot wine before meals and before sleeping.

For carbuncles: take five to six liang of silver vine, mash it up, mix in hot wine, stir to extract the juice, and take it warm while pouring over the affected area. After four to five doses, it will be effective.[140p]

　　　　针灸

　　《素问》曰：足太阳之疟，令人腰痛头重，寒从背起，先寒后热，熇熇暍暍然，热止汗出难已，刺郄中出血。　　疟脉满大急，刺背俞旁五胠俞各一，适肥瘦出其血也。　　先项背痛者，先刺之。[141p]

Chicken Blood Powder, for treating back pain: Use a red rooster, trimming a bit off the comb, and hold it upside down over the wound until the blood is fully drained, then replace it. Usually, five or six roosters will suffice; pain will stop and toxins will dissipate, allowing the wound to heal on its own. Internally, use six taels of ginseng, divided into six portions, and simmer for daily consumption.

For carbuncles: Use the liver of a hidden dragon, mix with chicken yolk and apply, or mix with vinegar or garlic and pound together to apply—both are effective.

For back pain: Take the whole root and leaves of the white balsam and pound them into a paste. First, wash the affected area with rice vinegar, then apply the medicine, changing it once a day, and it works wonders.

For back sores: Take the leaves of the rattan and pound them into a paste, extract the juice and mix with honey, drink several liters, and apply the residue to the sore. Another method: finely grind the rattan leaves with wine, extract the juice, boil several times, and consume.

For back pain: Use hibiscus flowers and leaves, dry them and powder them, mix with vinegar for application; white lotus is especially good.

Acupuncture

The "Suwen" states: For the foot taiyang malarial fever, one experiences waist pain and heavy-headedness, with cold rising from the back; first cold, then heat, with feverish discomfort and difficulty sweating once the heat subsides. Needle the xue point for bleeding. The malarial pulse is fast and full; needle the back-shu points and the five hu points, regulating for both fat and thin. If neck or back pain occurs first, needle that area first.[141p]

　　风疟，疟发则汗出恶风，刺三阳经背俞之血者。　　肺热病者，热争则喘咳，痛走胸膺背，不得太息，头痛不堪，汗出而寒，丙丁甚，庚辛大汗，气逆则丙丁死。刺手太阴阳明，出血如大豆，立已。　　刺脊间，中髓为伛。
　　深专者刺大脏。迫脏刺背，背俞也。　　病在少腹有积，刺侠脊两旁四椎间，刺两髂髎季胁肋间，导腹中气热下已。　　背与心相控而痛，所治天突与十椎及上纪。上纪者，胃脘也。下纪者，关元也。　　《灵枢》曰：足太阳之别，名曰飞扬，去踝七寸，别走少阴。实则鼽窒头背痛，虚则鼽衄，取之所别也。　　督脉之别，名曰长强，挟脊上项，散头上，下当肩胛，左右别走太阳，入贯膂。实则脊强，虚则头重，高摇之，挟脊之有过者，取之所别也。　　厥挟脊而痛至顶，头沉沉然，目(目巟)(目巟)然，腰脊强，取足太阳腘中血络。　　心痛引背不得息，刺足少阴。[142p]

Wind-cold malaria causes sweating and aversion to wind when it attacks; it should be treated by needling the back points of the three yang meridians. In the case of lung heat illness, the heat leads to wheezing and coughing, causing pain that radiates through the chest and back, preventing deep sighing, accompanied by severe headaches, sweating accompanied by chills, and when the heat is intense, it can lead to death. Needling the hand's taiyin and yangming points can help by drawing blood like the size of a large bean, which provides immediate relief.

Needling along the spine's intervertebral spaces, especially the mid-spinal cord, is significant. For deep and serious conditions, needling the major organs is essential. If there is an accumulation in the lower abdomen, needle the spaces on either side of the spine around four vertebrae and around the iliac crests at the sides of the ribs, guiding the Qi and heat from the abdomen downward.

When pain in the back is related to the heart, treatment should focus on the Tian Tui point and the ten vertebrae along with the upper and lower junctures; the upper juncture refers to the stomach area, while the lower juncture refers to the Guanyuan point. The "Lingshu" states: for the foot taiyang branch, called Feiyang, located seven cun above the ankle, it branches to flow into the shaoyin. If there is fullness, it causes stuffiness and pain in the head and back; if there is deficiency, it leads to nasal hemorrhage, addressing the branches.

The branch of the Governing Vessel is called Changqiang; it runs along the spine to the nape, dispersing headaches and extending to the shoulders, left and right it branches into the taiyang, entering and mingling with the ribs. In cases of fullness, the spine becomes stiff; when deficient, there is a heavy sensation in the head; to alleviate it, treat the blood network in the popliteal area of the foot taiyang.

If there is heart pain that radiates to the back, hindering breathing, needle the foot shaoyin.[142p]

　　黄帝问于岐伯曰：愿闻五脏之俞出于背者。岐伯曰：背中大俞在杼骨之端，肺俞在三焦之间，心俞在五焦之间，膈俞在七焦之间，肝俞在九焦之间，脾俞在十一焦之间，肾俞在十四焦之间，皆挟脊相去三寸所。则欲得而验之，按其处，应在手而痛解，乃其俞也。灸之则可，刺之则不可。气盛则泻之，虚则补之。以火补者，毋吹其火，须自灭也。以火泻者，疾吹其火，传其艾，须其火灭也　　《金匮要略》曰：饮酒，大忌灸腹背，令人肠结。　　《甲乙经》曰：肩背痹痛不举，血瘀肩中不能动摇，巨骨主之。　　肩背不可自带衣，臂腕外侧痛不举，阳谷主之。　　肩背欲折，臑如拔，手不能自上下，养老主之。　　项背痛引颈，魄户主之。[143p]

The Yellow Emperor asked Qi Bo: "I wish to know the acupuncture points related to the five internal organs that are located on the back." Qi Bo replied: "The point for the middle jiao is at the end of the Zhou bone, the lung point is situated between the three jiaos, the heart point is in the middle of the five jiaos, the diaphragm point is located among the seven jiaos, the liver point is at the nine jiaos, the spleen point is at the eleven jiaos, and the kidney point is at the fourteen jiaos. All these points are three inches away from the spine. To verify these points, you should press on them; if it hurts, then it is indeed their point. Moxa can be used, but needles should not. If there is excess Qi, reduce it; if deficient, then tonify it. When using fire for tonification, do not blow on the flames; it should extinguish by itself. When using fire for reduction, blow on the flames swiftly, and for moxa, ensure it goes out.

The "Essential Prescriptions of the Golden Coffer" states that drinking alcohol is a major contraindication for moxibustion on the abdomen and back, as it can lead to intestinal blockage. The "Classic of the Shell and the Green" states that if there is pain or inability to lift the shoulder and back, it indicates blood stagnation in the shoulder, governed by the large bone. If one cannot wear clothes by themselves, and experiences pain on the outer side of the arm and wrist, it indicates the Yang Valley point. If there is a desire to break the shoulder with pain radiating downward, and the hand cannot move up or down independently, it indicates the Elderly Support point. Pain at the neck and back that radiates to the neck is governed by the Door of the Soul point.[143p]

　　肩痛胸满凄厥，脊背急强，神堂主之。　　肩背髀痛，臂不举，寒热凄索，肩井主之。　　腰脊痛不得俯仰，刺脊中睪，脊内廉痛，便难，阴痿不用，少腹急引阴及脚内廉内，阴谷主之。　　男子脊急目赤，支沟主之。
　　腰脊强，四肢懈惰，善怒，咳少气，郁然不得息，厥逆，肩不可举，阳乃痿，身瞤，章门主之。　　肾脉缓甚为折脊。
　　《千金方》曰：列缺主背寒栗，少气不足以息，寒厥，交两手而瞀。凡实则为背热背汗出，四肢暴肿；虚则肩寒栗，气不足以息。　　附分，主背痛引头。[144p]

Shoulder pain, chest fullness, and chills; the spine feels tight and stiff, governed by the shoulder.

Shoulder and back pain, inability to raise the arm, with both cold and heat causing discomfort, governed by the shoulder well.

Lower back pain makes bending and looking up difficult; needling the spine's center and interior results in pain, with difficulty in bowel movements, impotence, and drawing pain in the lower abdomen leading to the inner thigh, governed by the yin valley.

In men, if the back feels urgent and the eyes are red, governed by the support ditch.

Tightness in the lower back leads to lethargy in the limbs, frequent anger, a dry cough with little breath, a feeling of distress, chills, inability to lift the shoulder, and male impotency; the body trembles, governed by the chapter gate.

When the kidney pulse is very weak, it leads to spinal issues.

The "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" states: The separated void governs back cold and shivering, insufficient breath; with cold chills, crossing both hands leads to dizziness. If the condition is full, there is heat in the back, sweating, and limbs swelling violently; if empty, there is shoulder cold and shivering, with insufficient breath.

The attached points govern back pain that radiates to the head.[144p]

　　膈关、秩边、京骨，主背恶寒痛，脊强难以俯仰。　　鱼际，主痹走胸背，不得息。
　　经渠、丘墟，主胸背急，胸中彭彭。　　凡发背，皆因服食五石寒食更生散所致；亦有单服锺乳而发者；又有生平不服而自发背者又有生平不服而自发背者　原缺，据《千金》卷二十二补。，此是上代有服之者。其候率多于背两胛间起，初如粟米大，或痛或痒，仍作赤色，人皆初不以为事，日渐长大，不过十日，遂至于死。其临困之时，已阔三寸，高一寸，疮有数十孔，以手按之，诸孔中皆脓出，寻时失音。所以养生者，少觉背上痒痛有异，即火急取净土，水和为泥，捻饼作子，厚二分，阔一寸半，以粗艾大作炷，灸泥饼上，贴着疮上灸之，一炷一易饼子。若粟米大时，可灸七饼子即瘥；如榆荚大，灸七七饼炷即瘥；如钱大，可日夜灸之，不限炷数。仍服五香连翘汤及铁浆诸药攻之，乃愈。[145p]

The diaphragm, the border of the spine, and the vital bones govern the pain from cold in the back, causing stiffness that makes it difficult to bend or look up. The fish region governs the numbness that spreads across the chest and back, making it hard to breathe.

The condition commonly begins between the shoulder blades, initially resembling the size of a grain of millet, accompanied by either pain or itchiness while appearing red. At first, people do not regard it as serious, but over ten days it may grow larger, potentially leading to death. Therefore, for maintenance of health, when one feels an unusual itch or pain in the back, it is urgent to take pure earth, mix it with water to make a paste, and form into cakes that are two-finger thick and one and a half inches wide. Use coarse moxa to create sticks, and apply them to the sore where the mud cake is placed. Change the cake with each stick. When the sore is the size of a grain of millet, seven cakes will suffice for healing. If it is the size of a catalpa seed, use seven times seven sticks for treatment. If it is the size of a coin, treatment is not limited by the number of sticks used both day and night. Also, take the Five Spice Lonicera and Iron Juice to help combat the condition for healing.[145p]

又法：诸发背未作大脓，可以冷水射之，浸石令冷熨之，日夜莫住，瘥乃止。此病忌面、酒、五辛等。亦有当两肩上发者。　　凡肿起背胛间，头白如黍粟，四边相连，肿赤黑，令人闷乱，即名发背也。禁房室、酒肉、蒜面。若不灸治，即入内杀人。若灸，当疮上七八百壮。有人不识，多作杂证治者，皆死。　　《医学纲目》曰：针灸背痛有二法：其一取肺。经云：肺病者喘咳逆气，肩背痛，汗出，取其经太阴足太阳之外厥阴内血者。又云：肺手太阴之脉，气盛有余则肩背痛，风寒汗出，气虚则肩背痛寒，少气不足以息，视盛虚热寒陷下取之是也。　　其二，取肾。经云：邪在肾，则病肩背颈项痛，时眩，取之涌泉、昆仑，视有血者，尽取之是也。　　肩背痛连胛：取胛缝，在背踹骨下直腋缝尖及臂，取二寸半，泻六吸；五枢二寸半，泻八吸。　　肩背胛痛，取昆仑、悬锺、肩井。[146p]

　　脊膂并腰疼，取人中口含水突处，针入三分，略向上些，但泻无补，留三吸；委中二寸半，忌灸；又于四畔紫脉上，去血如藤块者，不可出血。出血不止令人夭。又泻三里、五枢。　　《薛氏医案》曰：神效桑枝灸，治发背不起，或瘀肉不溃，此阳气虚弱，用桑枝燃火着，吹熄焰，用火灸患处片时，日三五次以助肿溃。若腐肉已去，新肉生迟，宜灸四畔。其阴疮瘰疬流注臁疮恶疮久不愈者，亦宜用之。大抵此法未溃则解热毒，止疼痛，消瘀肿；已溃则补阳气，散余毒，生肌肉。其阳证肿痛，甚或重如负石，初起用此法出毒水，即内消；日久者，用之虽溃亦浅，且无苦楚。惜患者不知有此，治者亦不肯用此也。[148p]

　　隔蒜灸法，治一切疮毒发背大痛或不痛，或麻木。如痛者灸至不痛，不痛者灸至痛，其毒随火而散。盖火以畅达，拔引郁毒，此从治之法也，有回生之功。用大蒜去皮，切三文钱厚，安疮头上，用艾壮于蒜上，灸之三壮，换蒜复灸。未成者即消，已成者亦杀其大势，不能为害。如疮大用蒜捣烂，摊患处，将艾铺上烧之，蒜败再换。如不痛或不作脓，及不发起或阴疮，尤宜多灸，灸而仍不痛，不作脓，不起发者，不治。此气血虚极也。　　李氏云：凡患背疽漫肿无头者，用湿纸贴肿处，但一点先干处，乃是疮头。[149p]

　　　　导引

　　《保生秘要》曰：背作疼胀，导引法：以掌心搓之九九，乘热交搭于左右二肩，躬身用力，往来煽动九九之数，加以运功。　　运功即行艮背大小圈法。行后，手指至指甲散出滞气，于疼病亦如之。左疼行左，右疼行右，二边俱疼，分而行之。背疽运功，依患处念推而行之，或推开肺经升肾水洗之。　　附：艮背诀。故初学之士，静坐片时，将万虑扫除，凝神定志，于本穴之中背之腔子里，平心元虚处，初从口念太乙救苦，而渐归于心归于背，存无守有，念兹在兹，从有复冥于无，神自虚而灵矣。[155p]

Guidance

The "Secrets of Preserving Life" states: For back pain and swelling, the guiding method is: rub the palms together ninety-nine times, then apply the heat by pressing on both shoulders alternately. Bend and exert force, moving back and forth according to the count of ninety-nine, and perform the energy adjustment. The energy adjustment involves practicing the small and large circles on the back. After practicing, let your fingers spread the stagnant energy from the fingertips; this applies to pains as well. If there is pain on the left, move to the left; if on the right, move to the right. If both sides are painful, practice separately for each side. For back sores, perform energy adjustments focused on the affected area, or push to open the lung meridian to wash the kidney water.

Additionally: the back calming method. Therefore, beginners should sit quietly for a while, clearing all thoughts, concentrating and setting their intention in the cavity of the back at the acupoint. Initially, chant "Taiyi Saves from Suffering" aloud, gradually returning this chant to the heart and then to the back, maintaining a state of emptiness and tranquility. From thoughts of existence return to the state of non-existence; the spirit will become empty and responsive.[155p]

　　　　医案

　　《齐东野语》曰：族伯临川推官，平生以体孱气弱，多服乌、附、丹砂，晚年疽发于背，其大如扇。医者悉归罪于丹石之毒，凡菉豆粉、羊血解毒之品，莫不遍试，殊不少损。或以后市街祝老为荐者，祝本疡医，然指下极精。诊脉已，即云：非敢求异于诸公，然此乃极阴证。在我法中，正当多服伏火朱砂及三建汤，否则非吾所知也。诸子皆有难色，然其势已殆，姑尝试一二小料，而祝复俾作大剂顿服。三日后，始用膏药敷贴，而丹砂乌附，略不辍口，半月余而疮遂平。凡服三建汤二百五十服，此亦可谓奇工矣。洪景卢所载时康祖病心痔，用《圣惠方》治腰痛，鹿茸、附子药服之而差。又福州郭医用茸、附医漏痔疾，皆此类也。盖痈疽皆有阴阳证，要当一决于指下，而今世外科，往往不善于脉，每以私意揣摩，故多失之，此不可不精察也。[156p]

Medical Case

"The Eastern Q by Qi" states: A relative of the clique was a magistrate in Linchuan, who, throughout his life, was frail and weak, often consuming substances like black (dragon), aconite, and vermilion. In his later years, a sore developed on his back, growing to the size of a fan. The doctors attributed it entirely to the poison from the vermilion and stone. They tried various detoxifying items, such as mulberry and bean powder, and sheep's blood, but with no effect. Someone recommended the old healer Zhu from the market, who was known as a sore specialist but was particularly precise in his diagnosis. After examining his pulse, he said: "I do not wish to contradict what others may think, but this is indeed a case of extreme yin. According to my methods, he should take more of the fire-suppressing vermilion and Sanjian decoction; otherwise, it is beyond my knowledge." The doctors' sons all seemed troubled, yet the patient was in a dire state, so they cautiously tried one or two small doses, while Zhu insisted on a larger dosage to be taken immediately. Three days later, they began applying an ointment, while continuing to take the vermilion and aconite without interruption. After more than half a month, the sore healed completely. In total, he took Sanjian decoction two hundred and fifty times, which can indeed be called exceptional skill. Hong Jinglu recorded that Kangzu suffered from a heart-related hemorrhoid and used "Holy Benefit Formula" to treat back pain, with deer antler and aconite, which led to improvement. Similarly, Guo, a physician from Fuzhou, used antler and aconite to treat leaking hemorrhoids, and such cases are numerous. Indeed, sores and abscesses manifest both yin and yang symptoms, and it is essential to determine this through pulse examination. However, contemporary surgeons often lack proficiency in pulse diagnosis, frequently relying on personal conjecture, which results in many errors; this is something that must be examined with precision.[156p]

　　《本事方》曰：一人发背，医疗逾月，势益甚。有张生者，教以艾火灸其上，至一百五十壮，知痛乃止。明日镊去黑痂，脓尽溃，肉理皆红，不复痛，乃以膏药贴之，日一易，易时剪去黑烂，月余乃平复。
　　《疮疡全书》曰：一人年六十岁，冬至后发背疽，五七日肿势约七寸，开迟，故变证果生，觉疮重如负石，热如火，痛倍常，六脉沉数，按之有力，此膏粱积热之变，邪气酷热，寒药治之。时冬月严寒，复有用寒远寒之戒，乃思《内经》有假者反之，违其时，从其证，可也。[157p]

The "Ben Shi Fang" states: A person developed a boil on their back, and after more than a month of treatment, the condition worsened significantly. There was a man named Zhang who advised using moxa to burn the area, applying it up to one hundred and fifty times, stopping only when the pain was felt. The next day, when the black scabs were tweezed away, the pus was completely drained, and the flesh was all red and no longer painful. A medicinal plaster was then applied, changed daily, and during the changes, the black and rotten parts were trimmed. After more than a month, it healed completely.

The "Chuang Yang Quan Shu" states: A man aged sixty developed a back boil after the winter solstice. After five to seven days, the swelling extended about seven inches, and because the opening was delayed, it began to change. He felt the sore was as heavy as carrying a stone, burning like fire, and the pain was double the usual. The pulse was deep and rapid, and pressing on it revealed strength. This was a transformation due to excess heat from rich foods and the presence of severe pathogenic heat, which needed to be treated with cold medicine. It was a harsh winter month, and there was a caution against using cold medicine excessively. Thus, one might think of the Inner Canon and its guidance: when conditions are contrary to the season, one may still proceed according to the symptoms.[157p]

　　一人胸背皆驼，颈渐短，问其故，因食旱鳖所致。患上用紫苏煎汤洗净，次用龟尿擦之。取龟尿法，以龟置器中，用镜照之，则尿出矣。
　　一人背发一块，心神兀兀，四肢倦怠，饮食不进，一医曰，此虱瘤也，剖开果虱合许。甘草汤洗净拭干，将多年油木梳，煅灰为末，麻油调擦，立愈。
　　《儒门事亲》曰：一富家女，年十余岁，好食紫樱，每食即二三斤，岁岁如此，至十余年。一日，潮热如劳，戴人诊其两手，脉皆洪大而有力，谓之曰：他日必作恶疮肿毒，热上攻目，阳盛阴脱之证。其家大怒，不肯服解毒之药。不一二年，患一背疽如盘，痛不可忍。其女忽思戴人曾有是言，再三悔过请戴人，戴人以(金非)针绕疽晕刺数百针，去血一斗，如此三次，渐渐痛减肿消，微出脓而敛。将作痂时，使服十补内托散乃痊。终身忌口，然目亦昏，终身无子。[158p]

A man had a hunchback and a gradually shortening neck. When asked about the cause, he attributed it to eating drought-dwelling turtles. For treatment, purple shiso was boiled into a broth to wash the area, after which he applied tortoise urine. To obtain tortoise urine, one would place a tortoise in a vessel and shine a mirror on it, which would induce urination.

In another case, a man developed a lump on his back, feeling mentally exhausted and physically weak, with loss of appetite. A physician diagnosed it as a lice boil and recommended surgical removal. After cleansing with licorice soup and drying the area, he used an old wooden comb ground into ash, mixed it with sesame oil, and applied it, resulting in immediate healing.

According to "The Teachings of the Scholar on Caring for Parents," there was a wealthy girl, over ten years old, who loved to eat purple cherries, consuming two to three pounds each time and repeating this every year for over a decade. One day, feeling feverish as if from labor, a practitioner examined her and found her pulse to be strong and forceful, predicting that she would eventually suffer from festering sores and toxic swelling, with heat rising to affect her eyes, leading to an excess of yang and depletion of yin. Her family was enraged and refused to accept detoxifying medicine. Within a year or two, she developed a boil on her back as large as a plate, causing unbearable pain. She recalled the practitioner’s words and repeatedly sought his help, apologizing. He used a golden needle to prick around the boil hundreds of times, extracting a bucket of blood over three treatments, gradually reducing the pain and swelling, with slight pus discharge. As a scab began to form, he advised her to take a tonic and internal herbal powder, leading to her recovery. She avoided certain foods for the rest of her life, but her vision remained dim, and she remained childless.[158p]

　　《丹溪心法》曰：一男子忽患肩背胛缝一线疼，上跨肩至胸前侧胁而止，其痛昼夜不息，不可忍，其脉弦数，重取豁大，左大于右。夫背胛，小肠经也；胸胁，胆经也。此必思虑伤心，脏未病而腑先病，故痛从背胛起，谋虑不决，又归之胆，故痛至胸胁而止，乃小肠火来乘胆木，子来乘母，是为实邪。询之，果因谋虑不遂而病。以人参四钱，木通二钱，煎汤下龙荟丸数服，愈。
　　一人背伛偻，足挛，脉沉弦而细，以煨肾散与之，上吐下泻，凡三服乃愈。[159p]

The "Danxi Heart Method" states: A man suddenly suffers from a sharp pain along the seam of his shoulder and back, extending from the shoulder across to the front of the chest and stopping at the side of the abdomen. The pain persists day and night, unbearable, with a pulse that is taut and rapid, showing a stronger left side than the right. The area of the back and shoulder relates to the small intestine meridian, while the chest and abdomen relate to the gallbladder meridian. This is certainly due to excessive thinking and worry harming the heart; although the organs themselves are not sick, the bowels are affected first. Therefore, the pain arises from the back and shoulder, stemming from indecision in thought, which eventually connects to the gallbladder, leading to pain in the chest and side. This is a manifestation of excessive heat from the small intestine attacking the gallbladder, where the offspring invade the mother, indicating a real pathogen. Upon inquiry, it was confirmed that the illness arose from unfulfilled plans. Administer four qian of ginseng and two qian of mutong, decocted into a broth with several doses of Longhui Pill, which resulted in recovery.

Another person presented with a hunched back and twisted legs, with a pulse that was deep, taut, and thin. The Shenwei Powder was given, leading to vomiting and diarrhea; after three doses, the patient recovered.[159p]

　　一男子年五十，形实色黑，背生红肿，及胛骨下痛，其脉浮数而洪紧，食亦呕，正冬月，与麻黄桂枝汤，加酒黄蘗、生附、栝蒌子、甘草节、羌活、青皮、人参、黄芩、半夏、生姜六贴而消。此正内托之法，非精要内托散、乳香、菉豆等药。想此方专为服丹石而发疽者设，不因丹石而发，恐非必用之剂。
　　五八婶年六十岁，背上生疮，脉洪大数，午后恶寒发热，食少，用连翘、黄芪、砂仁各三钱，人参、当归各二钱，陈皮、茯苓各五分，炙甘草、白朮各一钱，以黄芪为君，甘草、归、参为佐，乃实内补虚之中兼托里也。
　　一人年七十，患背疽，径尺余，杂与五香、十宣数十贴，脓血腥秽，呕逆不食者，旬余。病人自去吃内托散，膈中不安，且素有淋病三十年，今所苦者，淋之痛与呕吐不得睡而已。急以参、芪、归、朮煮膏，以牛膝汤入竹沥饮之，三日后，尽药一斤半，淋止思食；七日后，尽药四斤，脓自涌出而得睡；又兼旬而安。[160p]

A man aged fifty, with a dark complexion, has red swelling on his back and pain below his scapula. His pulse is floating, rapid, and tight. He also experiences vomiting after eating. It is mid-winter. A prescription of Ma Huang and Gui Zhi Decoction, along with wine, Huangbo, Shengfu, Gualouzi, Gan Caojie, Qianghuo, Qingpi, Ren Shen, Huangqin, Ban Xia, and Sheng Jiang is given, with six applications and gradual resolution of symptoms. This is a proper internal purging method, not the crucial Internal Purging Powder or medicines like Boswellia and Dolichos. It seems this formula is specifically for those who develop sores from ingesting dan stone; if not due to dan stones, it may not be an essential remedy.

A woman, aged sixty, has sores on her back. Her pulse is large and rapid, and she experiences chills and fever in the afternoon, with decreased appetite. She takes Lianqiao, Huangqi, and Sharen, three qian each; Ren Shen and Danggui, two qian each; Chenpi and Fuling, five fen each; Zhi Gan Cao and Baizhu, one qian each. With Huangqi as the chief ingredient and Gan Cao, Danggui, and Ren Shen as assistants, the formula is aimed at genuinely nourishing the internal void while simultaneously purging.

A seventy-year-old man suffers from back sores larger than a foot. He has received several applications of Wuxiang and Shixuan, mixed with pus and bloody filth, experiencing vomiting and inability to eat for over ten days. The patient took Internal Purging Powder on his own but felt discomfort in the chest, having suffered from a urinary condition for thirty years. Now he endures pain from the urination issue, and vomiting keeps him from sleeping. He urgently receives a decoction of Ren Shen, Huangqi, Danggui, and Baizhu, prepared in Niuxi soup, and mixed with bamboo juice for drinking. After three days of taking one and a half jin of the medicine, the urination pain stops, and appetite returns. After seven days, he has consumed four jin of the medicine, pus starts to flow out, and he finally gains peace at night. After another ten days, he maintains his stability.[160p]

　　一男子年六十余，性好酒肉，背疽见脓，呕逆发热，盖其得内托十宣多矣。医以呕逆，于嘉禾散中，加丁香以温胃行气，时七月大热，脉洪数有力，予因谓此脉证在溃疡尤为忌，然形气实，只宜人参膏和竹沥饮之，尽药十五斤，竹百余竿而安。予曰：此病幸安也。不薄味，必再作。仍厚味自若。夏月醉后，坐水池中，又年余，左胁旁生一软块如饼，二年后，软块为疽。本人见脓血淋漓，而脉洪数有力，又呕逆食少，遂自以人参膏入竹沥饮之，又百余竿而安。今八十岁，强健如旧。此病以老年血气弱，两服人参、竹沥而皆愈。若与内托十宣散，恐未能若是之安全也。[161p]

A man over sixty years old, who had a strong liking for wine and meat, developed an ulcer with pus and experienced vomiting and fever, likely due to the excessive consumption of inner tonics. The physician, addressing the vomiting, added cloves to the Jiahe powder to warm the stomach and promote the flow of qi. It was the hot month of July, and his pulse was strong and rapid. I noted that this pulse condition was particularly concerning in cases of ulceration; however, his vital energy was robust, so I recommended a mixture of ginseng paste and bamboo juice, consuming a total of fifteen pounds of medicine and over a hundred stalks of bamboo, which achieved stability. I said, “This illness is fortunately manageable. If he does not limit his diet, it will surely recur.” Still, he continued to eat richly. After a drunken episode in a water pool during summer, a year later, a soft lump the size of a cake appeared on his left side, which developed into an ulcer two years later. When I saw the pus and blood, his pulse was still strong and rapid, and he had vomiting with poor appetite. He decided to take the ginseng paste with bamboo juice again, consuming another hundred stalks, which brought him back to stability. Now at eighty years of age, he is as strong as before. This illness was due to the weakened blood and qi of old age; with just two doses of ginseng and bamboo juice, he recovered. If he had taken the inner tonics instead, I fear he would not have been as safe.[161p]

　　予治章兄背疽经尺，家贫待死而已。视疮穴黑深，似有近内之意，急作参芪归朮膏饮三日，略以艾芎汤洗，气息奄奄，不可支持，幸其身不发热，而可进饮食，每日作馄饨大碗与之。尽药膏五斤，馄饨多肉者三十碗，疮口渐合，以其因肉与馄饨助气之有益也。
　　《卫生宝鉴》曰：戊午冬，予从军住扎于成武县，有贾仓使父，年逾六旬，冬至后数日疽发于背，五七日肿势约七寸许，不任其痛。疡医曰：视之脓已成，可开发矣。公惧不从。逾三日，医曰：不开恐变生矣。遂以燔针开之，脓泄痛减。以开迟之故，迨二日变证果生，觉重如负石，热如焫火，痛楚倍常，六脉沉数，按之有力，此膏粱积热之变也。邪气酷热，固宜以寒药治之。时月严凝，复有用寒远寒之戒，乃思《内经》云，有假者反之，虽违其时以从其证可也。与疡医议，急作清凉饮子，加黄连秤一两五钱作一服服之，利下两行，痛减七分。翌日，复进前药，其证悉除。后月余平复。[162p]

I treated my older brother's back sore, which had developed into a severe condition, and we were too poor to afford anything but to await death. The wound appeared dark and deep, suggesting an internal issue. Urgently, I prepared a decoction of ginseng, astragalus, and rhizoma atractylodis for three days, and washed it with a mugwort and angelica decoction. He was in a frail state, almost unable to support himself, but fortunately, he did not have a fever and could still consume food. Each day, I gave him a large bowl of dumplings. After using five jin of the medicinal salve and providing thirty bowls of meaty dumplings, the wound gradually healed, likely due to the nourishing properties of the meat and dumplings.

The "Treasured Mirror of Health" states: In the winter of the year Wuy, I was stationed with the army in Chengwu County. There was a father of a merchant, over sixty years old, who developed a sore on his back just days after the winter solstice. Within five to seven days, the swelling reached about seven inches and was unbearable. The sore physician remarked that there was already pus and it could be lanced. The gentleman, fearing the procedure, did not comply. Three days later, the physician warned that not lancing it could lead to further complications. Eventually, he used a cauterizing needle to open the sore, allowing the pus to drain and relieving some pain. Because the opening was delayed, after two days, secondary symptoms arose, making him feel as if he was bearing a heavy stone, and he experienced intense heat and pain, with a rapid pulse. This was a transformation due to the accumulation of heat from rich foods. Given the strong heat of the evil energy, it was advisable to treat it with cooling remedies. The month was harsh and cold, and I had to be cautious about using cold treatments. I recalled the "Inner Canon," which states that if there is a deficiency, one should counter it; while it may be contrary to the season, it could be appropriate to address the symptoms. Consulting with the sore physician, I swiftly prepared a cooling decoction, adding one tael and five qian of yellow lungwort for one dose. This resulted in bowel movements twice, and the pain decreased by seventy percent. The following day, I gave him the previous medicines again, and all symptoms were resolved. Over the course of the next month, he recuperated fully.[162p]

　　《医学纲目》曰：史源母背髀间微痒，视之，有赤半寸许，方有白粒如粟黍，乃急着艾灸，其赤随消，二七壮而止。信宿复觉微痛，视之，有赤下流，长二寸，阔如韭叶，举家皆以前灸为悔。或云，等慈寺尼智全者，前病疮甚大，得灸而愈。奔问之，全云，剧时昏不知，但小师辈言范八奉议守定，灸八百余壮，方苏，约艾一筛尔。亟归白之。见从。[163p]

The "Medical Compendium" states: When the history source mother felt a subtle itch between her back and hip, she looked and saw a red spot about half an inch wide, with white grains resembling millet. She immediately applied moxa treatment, and the redness subsided, stopping after twenty-seven applications. Later, she felt a slight pain again, and upon inspection, found a red area that flowed below, measuring two inches long and as wide as a chive leaf. The whole family regretted not treating it with moxa earlier. Some said that the nun Zhiqian from Dengci Temple had previously suffered from a very large sore, which was cured through moxibustion. When questioned, Zhiqian said that during the worst times, she was faint and unaware, but the junior disciples said that Fan Ba suggested a strict adherence to treatment, performing moxibustion over eight hundred times before she recovered, using about a sieve full of moxa. She quickly returned to report this.[163p]

始以艾作炷，如银杏大，灸其上十数，殊不觉痛；乃截四旁赤，引其炷减四之三，皆觉痛；七壮后觉痒。每一壮烬，则赤随缩入，灸至二十余壮，赤晕收退。病者不惮，遂以艾作团，大灸其上，渐加至鸡黄大，约四十壮方觉痛，视火焦处已寸余。盖灸之迟，而初发处肉已坏，坏肉成顽，直至好肉方痛。四旁知痛，肉未坏也。病者六夜不寐，至是食粥安寝。至晚视之，疮如覆甑，突高三四寸，上有百数小窍，色正黑。突然高者，毒气出外而聚也；百数小窍者，毒未聚而浮攻肌肤也；色正黑者，皮与肉俱坏也。非艾火出其毒于坏肉之裹，则五脏逼矣。[164p]

At first, I made a moxa cone as big as a ginkgo nut and applied ten or so moxas to it, feeling no pain at all. Then I cut it down to four sides, reducing the cone by three-quarters, and I felt the pain. After seven applications, it began to itch. With each successive burning, the red area shrank inwards. After about twenty applications, the red halo receded. The patient felt no fear and thus made larger moxa, gradually increasing it to the size of a chicken's yolk. It took about forty applications before pain was felt, and upon examining the charred area, it had already exceeded an inch in size. This was because the moxa was applied slowly, and by then the flesh at the initial site had already decayed; the dead flesh had become stubborn, causing pain only when healthy flesh was reached. The surrounding area felt pain because the flesh was not yet decayed. The patient had not slept for six nights, but now could eat porridge and sleep soundly. By evening, the sore appeared as if covered by a steaming basket, protruding three or four inches, with countless small openings and a deep black color. The sudden protrusion indicated that the toxic gas was escaping and gathering; the countless small openings suggested that the toxins had not yet fully concentrated and were still attacking the skin; the deep black color revealed that both the skin and the flesh were decayed. If the moxa fire had not expelled the toxins from the decayed flesh, the internal organs would have been pressured.[164p]

　　《薛氏医案》曰：宪副陈鲁山居官勤苦，劳伤元气，背患疽，漫肿，中央色黯，四畔微赤，微痛，脉浮大，按之微细，左寸短而右寸若无，十余日肿未全起。此病元气虚寒，朝用参、芪、姜、桂、归、朮、陈皮、半夏、炙草温补其阳，夕用加减八味丸滋其肝肾，各四剂而腐溃，但脓水清稀，盗汗自汗，内热晡热，脉浮而数；改用八珍汤，复发热而阳夜举，此肾虚火动，仍用加减八味丸料煎服而安。又因怒动肝火，疮出鲜血二盏许，左关弦数，右关弦弱，此肝木侮脾，以致肝不能藏血，脾不能统血，用十全大补兼前药各二剂而血止。再用前药调理而痊。

　　秋官高竹真患背疽，色黯坚硬，重如负石，神思昏愦可畏。其亲廷评郑沙村请同往治。郑云：竹真先任湖广某县时，以某河涉险不便，竹真为整治有功，其民为立生祠。凡渡河者无不祷祭，竹真患此，悉疑立祠致祟。余曰：不然。病因元气虚寒，积毒炽盛所致。遂以杵蒜摊患处，用钱大艾炷灸二十余壮，尚不知；乃摊蒜铺艾灸，亦不知；乃着肉灸，良久方知，再灸方痛。内服参、附大补之剂而起。

　　儒者顾大有年几六旬，仲冬背疽初起，入房，患处黑死五寸许，黯晕尺余，漫肿坚硬，背如负石，发热作渴，小便频数，两耳重听，扬手露体，神思昏愦，脉沉而细，右手为甚，便秘二十七日，计进饮食百余碗，腹内如常，众欲通之，余曰：所喜者此耳。急用大剂六君，加姜、附、肉桂三剂，疮始臖痛。自后空心用前药，午后以六味丸料，加参、芪、归、朮五剂，复用活命饮二剂，针出黑血甚多，瘀脓少许，背即轻软，仍用前药，便亦通利。余适他往四日，神思复昏，疮仍黑陷，脓水淋漓，饮食不进，急以参、芪、归、朮各一两，炮附子五钱，姜、桂各三钱服之，即索饮食，并鸭子二枚。自后日进前药二剂，肉腐脓溃而愈。[168p]

At that time, as it was autumn, we also administered a tonic formula, using Shenmai Powder instead of tea.[172p]

　　一男子背疽不起发，脉浮，按之则濇，此血气俱虚，故不能发。非补剂不愈。
　　太守朱阳山之内，年五十二，四月四日背当心生疽如粟，三日渐大，根盘五寸许，不肿痛，不寒热，脉微而沉。余曰：实则痛，虚则痒。不发不治，溃而不敛亦不治。乃与大补阳气之剂，色白而黯，疮势如故，神疲食减，小便淋濇。乃与大补气血如姜、桂二剂，疮亦不起。十五日，涉怒，呕泻并作，复与大补药一剂，疮仍不起，留前药二剂，昏愦不服。或劝之，始悟，依方连进七剂。十六日，疮起而溃，色红而淡。十九日，与大补二十余剂，后因劳自汗，口干舌强，太阳发际脑顶俱胀，此血气俱虚，肝胆火上炎，用补中益气加山栀、芍药顿愈。但内热少睡，手足不时发热晡热，用逍遥散加山栀，热退；复用归脾汤，疮亦愈。计疮发及敛，凡四十二日，未尝一用攻疮之药。
古今图书集成医部全录卷一百七十九[173p]

A man developed a back sore that didn't erupt, with a floating pulse that felt thin upon pressure. His blood and qi were both deficient, hence it couldn't erupt; thus, he required a strengthening medicine to recover.

In Zhu Yang Mountain, a governor, aged fifty-two, experienced a sore on his back near the heart, resembling millet, which grew larger over three days, with a root approximately five inches in diameter. It did not swell or hurt, nor was there fever or chills, and his pulse was weak and deep. I said: "If it is real, it hurts; if it is empty, it itches. Without eruption or treatment, if it breaks down and does not close, it also needs no treatment." Therefore, I prescribed a strong supplement for yang qi, which was white and dull in color, yet the sore's condition remained the same, with fatigue, reduced appetite, and cloudy urination. I then prescribed several tonics for qi and blood, like ginger and cinnamon, yet the sore still did not erupt.

On the fifteenth day, he became angry and suffered from vomiting and diarrhea simultaneously. I again administered a strong tonic, but the sore remained inactive. I retained the previous two prescriptions, as he was in a daze and couldn't take them. After being advised, he finally understood and took seven doses in succession. On the sixteenth day, the sore erupted, showing red and pale colors. On the nineteenth day, I gave him more than twenty doses of a strong tonic. Later, due to exertion, he sweated, felt dry in the mouth, and had a bloated sensation in the temples and the top of his head; this indicated deficiency in both blood and qi, with the liver and gallbladder fire inflamed upward. I used a formula to nourish the spleen and augment qi, adding gardenia and peony, and he quickly recovered. However, due to internal heat and restless sleep, his hands and feet often felt warm in the afternoons; I prescribed Xiaoyao Powder with added gardenia, which reduced the heat. I also administered Gui Pi Decoction, and the sore healed as well. In total, the sore emerged and closed within forty-two days without ever using any medications to attack the sore.[173p]

背脊门

　　　　医案

　　《薛己医案》曰：江阴举人陈鸣岐寓京，患背疽，用大补之剂而愈。翌日，设席作谢，对谈如常。是晚，得家信，大拂其意，恼怒，发热作渴，食梨子少许。至夜，连泻数次。早，促予视，脉已脱矣，竟至不起。夫梨者利也，疏利下行之物，凡脾胃虚寒产妇金疮者，皆当忌之。
　　留都郑中翰，仲夏患发背，已半月，疮头十余枚，皆如栗许，漫肿坚硬，根大如盘，背重如负石，即隔蒜灸五十余壮，其背顿轻。彼因轻愈，不守禁忌，三日后大作，疮不起发，喜得作痛，用活命饮四剂，势少退；用香砂六君子汤四剂，饮食少进。彼恃知医，自用败毒药二剂，饮食益少，口流涎沫，若不自知，此脾虚之甚也。每用托里药内参、芪各三钱，彼密自拣去大半，后虽用大补药加姜、桂，亦不应；遂以参、芪各一斤，归、朮各半斤，干姜、桂、附各一两，煎膏一罐，三日饮尽，涎顿止，腐顿溃，食顿进；再用托里健脾药，腐肉自脱而愈。[174p]

Back Pain Case Study

The "Xue Ji Medical Case" states: Chen Mingqi, a provincial graduate from Jiangyin, lived in the capital and suffered from back abscesses. He was cured after taking a great tonifying remedy. The next day, he set up a banquet to express gratitude and spoke as usual. That evening, he received a letter from home that greatly upset him, causing anger and thirst; he ate a little pear. By night, he experienced multiple bouts of diarrhea. In the morning, he urged me to examine him, but his pulse had already faded, and he ultimately became unable to rise. Pears are diuretic; they promote the movement of fluids downward. Those with a weak, cold spleen and stomach or postpartum women should avoid them.

In the capital, Zheng Zhonghan suffered from back pain for half a month. He had over ten sores on his back, sized like chestnuts, swollen and hard, with roots as large as plates. His back felt heavy as if carrying stones. He underwent fifty cauterizations with garlic, after which his back felt lighter. However, feeling improved, he disregarded restrictions and after three days, it worsened significantly; the sores flared up again, causing pain. He took four doses of a life-saving remedy, with slight improvement; then, four doses of Xiangsha Liu Junzi Decoction, but his food intake decreased. He relied on his medical knowledge and took two doses of a toxin-clearing medicine, which further reduced his appetite, leading to excessive salivation, as if he were unaware; this was a sign of severe spleen deficiency. He used to take three qian each of Tori medicine, angelica, and astragalus but secretly removed most of them. Later, even after taking a strong tonic with ginger and cassia, it was still ineffective. Thus, he took one pound each of ginseng and astragalus, half a pound each of licorice and atractylodes, and one tael each of dried ginger, cassia, and prepared aconite to brew a paste in a jar, consuming it over three days. The salivation suddenly stopped, the corruption and sores healed, and his appetite returned. He used Tori medicine again for strengthening the spleen, and the necrotic tissue fell off, leading to full recovery.[174p]

　　南都聘士叶公玉表兄聂姓者，患发背，时六月，腐肉已去，疮口尺许，色赤而焮，发热不食，欲呕不呕，服十宣散等药，自为不起。叶请余决之。其脉轻诊则浮而数，重诊则弱而濇，此溃后之正脉。然疮口开张，血气虚也；欲呕而不呕，脾胃虚也；色赤焮肿，虚火之象也。尚可治。遂与十全大补汤，加酒炒黄蘗、知母、五味、麦门及饮童便，饮食顿进，肌肉顿生。服至八剂，疮口收如粟许。又惑于人言，又服消毒药二剂，以为消余毒，反发热昏愦；急进前药，又二十余州乃愈。后两目因作善事，一昼夜不睡，致劳发热，似睡不睡，与前药二剂，愈加发热，饮食不进，惟饮热汤。后以前药加附子一钱，二剂复愈。[175p]

In the southern capital, a scholar named Ye Gong had a cousin with the surname Nie who suffered from a back issue. It was June, and the rotten flesh had already been removed, leaving a wound about an inch wide, red and inflamed. He had a fever, was unable to eat, and felt nauseous but couldn’t vomit. After taking ten Xuan San and other medications, he still couldn’t recover. Ye asked me to diagnose him.

Upon light examination of his pulse, it felt floating and rapid; upon deeper examination, it was weak and thin—signs of proper pulse after a rupture. However, the wound was open, indicating a deficiency of blood and qi; the nausea without vomiting indicated a weak spleen and stomach; the red and inflamed appearance showed signs of virtual fire. Nevertheless, he was still treatable.

I prescribed Shen Qi Da Bu Tang, adding wine-fried Huang Bo, Zhi Mu, Wu Wei, Mai Men Dong, and a drink of children's urine. His appetite increased steadily, and muscles began to grow. After taking eight doses, the wound shrank to the size of a grain. However, influenced by others' words, he took two doses of poison-reducing medicine, thinking it would eliminate residual toxins, but instead, his fever and delirium worsened; urgently, I administered the previous medicine again, and after more than twenty days, he finally recovered.

Later, he engaged in good deeds, staying awake for a whole day and night, which led to exhaustion and fever. He felt as if he was sleeping but was not; I then gave him two doses of the previous medication, which increased his fever and he could only drink hot soup. Ultimately, I added one qian of Fu Zi to the previous formula, and after two more doses, he recovered again.[175p]

　　高秋官贞甫孟秋发背，色黯而硬，不痛不起，脉沉而细，四肢逆冷，急用大艾隔蒜灸三十余壮，不痛；遂用艾如粟大者七壮，着肉灸，始知痛。与六君子汤二剂，每剂入附子二钱，不应；后剂又加肉桂二钱，始应。
　　石武选廉伯患发背，内服防风通圣散，外敷凉药，汗出不止，饮食不进，且不寐，疮盈尺，色黯而坚硬，按之不痛，气息奄奄，此阳气已脱，脉息如无，急隔蒜灸一时许，背顿轻，四围高不知痛，中央肉六寸许一块，已死。服香砂六君子汤一剂，翌日复灸一次，痛处死血得解，令砭去。予归后，为他医所惑，未砭，其血复凝，又傅辛温活血药。翌日，依予言砭之，出黑血二盏许。彼云：背强顿去。以前药加姜、桂服一锺，即鼾睡，觉来肢体少健，但饮食仍不思，吞酸仍有，疮仍不痛。彼以为阴毒乃如此。予曰：此气血虚极，寒邪淫于内，无阳营于患处，故肌肉死也，非阴毒。[176p]

In the late autumn, Guan Zhenfu suffered from a back boil, which was dark and hard, causing no pain when touched. The pulse was deep and thin, and the limbs were cold. Urgently, he applied moxa with garlic, using over thirty sticks, but it did not hurt; he then used moxa about the size of millet in seven doses, applied directly to the flesh, and only then did he feel pain. He was given Six Gentlemen Decoction in two doses, with two qian of aconite in each dose, but there was no response; the next dose had an additional two qian of cinnamon, and then he began to respond.

Shi Wuxuan Lianbo was troubled by a back boil. He took internal medicine, a wind-dispersing formula, and applied cooling herbs externally. He sweated profusely without cessation, could not eat, did not sleep, and had a wound of a foot long that was dark and hard. Pressing it did not elicit pain, and his breath was faint; this indicated a loss of yang. The pulse was nearly nonexistent. He urgently applied garlic moxa for about one period, and the back felt lighter, with surrounding areas feeling no pain. There was an area of the back about six inches wide that had already died. He took a dose of fragrant sand Six Gentlemen Decoction, and the next day moxibustion was applied again. The dead blood in the painful area was released, prompting a need for needling. After my return, he was misled by another doctor and did not undergo needling; his blood coagulated again, leading to the application of a warming blood-activating medicine. The next day, guided by my advice, he underwent needling and expelled about two cups of black blood. They claimed that the pain in the back suddenly disappeared. Previously, he was given medicinals with ginger and cinnamon, which helped him sleep soundly. Upon awakening, his limbs felt slightly stronger, but he still lacked appetite, experienced sourness upon swallowing, and the wound was still painless. They believed this to be due to yin toxicity. I clarified that this was an extreme deficiency of qi and blood, with cold evil rampant within, and no yang nourishment present in the affected area, causing the flesh to die; it was not due to yin toxicity.[176p]

若阳气一回，胃气即苏，死肉即溃，可保无虑矣。以前药二剂，各加姜、桂、附子二钱服之，略进米饮，精神复旧，患处竟热，脉略有力，此阳气略回矣。是日，他医谓疮疡属火证，况今暑令，乃敷芙蓉根等凉药，即进粥二碗，服消毒药，死肉即溃。予意芙蓉乃寒凉之药，与脾胃何益？饮食即时而进？消毒乃辛散之剂，与阳气何补？死肉即时而溃？此盖前桂、附之功至，而脾胃之气复，故饮食进，阳气旺，故死肉腐也。苟虚寒人若内无辛热回阳之药，辄用寒凉攻毒之剂，岂可得生耶？若以为火令属阳之证，内有热而施辛温补益之剂，岂不致死而反生耶？殊不知此乃舍时从证之治法也。[177p]

Once yang energy returns, the stomach qi will revive, the dead flesh will decay, and one can be free from worries. With the previous two doses of medicine, each supplemented with two qian of ginger, cinnamon, and fuzi, and slightly taken with rice soup, the spirit returns to normal, the affected area remains hot, and the pulse is slightly stronger; thus, yang energy has partially returned. On this day, another physician claimed that the abscess was a fire condition, and given the current heat of summer, applied cool medicines like hibiscus root, and administered two bowls of porridge, along with detoxifying medication, leading to the decay of dead flesh. I believe hibiscus is a cold and cool medicine, which offers no benefit to the spleen and stomach. Should one eat immediately? The detoxifying medicine is an astringent and dispersive agent; how does it nourish yang energy? The dead flesh decays immediately? This is due to the previous effects of cinnamon and fuzi, which restored the stomach qi, thus allowing food intake, with strong yang energy leading to the decay of dead flesh. If a person with deficient cold does not have warming spices to revive yang and instead uses cold, cooling, toxic-clearing agents, can they possibly survive? If they think fire pertains to the yang condition and, sensing internal heat, apply warming and replenishing agents, would this not lead to death rather than revival? They do not realize this is a treatment method that disregards timing in favor of pathological condition.[177p]

　　一男子发背，脓始溃，肿未消，已十七日，脉微而静。予曰：脓毒未尽，脉先弱，此元气虚，宜补之，否则后必生变。彼惑于人言，乃服败毒药，腐肉虽溃，疮口不完。忽腹中似痛，后去白垢，肛门里急，复求治。予曰：此里虚然也。非痢非毒，当温补脾胃为善。因诸疡医皆以为毒未尽，仍服败毒药而死。[178p]

A man had a back abscess that began to suppurate; the swelling had not subsided for seventeen days, and his pulse was weak and quiet. I said: "The pus and poison are not expelled, and the pulse is weak first; this is a sign of deficient vital energy. It should be replenished, otherwise, there will surely be complications later." He was confused by others' words and took anti-toxic medicine. Although the necrotic flesh suppurated, the wound did not heal. Suddenly, he felt a pain in his abdomen, then passed white matter, and experienced urgency at the anus, prompting him to seek treatment again. I said: "This is an internal deficiency. It is neither dysentery nor toxicity; it would be wise to warm and supplement the spleen and stomach." Consequently, all the ulcer doctors believed the poison was not yet resolved and continued administering the anti-toxic medicine until he died.[178p]

　　贺少参朝仪背胛患疽，大如豆粒，根畔木闷不肿，肉色如常。予曰：此气虚毒甚之证，虽用补剂，亦不能收敛。先用活命饮二剂，背强少和；又二剂，疽少赤；用大补剂，疮出黑血杯许，继有鲜血，微有清脓。予曰，可见气血虚极矣。他医以为属气血有余之证，密用攻毒药一锺，即呕逆腹内阴冷而死。
　　少司寇周玉岩背患疽在胛，已四日，疮头如粟，重如负石，坚硬不起，自以为小恙，外敷凉药，内服连翘消毒散，去后四次，形体倦怠，自汗盗汗，口干不寐，请予治。予曰：疮不宜硬，色不宜黯。公曰：初起时赤而软，自用前二药以致如此。予曰：凡疮外如麻，内如瓜，毒结于内，非小患耳。脉轻诊似数，按之则微，未溃脉先弱，主后难敛。[179p]

He Shaocan had a sore on his back about the size of a bean, with no swelling around the root, and the flesh was of normal color. I said: This is a sign of severe deficiency and toxicity. Even if tonics are used, they will not be effective in consolidating it. First, I administered two doses of the Vitality Decoction, which slightly strengthened the back; after two more doses, the sore became slightly red. When I used a significant tonic, the sore produced black blood resembling wine, followed by fresh blood and a little clear pus. I said: It can be seen that the deficiency of Qi and blood is extremely severe. Other doctors believed it was a sign of excess Qi and blood, so they secretly administered a dose of detoxifying medicine, which resulted in vomiting, internal coldness, and ultimately death.

Zhou Yuyan, a minor official, had a sore on his back for four days. The sore's head was like millet, heavy as carrying a stone, hard and raised. He thought it was a minor ailment, applying cool medicines externally and taking a detoxifying powder internally. After four doses, he felt fatigued, had spontaneous sweating and night sweats, dry mouth, and insomnia, and requested me to treat him. I said: A sore should not be hard, nor should its color be dark. He replied: Initially, it was red and soft, but I used the previous two medicines, leading to this condition. I said: In cases of sores, they should feel like hemp externally and like melon internally; toxicity is accumulating inside, which is not a minor issue. The pulse was lightly diagnosed and seemed frequent; upon palpation, it was weak. Before it ruptured, the pulse weakened first, making it difficult to treat afterwards.[179p]

因与乡雅不能辞，遂隔蒜灸二十余壮，乃知痛；又十余壮，背觉少和；服六君子汤加黄芪、藿香、当归、麻黄根、浮麦二剂，渴止汗少敛，疮色仍黯坚硬；又服辛温活血之药，疮始起，渴止汗敛，所结死血得散。良久，汗复出，口复干。又服数剂，外皮虽溃，清脓尚未溃通，而内脓欲走别处，彼用药围之。予曰：里虚而脓不能溃于外，围药逼毒入内。至十二日，脉浮，按之如无，再用前药二剂，加姜、桂服之即安寐。又二日，脉忽脱，再与前药，加附子七分，服二剂。公曰：背今日始属吾也。形体亦健，颇有生意。因予先日有言难以收敛，更医治。乃杂用清热解毒，及敷凉药，遂致里虚，元气下陷，去后如痢，用治痢消毒药而死。[180p]

Due to an inability to refuse the local customs, I endured more than twenty severe pangs before realizing the pain. After ten more pangs, my back began to feel somewhat relaxed. I took six gentlemen's decoction added with Astragalus, patchouli, angelica, Ephedra root, and floating wheat in two doses; my thirst stopped, and my sweating diminished, but the sores remained dark, hard, and unsightly. I then took warming, blood-moving medicines, and the sores began to appear; my thirst ceased, and sweating reduced, allowing the stagnant blood to disperse. After a long while, I began to sweat again, and my mouth became dry once more. After taking several doses, although the outer skin broke, the clear pus had not yet drained, and the internal pus seemed to seek another outlet; they applied medicine to surround it. I said: If the interior is deficient and the pus cannot break outwards, surrounding medicine forces the poison inward. By the twelfth day, the pulse was floating, and pressing it felt non-existent. I used the previous medicines twice more, adding ginger and cassia, which brought immediate comfort and sleep. After two more days, the pulse suddenly became weak. I administered the previous medicines again, adding seven parts of aconite, and gave two doses. The gentleman said: "Now my back has begun to return to me." His body also felt strong, showing signs of life. However, since I mentioned earlier that it would be difficult to consolidate his condition, more treatment was required. I thus combined medications to clear heat and detoxify, along with cooling medicines, which ultimately led to internal deficiency and a decline in vital energy, resulting in a lingering condition resembling dysentery, treated with dysentery detoxifying medicines, and he died.[180p]

　　姜举人发背，十日正，腐溃作渴，喜热汤饮，此中气虚，不能生津液而口干，宜预补之，否则不能收敛。后疮口果不收。犹以毒为未尽，用败毒药两剂，疮口不完，清利腹痛，又服清凉之剂而死。
　　王序班发背，元气虚弱，用托里药而始起，用大补药而始溃。彼惑他议，敷凉药，致腹内不和，里急后重，去后如痢，大孔作痛。予曰：此里虚，非痢。仍用败毒治痢药而死。凡疮大溃之后，大便后有白脓，或止便白脓，或泻痢，此肠胃气虚也；里急后重，血虚也。若果痢，亦不可用清凉败毒之药。况仲景先生云：治痢不止者当温之；下痢腹痛急，当救里，可与理中四逆附子辈。大孔痛，当温之。东垣先生治痢元气陷下者，未尝不用温补之药。然疮脓溃既久，血气既弱，不用温补，吾不得而知也。[181p]

Jiang, a juren, developed a back sore; ten days later it was in a critical state, rotten and causing thirst, preferring hot soup to drink. This indicated a deficiency of middle qi, unable to generate bodily fluids, leading to dryness of the mouth. It was advisable to supplement beforehand; otherwise, healing could not be achieved. Later, the sore did not heal. He suspected the poison had not yet been cleared and used two doses of detoxifying medicine, yet the sore did not heal completely. Facing abdominal pain, he took a cooling remedy and died.

Wang, having a back sore, was weak in primal qi. He started with medication to promote the interior but began to ulcerate after taking strong tonics. Misled by others, he applied cooling medicines, causing disharmony in the abdomen, urgent distress in the interior, and painful loose stools resembling dysentery. I stated: this is a case of internal deficiency, not dysentery. Yet he still used detoxifying medicine for dysentery and died. After a great ulceration, having white pus in the stool, whether it stopped or led to dysentery, indicates a deficiency of stomach and intestines; urgent distress and heaviness indicate blood deficiency. If it were truly dysentery, cooling detoxifying medicines should not be used. Furthermore, Master Zhongjing states: for dysentery that does not resolve, one must warm it; in cases of acute abdominal pain with dysentery, one should rescue the interior, possibly using warming tonics such as Li Zhong Wan with Fu Zi. For significant pain, one should warm. Master Dongyuan treated dysentery with sinking primal qi and did not neglect to use warming tonics. However, if the pus from the ulcer has been oozing for a long time and the qi and blood are weakened, whether to avoid warming tonics is beyond my knowledge.[181p]

　　一男子年四十余岁，发背未溃，即作渴，脉数肿高，色紫面赤，小便如膏，予以加减八味丸料加酒炒知母、黄蘗为丸，每日空心并食前以童便送下百丸，用八珍汤加五味子、麦门冬、黄芪酒炒、知母、赤小豆食远煎服，逐日又以童便代茶饮之，渴止疮溃而愈。吾治得生者此人耳。
　　留都机房纪姓者，背疮，胃气虚，用温补药而饮食进，大补药而疮腐愈。后患腿疮，予用养血化痰之剂，少止。彼嫌功缓，他医以为湿热。服麻黄左经汤一剂，汗出不止。予曰：必发痉而死。已而果然。
　　一男子患背疮，痛甚，服消毒药愈炽，予为隔蒜灸之而止，与仙方活命饮二剂顿退，更与托里药溃之而愈。
　　一男子背疮已四日，疮头如黍，焮痛背重，脉沉实，与黄连内疏汤二剂少退，更与仙方活命饮二剂而消。
　　一男子背疮，焮肿作痛，脉浮数，与内托复煎散二剂少退，与仙方活命饮四剂痛止而溃，再与托里药而愈。[182p]

A man over forty years old had back sores without pus, felt very thirsty, his pulse was rapid and his body swollen, his complexion was purple and face red, and his urine was like paste. In the capital, a man named Ji had back sores and weak stomach energy. I used warming and tonifying medicines and increased his food intake. After using strong tonics, the sores began to decay. A man with back sores in severe pain took detoxifying medicines and became even more inflamed. I treated him with garlic moxibustion to stop the pain and provided two doses of the Xianfang Huoming Decoction, which reduced the symptoms. I then prescribed an expelling medicine, and he recovered.

A man had back sores for four days; the sore's top was like millet, and he experienced burning pain with a heavy back. His pulse was deep and solid. After taking two doses of Huanglian Neishou Decoction, there was slight improvement, and then I provided two doses of the Xianfang Huoming Decoction, which reduced the symptoms.

　　一妇人背疮发热，烦躁饮冷，与黄连解毒汤少愈，更与托里消毒散始溃，与托里药而敛。
　　一男人背疮毒势炽甚，痛不可忍，诸药不应。以仙方活命饮二剂，诸证悉退；又二剂而溃；以金银花散六剂而愈。
　　一妇人背疮，肿痛发热，讝语脉大，用清心汤一剂而安，以金银花、甘草、天花粉、当归、栝蒌、黄芪数剂渐溃，更以托里药而愈。
　　一男子背疮，腐肉渐脱，而脓微清，饮食无味，以十宣散去白芷、防风，加茯苓、白朮、陈皮，月余而敛。
　　一男子背疮已愈，惟一口不敛，诊之脉浮而濇，以十全大补汤治之而愈。
　　一男子背疮将愈，但肌肉生迟，诊之脾胃俱虚，以六君子汤加芎、归、五味子、黄芪治之而愈。
　　一男子背疮已愈，惟一眼番出努肉如菌，三月不愈，乃伤风寒也，以生猪脂调藜芦末涂之，即愈。亦有努出三寸许者，尤宜用此药也。乌梅涂之亦效。若势缓，硫黄亦可。[183p]
