　　一男子背患毒，臖痛饮冷，发热多汗，便秘谵语，以破棺丹二丸而宁；以金银花散四剂脓成，开之；更用托里药而愈。
　　一妇背疮脓成，胀痛不安，针之，投托里消毒药即愈。大抵发背之证，虽发热疼痛，形势高大，烦渴不宁，脉若有力，饮食颇进，可保无虞。其脓一溃，诸证悉退。多有因脓不得外泄以致疼痛，若用败毒寒药攻之，反致误事。若有脓，急针之，脓一出，苦楚即止。脓未成而热毒作痛者，用解毒之药。亦有腐溃尺余者，若无恶证，投以大补之剂，肉最易生，亦无所妨。惟忌肿不高，色不赤，不臖痛，脉无力，不饮食，肿不溃，腐不烂，脓水清，或多而不止，肌肉不生，属元气虚也，皆难治，宜峻补之。其或脓血既泄，肿痛尤甚，脓水败臭，烦躁时嗽，腹痛渴甚，泻利无度，小便如淋，乃恶证也，皆不治。[184p]

A man suffered from a back ailment with toxicity, experiencing aching pain, chills, fever, excessive sweating, constipation, and delirium. He took two pills of Po Guan Dan and found relief; later, he was treated with four doses of honeysuckle powder, which cleared the pus, and further healed with detoxifying medicine.

A woman had a back sore with formed pus, causing bloating and discomfort. After being needled, she took detoxifying medicine and was cured. Generally, in cases of back ailments, although there may be fever and pain, the condition appears serious yet manageable if thirst is present and the pulse is strong. If eating well, there should be no significant issues. Once the pus is released, all symptoms will recede.

Often, pain arises when pus cannot escape; using cold medicines to attack it could worsen the situation. If pus is present, it should be needled promptly; once it is released, the pain will cease. If heat and toxins cause pain before the pus forms, detoxifying medicine should be used. There may also be instances of decay extending over a foot; if there are no severe symptoms, tonics will promote healing without causing harm.

However, caution is necessary if the swelling is low, not red, not causing pain, the pulse is weak, there is no desire to eat, swelling has not burst, decay is not present, pus is clear and excessive but not stopping, and muscle growth is absent—this indicates deficiency of vital energy and is difficult to treat; robust tonics are advisable. In cases where pus and blood have already been expelled, the swelling and pain may intensify, with foul-smelling pus, restlessness, cough, severe abdominal pain and thirst, excessive diarrhea, and painful urination—these are signs of severe illness and should not be treated.[184p]

　　一弱妇背疮，外皮虽腐，内脓不溃，胀痛，烦热不安。予谓宜急开之，脓一出，毒即解，痛即止，诸证自退。待其自溃，不惟疼痛，溃烂愈深。彼不从，待将旬日，脓尚未出，人已痛疲矣。虽针之，终不能收敛，竟至不起。
　　一男子背疮，溃而瘀肉不腐，予欲取之，更以峻补之。
　　一妇素弱，背疮未成脓，大痛发热。予谓须隔蒜灸以拔其毒，令自消。皆不从，俱致不救。常治，不问日期阴阳，肿痛，或不痛，或痛甚，但不溃者，即与灸之，随手取效。势未定者，先用箍药围之，若用乌金膏或援生膏点患处数点尤奸。若头痛拘急，乃表证，先服人参败毒散一二剂。如臖痛发热脉数者，用金银花散，或槐花酒、神效托里散。如疼痛肿硬脉实者，以清凉饮、仙方活命饮、苦参丸。肿硬木闷，疼痛发热，烦躁饮冷，便秘脉沉实者，内疏黄连汤，或清凉饮。大便已利，欲其作脓，用仙方活命饮、托里散、蜡矾丸，外用神异膏。[185p]

A weak woman has a sore on her back; although the outer skin is rotten, the inner pus has not burst forth, causing swelling and pain, along with restlessness and fever. I suggested that it should be urgently opened; once the pus comes out, the poison would be resolved, the pain would stop, and all symptoms would recede. However, she did not follow this advice, waiting for several days while the pus remained unyielding, and she became more painful and exhausted. Even though I applied acupuncture, it ultimately could not bring relief, leading to her condition becoming critical.

A man also has a sore on his back; it’s ulcerated, but the flesh is not rotting. I wanted to excise it and apply strong remedies.

A woman, who is generally weak, has a sore on her back that has not yet formed pus, with severe pain and fever. I believed she needed garlic moxibustion to draw out the poison and let it resolve on its own. Again, she did not follow this advice, and both her conditions became dire.

For cases I regularly treat, regardless of the lunar calendar, swelling and pain, whether mild or severe, but not ulcerated, I would apply moxibustion and observe the effects accordingly. For conditions that are not yet established, I first use wrapping medicine. Applying Wu Jin ointment or Yuan Sheng ointment at the affected area once or twice is quite effective. In cases of headache and tightness, indicating an external symptom, I first administer one to two doses of Ren Shen Bai Du San. If pain and fever are present with a rapid pulse, I use Jin Yin Hua San or Huai Hua wine, or the effective Tuo Li San. For pain with swelling and a hard pulse, I utilize Qing Liang Yin, Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin, or Ku Shen Wan. If there is hard swelling and fullness, with pain, fever, irritability, and cold drinks causing constipation with a deep solid pulse, I administer Nei Shu Huang Lian Tang or Qing Liang Yin. If bowel movements have been regulated and I wish for it to form pus, I use Xian Fang Huo Ming Yin, Tuo Li San, or La Fan Wan, along with the external application of Shen Yi Ointment.[185p]

如饮食少思，或不甘美，用六君子汤加藿香，连进三五剂；更用雄黄解毒散洗患处，每日用乌金膏涂疮口处，俟有疮口，即用纸作捻，蘸乌金膏纴入疮内。若有脓为脂膜间隔不出，或作胀痛者，宜用针引之，腐肉堵塞者去之。若瘀肉腐动，用猪蹄汤洗。如脓稠或痛，饮食如常，瘀肉自腐，用消毒与托里药相兼服之，仍用前二膏涂贴。若腐肉已离好肉，宜速去之。如脓不稠不稀微有疼痛，饮食不甘，瘀肉腐迟，更用桑柴灸之，亦用托里药。若瘀肉不腐，或脓清稀不臖痛者，急服大补之剂，亦用桑木灸之，以补接阳气，解散郁毒。常观患疽稍重，未成脓者，不用蒜灸之法，及脓熟不开，或待腐肉自去，多致不救。大抵气血壮实，或毒少轻者，可假药力，或自腐溃。怯弱之人，热毒中隔，内外不通，不行针灸，药无全功矣。然此证若脓已成，宜急开之。否则重者溃通脏腑，腐烂筋骨；轻者延溃良肉，难于收功，因而不敛多矣。[186p]

If there is lack of appetite or unwillingness to eat due to a poor diet, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with Huoxiang, taking three to five doses in succession. Additionally, apply the Xionghuang Jiedu Powder to cleanse the affected area. Daily, use Wujin Ointment to apply on the sore. When a sore develops, take a paper twist, dip it in Wujin Ointment, and insert it into the sore. If there is pus trapped beneath a fatty film that cannot be expelled, or if there is swelling and pain, it is advisable to draw it out with a needle; if there are necrotic tissues obstructing, remove them. If the necrotic tissue is loose and decaying, wash it with pig's trotter soup. If the pus is thick or painful, and the diet is normal or if necrotic tissue is decaying slowly, take a combination of disinfectants and medications to promote the discharge of pus, while continuing to apply the previous ointment. If the necrotic tissue has separated from healthy tissue, it should be removed promptly. If the pus is neither thick nor thin and there is slight pain, with no appetite and slow decay of necrotic tissue, further moxa with mulberry wood should be done, along with medications to promote pus discharge. If the necrotic tissue is not decomposing, or if the pus is thin and clear with little pain, urgently take a potent tonic and also use mulberry wood moxibustion to invigorate and dispel stagnant toxins. Observe that when the ulcers are slightly serious but not yet purulent, avoid the use of garlic moxibustion; if the pus is not mature and is left to decay on its own, it often leads to dire consequences. Generally, those with strong qi and blood or mild toxicity may rely on herbal efficacy or natural decomposition. However, weak individuals with heat toxins internally obstructed will not benefit from acupuncture, leading to incomplete results. Yet, if there is already pus formed, it must be opened urgently. Otherwise, in severe cases, it will lead to perforation of internal organs and decay of tendons and bones; in milder cases, it will prolong the decay of healthy flesh, making recovery difficult.[186p]

　　一妇人背疮，半月余尚不发起，不作脓，痛甚脉弱，隔蒜灸二十余壮而止。更服托里药渐溃，脓清而瘀肉不腐，以大补药及桑柴灸之，渐腐取之而寻愈。常治一日至四五日未成脓而痛者，灸至不痛，不痛者灸至痛。若灸而不痛或麻木者，明灸之，毒气自然随火而散。肿硬不作脓，臖痛或不痛或微痛，或疮头如黍者，灸之尤效。亦有数日色尚微赤，肿尚不起，痛不甚，脓不作者，尤宜多灸，勿拘日期，更服甘温托里药，切忌寒凉之剂。或瘀血不腐，亦用桑木灸之。若脉数发热而痛者，发于阳也，可治。脉不数不发痛者，发于阴也，难治。不痛最恶，不可视为常疾。此证不可不痛，不可大痛。烦闷者不治。大抵发背脑疽大疔悬痈脱疽脚发之类，皆由膏粱厚味，尽力房劳，七情六欲，或丹石补药，精虚气弱所致，非独因荣卫凝滞而生也。必灸之以拔其毒，更辨其因，及察邪在脏腑之异，虚实之殊而治之，庶无悞也。[187p]

A woman had a back sore that did not erupt for over half a month; it did not produce pus, was very painful, and her pulse was weak. After applying moxibustion with garlic slices over twenty times, it stopped. She then took a resolving medicine, and the sore gradually softened, producing clear pus without the flesh decaying. With a combination of strong tonics and moxibustion from mulberry wood, the necrotic tissue was gradually dealt with, leading to recovery.

For those whose sores have not formed pus after one to five days and are painful, apply moxibustion until the pain subsides; if they are already painless, apply moxibustion until they ache. If there is no pain or just numbness, conduct moxibustion brightly to disperse any toxic energies.

If swelling is firm without pus, and there is slight pain or none at all, especially when the sore resembles millet, moxibustion is particularly effective. If after several days the color is only slightly red and there is no swelling or significant pain, it is advisable to apply more moxibustion without being restricted by the time frame, while also taking sweet and warming resolving medicines, and strictly avoiding cold and cooling substances. If there is stagnant blood that does not decay, apply moxibustion with mulberry wood as well.

If the pulse is rapid and hot with pain, it arises from yang, and can be treated. If the pulse is not rapid and has no pain, it arises from yin, and is difficult to treat. The absence of pain is particularly concerning and should not be viewed as an ordinary illness. This condition should not be entirely painless, nor should it be extremely painful. Those feeling troubled should not be treated.

In general, abscesses on the back, brain boils, severe swellings, detached sores, and foot problems are all caused by rich and heavy foods, excessive physical exertion, emotional disturbances, or the use of medicinals and essence-replenishing tonics, leading to deficiency of essence and weakness of qi. They do not arise solely from stagnation in the nourishing and protective systems. It is essential to apply moxibustion to draw out the poison, further identify the causes, and investigate the location of the pathogen within the organs to determine treatment based on deficiency and excess, ensuring there are no missteps.[187p]

　　一男子背疮初生如粟，闷痛烦渴便秘，脉数实，此毒在脏也。予谓宜急疏去之，以绝其源，使毒不致外侵。彼以为小恙，乃服寻常之药，后大溃而殁。
　　老妇患背疮，初生三头，皆如粟，肿硬木闷烦躁；至六日，其头甚多，脉大按之沉细，为隔蒜灸及托里，渐起发，尚不溃。又数剂，内外虽腐，为筋所隔，脓不得出，至胀痛不安。予谓须开之，彼不从。后虽自穿，毒已攻深矣，亦殁。大抵发背之患，其名虽多，惟阴阳二证为要。若发一头或二头，其形臖赤肿，高头起，疼痛发热，为痈属阳，易治。[188p]

A man had a sore on his back, initially small like a grain, causing him distress, pain, thirst, and constipation; his pulse was rapid and strong, indicating that the poison resided in his organs. I believed it necessary to urgently drain it to eliminate the source, preventing the poison from invading further. He thought it was a minor issue and took ordinary medicine, but eventually, it deteriorated into a severe ulcer, leading to his demise.

An old woman suffered from sores on her back, initially three lumps, all small like grains, swollen, hard, and causing distress and agitation. By the sixth day, the lumps multiplied significantly; her pulse was large and, when pressed, felt deep and fine, with a blockage preventing treatment. Gradual treatment began, although both inside and outside were rotting, the pus could not be expelled due to the muscular barrier, leading to swelling and unbearable pain. I insisted that it needed to be opened, but she refused. Later, even though she tried to pierce it herself, the poison had already penetrated deep, and she also perished. Generally, the affliction of sores on the back, despite being called various names, fundamentally hinges on the dual principles of yin and yang. If one or two lumps arise, exhibiting swelling, redness, elevation, pain, and heat, they belong to the yang category and are easier to treat.[188p]

若初起一头如黍，不肿不赤，闷痛烦躁，大渴便秘，讝语咬牙，四五日间，其头不计数，其疮口各含如一栗，形似莲蓬，故名莲蓬发；积日不溃，按之流血，至八九日或数日，其头成片，所含之物俱出，通结一衣，揭去又结，其口共烂为一疮，其脓内攻，色紫黯，为疽属阴，难治。脉洪滑者尚可，沉细尤难。如此恶证，惟隔蒜灸及涂乌金膏有效。凡人背近脊并髀皮里有筋一层，患此处者，外皮虽破，其筋难溃，以致内脓不出，令人胀痛苦楚，气血转虚，变证百出。若待自溃，多致不救。必须开之，兼以托里。常治此证，以利刀剪之，尚不能去。似此坚物，待其自溃，不亦反伤？非血气壮实者，未见其能自溃也。[189p]

If a lump initially appears like millet, not swollen or red, causing dull pain and irritability, great thirst and constipation, with mumbling or grinding of teeth, within four to five days the lump counts in numbers, its sores resemble a chestnut, taking on the shape of a lotus pod, hence it is called lotus pod hair; if it does not resolve over the days, pressing it releases blood, and by the eighth or ninth day or several days, the lump flattens, and everything contained within comes out, creating a unified clot, which, when removed, re-clots, forming a common sore that rots together, with purulent matter internally attacking, appearing dark purple, belonging to a type of abscess that is hard to treat. A pulse that is rapid and slippery is somewhat manageable, but a deep and thin pulse is particularly difficult. Such a severe condition can only be effectively treated with garlic moxibustion and the application of black ointment. For individuals with this condition presenting in the skin along the spine and thigh where a layer of muscle exists beneath, even if the outer skin breaks, the muscle is hard to rupture, causing internal pus to remain, leading to swelling and suffering, with qi and blood becoming weak, resulting in numerous changes in symptoms. If one waits for it to rupture on its own, it often leads to death. It must be opened up, along with draining the internal matter. Regular treatment of this condition, even with razor or scissors, often fails to remove it. This hard entity, waiting for it to self-rupture, could turn harmful. Those lacking strong blood and qi seldom see it rupture on its own.[189p]

　　一男子年逾五十，患背疮，色紫肿痛，外皮将溃，寝食不安，神思甚疲，用桑柴灸患处出黑血，即鼾睡，觉而诸证如失。服仙方活命饮二剂，又灸一次，脓血皆出；更进二剂，肿痛大退；又服托里消毒散数剂而敛。夫疮势炽甚，宜用峻剂攻之，但年老血气衰弱，况又发在肌表，若专于攻毒，则胃气先损，反致悞事。
　　一妇人背疮发热作痛，专服降火败毒药，溃后尤甚，烦躁时嗽，小便如淋，皆恶证候，辞不治，果死。大抵疮疡之证，五善之中，见一二善证者可治；七恶之内，见一二恶证者难治。若虚中见恶证者，不救；实中无恶者，自愈。此证虽云属火，未有不由阴虚而致者。故经云：督脉经虚，从脑而出；膀胱经虚，从背而出。岂可专泥于火！[190p]

A man over fifty years old suffered from a sore on his back, which was swollen and painful, with a purple color and the skin about to break. He found it hard to eat or sleep, feeling extremely fatigued. He used mulberry branches to cauterize the affected area, releasing black blood, then fell asleep. Upon waking, all symptoms seemed to disappear. After taking two doses of a life-restoring potion and cauterizing once more, pus and blood all came out; with two more doses, the swelling and pain greatly subsided; finally, after taking several doses of a detoxifying powder, it healed.

However, the sore was very severe, and strong medicine was advisable to attack it, but being old, his blood and energy were weak, especially since it appeared on the surface of the skin. If one focuses solely on attacking the poison, the stomach's energy is first harmed, ultimately worsening the conditions.

A woman with a sore on her back experienced heat and pain, and solely took medicines to reduce heat and expel toxins. After the sore burst, the condition worsened, causing agitation, coughing, and painful urination, all of which were bad symptoms. She refused treatment and ultimately died. Generally, when dealing with sores and ulcers, among five good conditions, if one or two good signs appear, treatment may be successful; but among seven bad conditions, if one or two bad signs show up, treatment becomes difficult. If bad signs appear in a weak condition, it is hopeless; if in a strong condition there are no bad signs, recovery may occur by itself. Although this condition is said to be attributed to fire, it invariably arises from yin deficiency. Thus, it is stated in the classics: when the governing vessel is deficient, it emerges from the brain; when the bladder meridian is deficient, it emerges from the back. How can one be solely fixated on fire![190p]

　　赵太守患背疮，肿坚不泽，疮头如粟，脉洪大，按之则濇。经云：骨髓不枯，脏腑不败者，可治。然肿硬色夭，坚如牛领之皮，脉更濇，此精气已绝矣，不治，亦死。
　　张宜人年逾六十，患发背三日，肉色不变，头如粟许，肩背加重，寒热饮冷，脉洪数。陈良甫云：外如麻，里如瓜。齐氏云：憎寒壮热，所患必深。又云：肉色不变，发于内也。予以人参败毒散二剂，及隔蒜灸五十余壮，毒始发，背始轻；再用托里药渐溃。顾气血虚甚而作渴，用参、芪、当归、熟地等药，渴亦止。彼欲速效，自用草药罨患处，毒气复入，遂不救。尝见老弱者患此，疮头不起，或坚如牛领之皮，多不待溃而死。有溃后气血不能培养者，亦死。凡疮初溃，毒正发越，宜用膏药吸之，参、芪等药托之。若反以药遏之，使毒气内攻者，必不救。[191p]

Governor Zhao suffered from a back sore, which was swollen and hard, with no moisture, the sore resembling millet. His pulse was strong and rapid, and when pressed, it felt hard. The text states that if the marrow is not depleted and the organs are not failing, it can be treated. However, if the swelling is hard and the color is dark, as tough as a cow's skin, and the pulse is still more rapid, then this indicates that the vital energy has already been exhausted; without treatment, death is inevitable.

Zhang Yiren, over sixty years old, suffered from a back issue for three days. The color of the flesh did not change, with the sore about the size of millet, and with increasing weight on his shoulders and back, along with symptoms of chills and fever, and a rapid pulse. Chen Liangfu remarked that externally it felt like hemp, but internally like melon. The Qi family noted a dislike for cold and a strong heat, indicating a deep-seated issue. Additionally, with the flesh color unchanged, it was suggested to be an internal problem. I prescribed two doses of Ren Shen Bai Du San and applied garlic moxibustion more than fifty times; the poison began to erupt, relieving some weight from the back. Then I used Tuo Li medicine to gradually promote ulceration. However, since his Qi and blood were extremely deficient, causing thirst, I used herbs like ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and cooked rehmannia, which also alleviated the thirst. He wished for a quick effect, applying herbal poultices directly to the sore, which allowed the toxic energy to re-enter, leading to his demise.

I have often seen elderly and weak individuals affected by this; if the sore does not rise or is as hard as a cow's skin, many do not survive before it ulcerates. Even those who do ulcerate but cannot nourish their Qi and blood would also die. Generally, when a sore first ulcers and the poison is strong, it is advisable to use a plaster to draw it out, followed by herbs like ginseng and astragalus to support healing. If one instead uses medicine to suppress it, causing the toxic energy to attack from within, recovery is surely impossible.[191p]

　　虞弈侍郎背中发小疮，不悟。只以药调补，数日不疼不痒，又不滋蔓，疑之。呼外医灸二百壮，已无及。此公平生不服药，一年来，惟觉时时手脚心热，疾作不早治，又误服补药，何可久也！盖发背无补法。谚云：背无好疮，但发于正中者为真发背。按谓发背无补法，此非通论，然一种痴补而无通变者，又为不可。[192p]

Deputy Minister Yu Yi had small sores on his back but was unaware of them. He only applied medicine to nourish the area, and for several days, there was no pain or itch, nor did it spread, which made him suspicious. He called for an external doctor who performed moxibustion two hundred times, but it was already too late. This individual had never taken medicine throughout his life; for a year, he only felt occasional heat in his palms and soles, and since he neglected early treatment of his illness and mistakenly took nourishing medicine, how could it last long? It is said that there is no remedy for ailments on the back. A proverb states: "There are no good sores on the back; only those situated directly in the center can be deemed true sores of the back." Although it is stated that there are no remedies for back ailments, this is not a universal principle. However, someone who blindly seeks to nourish without understanding the changes in their condition is also in a situation that cannot be ignored.[192p]

　　程明佑治槐充胡妪年六十，疽发背，大如盂，头如蜂窠，呕逆，咽不下，疡医药之，毒虽杀而胃寒泄。程曰：凡病必分阴阳虚实。今胃伤于寒，故呕逆，温补则荣卫充而气血周贯，毒随脓出而肌肉渐生。依方投药四五剂，咽遂下，呕止，痈溃，体渐平。
　　陈斗嵓治王主政，福建人，背患痈，痛甚，发咳逆，十余日水谷不下，脉伏如绝。医皆不治。陈视之曰：此寒凉过甚，中气下陷。以四君加姜、桂三进而病如失，痈亦渐愈。
　　周评事观患背痈，疮口久不合，召疡医徐廷礼疗治，恒以托里、十宣二散与服，不效。徐谓周曰：更请盛用美来共事料理，吾技穷矣。既而盛至，按用药率与徐类，但多加人参五钱，附子稍行功耳。服后两足俱暖，自下而上。谓其子曰：今之药何神哉！顿觉神爽快。服之旬日而疮口平复。[193p]

Cheng Mingyou treated a woman named Hu Yu, who was sixty years old and suffering from a large ulcer on her back, swollen like a bowl, with a head resembling a beehive. She experienced vomiting and difficulty swallowing. The ulcer had been treated with medicines, but though the poison was expelled, it caused a coldness in her stomach and diarrhea. Cheng said, "For every illness, one must differentiate between yin and yang, as well as deficiency and excess. Now the stomach is harmed by cold, hence the vomiting and reversal. By warming and nourishing, we can restore the vital energies and blood circulation, and the poison will be expelled along with the pus, allowing the flesh to gradually regenerate." After following his prescription for four or five doses, she was able to swallow, the vomiting ceased, the ulcer ruptured, and her condition gradually improved.

Chen Dougan treated Wang Zhuzheng, a man from Fujian, who suffered from an ulcer on his back with severe pain and a cough that persisted for over ten days without food or drink. His pulse was nearly imperceptible. The doctors could not treat him. Chen observed and said, "This is due to excessive cold, causing a collapse of the vital energy." He prescribed a formula of the Four Gentlemen herbs, adding ginger and cinnamon to progress the treatment. Gradually, his condition improved, and the ulcer started to heal.

Zhou Pingzhi examined a patient with an ulcer on the back, which had not healed for a long time. He summoned the ulcer specialist Xu Tingli for treatment, who consistently administered medications without effect. Xu then said to Zhou, "Please ask Sheng to join us in the treatment, for my skills have reached their limit." When Sheng arrived, they applied a similar treatment regimen but increased the dosage of ginseng by five qian and made slight modifications with aconite. After taking the medicine, both of his legs became warm, moving from the lower to the upper body. He told his son, "What a miraculous medicine this is! I feel instantly rejuvenated." Within ten days, the wound had completely healed.[193p]

　　汪石山治一老人患痈，诊视之，其脉洪缓而濡，痈肿如碗，皮肉不变，按之不甚痛，微发寒热。乃语之曰：若在髆胛脉络交错皮薄骨高之处，则难矣。今肿去胛骨下掌许，乃太阳经分，尚可治。遂用黄芪五钱，当归、羌活、甘草节各一钱，先令以被盖暖，药熟热服，令微汗，寝熟肿消一晕，五服遂安。
　　进士张德宏背，疽微肿微赤，饮食少思。予用六君等药，脓成而溃；再用大补阳气之类，肉生而敛。忽寒热作呕，患处复肿，其脉浮大，按之若无，形气殊倦。予谓之曰：此胃气虚惫，非疮毒也。彼云：侵晨登厕，触秽始作，信夫先生胃虚之说也！用补托而敛。
　　昆庠王子大背患疽，年余，疮口少许不敛，色黯陷下，面色痿黄，形气怯弱，脉浮缓而濇，此脾肺气虚也。用十全大补汤加附子少许，数剂而元气渐复；却去附子，又三十余剂全愈，而领乡荐。[194p]

Wang Shishan treated an elderly man suffering from a carbuncle. Upon examination, his pulse was flooding, slow, and soft; the carbuncle was as swollen as a bowl, with little change in the skin and flesh, not very painful to the touch, and he had slight chills and fevers. Wang said, "If the swelling were located at a place where the muscles and bones are thin and tightly intertwined, it would be difficult to treat. Now that the swelling is below the shoulder bone, it is at a point of the Sun Meridian, and it is still possible to treat it." He then prescribed five qian of astragalus, one qian each of angelica, notopterygium, and licorice, and advised to keep the patient warm under a cover. The medicine was to be taken hot, inducing slight sweating. After sleeping soundly, the swelling subsided after one night, and after five doses, the patient was stable.

Zhang Dehong, a jinshi, had a slight swelling and redness on his back, with diminished appetite and thought. I used the Six Gentlemen formula, leading to pus formation and rupture; then I used nourishing yang energy herbs, resulting in flesh growth and retraction. Suddenly, he experienced chills and fever, and the affected area swelled again, his pulse was floating and large, almost imperceptible upon pressure, and he felt greatly fatigued. I said to him, "This is due to a deficiency in stomach qi, not a toxin from the sore." He replied, "In the early morning, when I used the toilet, I encountered foulness, which must affirm your claim about my weak stomach!" I used tonifying methods to aid retraction.

Wang Zidai from the county had suffered from a carbuncle on his back for over a year. The sore had barely closed at the opening, the color was dark and depressed, his complexion was sallow and weak, and his pulse was floating, weak, and thin. This indicated a deficiency in the spleen and lung qi. I prescribed the Complete Restoration Decoction with a small addition of fuzi (Aconite), and after several doses, his vitality gradually revived; I then removed the fuzi, and after over thirty doses, he fully recovered and was recommended by the township.[194p]

　　一妇年五十余，四月初，背当心生疽，如粟大，三日渐大，根盘五寸许，不肿痛，不寒热。予诊其脉，微而沉。曰：脉病而形不病者，忌也。实则痛，虚则痒，阴证阳证之所由分也。不发，不治。溃而不敛，亦不治。乃与大补阳气之剂，色白而黯，疮势如故。至十二日，复诊其脉沉，疮势不起，神疲食减，小便淋漓，乃与大补气血加姜、桂二剂，疮亦不起。十五日，因怒呕泻并作，服大补药一剂，疮仍不起。予留药二剂而去。病者昏愦不服。或劝之，省悟。依方连进七剂。十六日疮起而溃，色红而淡，脓亦如之。十九日，予至，喜曰：疮已逾险处，但元气销烁，尚可忧，连与大补二十余剂。五月十一日，病者因劳，自汗口干，舌强，太阳发际脑顶俱胀，复延予至。诊之曰：此气血俱虚，肝胆火上炎。用补中益气汤加山栀、芍药，顿愈。但内热少睡，手足发热，不时寒热，用逍遥散加山栀，热退；复用归脾汤，疮乃愈。计疮发及敛四十二日。[195p]

A woman, over fifty years old, in early April, developed a sore on her back, the size of a grain. After three days, it grew larger, with a root about five inches long. It was neither swollen nor painful, and she didn’t have chills or fever. I took her pulse, which was weak and deep. I said: when the pulse indicates illness but the body does not show symptoms, it is concerning. In a case of excess, there is pain; in deficiency, there is itching. This is what distinguishes yin and yang presentations. If it does not erupt, it will not be treated. If it erupts but does not heal, it will also not be treated. I then gave her a remedy to greatly replenish yang energy, which appeared pale and dull; the sore remained the same. By the twelfth day, upon checking her pulse again, it was still deep, the sore had not progressed, she felt fatigued, had a reduced appetite, and her urination was scanty. I then prescribed a remedy to greatly replenish qi and blood, adding ginger and cinnamon, yet the sore also did not progress. On the fifteenth day, due to anger, she experienced vomiting and diarrhea simultaneously, so I had her take a dose of the restorative medicine, but the sore still did not improve. I left two more doses of medicine and left. The patient was in a daze and did not take the medicine. Some encouraged her, and she finally understood. Following the prescribed method, she took seven doses in succession. On the sixteenth day, the sore began to erupt and became red and light in color, with pus similarly appearing. On the nineteenth day, I arrived and was pleased to see: the sore had crossed the critical phase, but her vital energy was still waning, which remained concerning, so I continued with the great restorative medicine for over twenty doses. On May 11th, due to overexertion, the patient developed spontaneous sweating, a dry mouth, a stiff tongue, and swelling at both the temples and the crown. I was called upon again. Upon examination, I concluded: both qi and blood are deficient, and there is inflamed fire in the liver and gallbladder. I used a tonic formula to invigorate qi, adding gardenia and peony, and she promptly improved. However, she experienced internal heat, had difficulty sleeping, and her hands and feet felt warm intermittently, accompanied by chills and fever. I prescribed Xiao Yao San with additional gardenia, and the heat subsided. I then used Gui Pi Tang, and the sore finally healed. In total, the sore lasted forty-two days from onset to healing.[195p]

　　操江都宪伍松月背疮，愈后大热，悞为实火，用苦寒药一锺，寒热益甚，欲冷水浴身，脉浮大，按之全无。予曰：此阳气虚浮在肌表，无根之火也。急用六君子加附子，一剂即愈。
　　一男子背疮不敛，小便赤濇，臖肿发热，口干体倦，脉洪数而无力，用参、芪、归、朮、熟地、芎、芍、陈皮、麦冬、五味、炙草、肉桂，补元气，引虚火归经，脉证益甚，此药力未能及也，再剂顿退，却去肉桂，又数剂而愈，此证因前失补元气故耳。[196p]

A man had a back sore that did not heal and was experiencing hesitation in urination, with red turbid urine, swelling and heat, dry mouth, and fatigue. His pulse was rapid and forceful but weak. I prescribed ginseng, astragalus, angelica, poria, cooked rehmannia, notopterygium, peony, aged tangerine peel, ophiopogon, five-flavor berry, honey-fried licorice, and cinnamon to tonify the original qi and draw the vacuous fire back to the channels. However, the pulse and symptoms worsened; the medicine was insufficient. After another dose, the symptoms suddenly improved, but I removed the cinnamon and after several more doses, he recovered. This condition was due to a prior deficiency in tonifying the original qi.[196p]

　　中翰郑朝用背疽发热，吐痰，饮食无味，肌肉不生，疮出鲜血。予曰：此脾气亏损，不能摄血归源也，法当补脾胃。彼不信，消毒凉血。加恶寒呕吐，始悟其言。用六君加炮姜、半夏、茯苓数剂，诸证悉退；又令用十全大补，疮口渐敛。后因饮食稍多，泄泻成痢，此脾胃虚寒下陷，用补中益气下四神丸而痢止。继以六君子汤而疮愈。
　　封君袁怀雪背疽，发热作渴，脉数无力，用四物加黄蘗、知母、元参、山栀、连翘、五味、麦冬、银花，脉证渐退；又加白芷、参、芪，腐肉悉溃。因停药且劳，热渴仍作，乃与参、芪、归、芷、炙草、山药、山萸、茯苓、泽泻、肉桂而安；又以六味地黄丸及十全大补而敛。[197p]

Zheng Chao, a scholar of Zhonghan, suffered from a back ulcer accompanied by fever, phlegm, loss of appetite, muscle atrophy, and fresh bleeding from the sores. I said: "This is due to deficiency in the spleen's energy, which cannot control the blood and return it to its source. The treatment should focus on tonifying the spleen and stomach." He did not believe this and opted for methods to detoxify and cool the blood. However, he soon experienced severe chills and vomiting, which led him to realize the truth of my words. I then recommended the Ten Complete Great Tonifying Decoction, and the wounds gradually healed. Therefore, I used the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction with the Four Divine Pills to stop the dysentery. Subsequently, he took the Six Gentlemen Decoction again, and his wounds healed completely.

Yuan Huaixue, a nobleman, had a back ulcer, experienced fever and thirst, with a rapid but weak pulse. Additionally, I used the Six-Ingredient Rehmannia Pill and the Ten Complete Great Tonifying Decoction to consolidate his recovery.[197p]

　　都宪周宏冈背疽肿而不溃，脉大而浮，此阳气虚弱而邪气壅滞也。用托里散，倍用参、芪，反内热作渴，脉洪大鼓指，此虚火也。用前散急加肉桂，脉证顿退；仍用托里而愈。若以为热毒而用寒药，则误矣。
　　太仆王的塘背疮初起，因大劳又用十宣散之类，加喘渴内热，脉大无力，此阳气自伤，不能升举，下陷于阴分而为内热也。予以补中益气加酒炒芍药、麦门冬、五味子治之而愈。
　　上舍张克恭患背疮，内服外傅，皆寒凉败毒，遍身作痛，欲呕少食，晡热畏寒。予曰：遍身作痛，荣卫虚而不能营于肉里也；欲呕少食，脾胃虚寒，而不能消化饮食也；内热晡热，阴血内虚，而阳气陷于阴分也；恶寒畏寒，阳气虚弱，而不能卫于肌肤也。此皆由脾胃之气不足所致。遂用补中益气汤，诸证渐退；又以十全大补汤腐肉渐溃；又用六君子汤加芎、归，肌肉顿生而愈。[198p]

Zhou Honggang, the prefect of the capital, had a back ulcer that did not suppurate, with a large and floating pulse, indicating a deficiency of yang qi and stagnation of evil qi. Wang Dedang from the Ministry of Justice initially had a back sore, exacerbated by overexertion and the use of medicinal formulas like Shixuan Powder, leading to internal heat with symptoms of panting and thirst, and a large, weak pulse. Zhang Kegong from the Upper Residence had a back ulcer. All these issues stemmed from insufficient qi in the spleen and stomach. Thus, I used Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, and the symptoms gradually improved. I also utilized Shi Quan Da Bu Tang as the necrotic tissue began to break down and later used Liu Jun Zi Tang with added Chuanxiong and Angelica, resulting in rapid regrowth of muscle and eventual recovery.[198p]

　　儒者周两峰怀抱久郁，背脊患疽，肝脉弦洪，脾脉浮大，按之微细，以补中益气汤加桔梗、贝母，少用金银花、白茫二剂，肝脉顿退，脾脉顿强；乃以活命饮二剂，脓溃肿消，肝脉仍弦；此毒虽去而胃气复伤，仍用补中益气汤加茯苓、半夏而愈。
　　上舍蔡东之患背疮，予用托里之药而溃，疮口尚未全敛。时值仲冬，兼咳嗽。予曰：疮口未敛，脾气虚也；咳嗽不止，肺气虚也。法当补其母。一日，与其同宴，见忌羊肉。予曰：补可以去弱，人参、羊肉之类是也，最宜食之。遂每日不撤，旬余而疮敛，嗽亦顿愈矣。[199p]

The Confucian scholar Zhou Liangfeng had long been troubled by internal accumulation, suffering from a sore on his back, with a taut and strong liver pulse, and a floating and large spleen pulse. As for Cai Dong, who suffered from a sore on his back, I used the Tuo Li medicine and it softened, but the sore had not fully closed. At that time, it was mid-winter, and he also had a cough. 　　宪副屠九峰孟春患背疮，色黯漫肿作渴，便数，尺脉洪数，此肾水干涸，当殁于火旺之际。不信，更用苦寒之药，复伤元气以促其殁。
　　京兆柴黼庵仲夏患背疮，色黯微肿，发热烦躁，痰涎自出，小腹阴实，手足逆冷，右关浮濇，两尺微细。予曰：此虚寒之证也。王太仆云：大热而不热，是无火也。决不能起。恳求治之，遂用大温补之药一剂，流涎虽止，患处不起，终不能救。
　　顾包泉老医，年六十有五，因盛怒，疽发于背，大如盂，四围色黑，召疡医治之，用冷药敷贴，敷已觉凉。约曰：七八日后，为用刀去瘀肉。顾俟其去，曰：四围色黑，乃血滞，更加冷药，非其治也。乃去旧药，更治热药傅之，觉甚痒，终夜，明日，色鲜红，臖肿亦消，惟中起数十孔如蜂房。一日，又觉恶心作哕，视一人头如两人头。自诊曰：此虚极证也。用参附大剂进二服，视已正矣，不数日竟愈。[200p]

　　一妇因得子迟，服神仙聚宝丹，背生痈，甚危，脉散大而濇，急以加减四物汤百余贴，补其阴血，幸其质厚，易于收敛。
　　吴庠史邦直之内，仲夏患背疽，死肉不溃，发热痛甚，作呕少食，口干饮汤，脉洪大，按之如无，此内真寒而外假热，当舍时从证，先用六君加炮姜、肉桂四剂，饮食顿进，诸证顿退；复用十全大补汤，仍加姜、桂之类五十余剂，而死肉溃；又五十余剂而新肉生。斯人气血充盛，而疮易起易敛，使医者逆知，预为托里，必无此患。
　　一男子不慎房劳，背胛肿高三寸许，阔径尺余，自汗盗汗，内热发热，口干饮汤，脉浮大，按之弱濇，此精虚气弱为患，用十全大补加五味、麦冬、山萸、山药四剂，诸证悉退。因予他往，别用流气饮一剂，虚证悉具，肿硬如石。予仍以前药六剂而愈。[201p]

　　内翰杨皋湖孟夏患背疽，服克伐之剂，二旬余矣，漫肿坚硬，重如负石，隔蒜灸五十余壮，背遂轻；以六君加砂仁二剂，涎沫涌出，饮食愈少。此脾虚阳气脱陷，剂用温补，反呕不食，仍用前药作大剂，加附子、姜、桂，又不应；遂以参、芪各一斤，归、朮、陈皮各半斤，附子一两，煎服三日而尽，流涎顿止，腐肉顿溃，饮食顿进；再用姜、桂等药托里健脾，腐脱而疮愈矣。
　　王德之患发背，脉浮数，按之则濇，大便五六日不行，腹不加胀。余曰：邪在表不在里，但因气血虚，饮食少，故大便不行，非热结也，宜生气血为主。彼泥积毒在内，用大黄之药下之，遂连泻三四次，更加发热；来日又服一剂，泻遂不止，饮食不化，呃逆不绝，手足皆冷。予诊之，脉已脱，辞不治。其子曰：泻之能为害乎？余曰：服利药而利不止者，死。不当泻而强泻，令人开肠洞泄不止者，死。下多亡阴者，死。[202p]

In the early summer, Yang Gao from Neihan suffered from a back abscess. I then used ginger and cinnamon and other herbs to strengthen the spleen, resulting in the necrotic tissue shedding and the ulcer healing.

Wang Dezhi suffered from back pain, his pulse was superficial and rapid; pressing down revealed a thin pulse. He had not had a bowel movement for five to six days, and his abdomen was not distended. I said: The pathogens are on the surface, not internally, but due to a deficiency in qi and blood, and reduced food intake, the bowels are not moving; it is not due to heat accumulation, and we should focus on nourishing qi and blood. However, there was accumulated internal toxicity, and I used rhubarb to purge it, resulting in three or four loose stools and increased fever. The next day, after taking another dose, he continued to have diarrhea, food was not digesting, he suffered from continuous hiccups, and his hands and feet became cold. Upon diagnosing him, his pulse was faint, and I advised against further treatment. His son asked: Could purging be harmful? I replied: If one takes a purgative and diarrhea does not stop, it can be fatal. If one purges when it's inappropriate and causes endless bowel movements, it can be fatal. If too much fluid is lost, it can be fatal.[202p]

曰：疮疡乃积毒存脏，若不驱逐其毒，何以得解？余曰：疮疡虽积毒在脏腑，治法先当助胃气使根本坚固，参以行经活血时宜之药，非专用大黄也。今病在表而反以峻利之剂，重夺其阴，其可乎哉？故曰：表病里和而反下之，则中气虚，表邪乘虚而入，由是变证百出。虽云脉浮数，邪在表，属外因，当用内托复煎散，其间黄芩、苍朮亦不敢用。脉沉实，邪在内，属内因，当用内疏黄连汤，其中大黄、槟榔亦不敢用。况浮数濇三脉，皆主血气俱虚，邪既在表，而反用峻利之剂，重泻其里，诛伐无过，不死何俟！[203p]

It is said: Sores and ulcers are a result of accumulated toxins within the organs. If one does not expel these toxins, how can one find relief? I said: Although the toxins accumulate in the organs in cases of sores and ulcers, the treatment should first assist the stomach’s energy to strengthen the foundation, combined with medicines to invigorate blood circulation at the appropriate times, rather than relying solely on harsh purgatives like Da Huang. Now, if there is an exterior condition yet one were to use extreme purging agents, taking away the yin, how could this be acceptable? Therefore, it is said: In cases of exterior diseases, if one forces a downward action while the interior is harmonized, the vital energy becomes deficient, allowing external pathogens to exploit this weakness, leading to countless variations in malady. Though the pulse may be floating and rapid, indicating that the pathogen is on the surface and external in nature, one should use internal tonics and reconciling decoctions, and even Huang Qin and Cang Zhu should not be used liberally. If the pulse is deep and solid, indicating that the pathogen is internal and attributed to internal causes, one should use Huang Lian Decoction to disperse it internally, and even Da Huang and Bing Lang should be avoided. Moreover, considering the floating and rapid pulses—indicating deficiency of both blood and vital energy—if the pathogen remains at the surface yet one resorts to harsh purgatives to severely deplete the interior, the punishment will be excessive, leading to death, if not immediately.[203p]

　　张锦衣年逾四十，患发背，心脉洪数，势危剧。心脉洪数，乃心火炽甚。经云：诸痛痒疮疡，皆属心火。心主血，心气滞则血不行，故生痈也。骑竹马灸穴，是心脉所由之地，急灸之以泻心火，隔蒜灸以拔其毒，再以托里消毒，果愈。
　　平氏室患发背，以托里消毒药二十余剂而溃。因怒顿吐血五六碗许，气弱脉细，此气血虚极也。遂令服独参膏斤许，稍缓，更以参、芪、归、朮、陈皮、炙甘草三十余剂，疮口渐合。设投以犀角地黄汤沉寒之药，鲜有不误。[204p]

Zhang Jinyi, over forty years old, suffered from back pain, and his heart pulse was rapid and forceful, indicating a dangerous condition. A rapid and forceful heart pulse signifies excessive heart fire. The classics state: all pains, itchiness, sores, and ulcers relate to heart fire. The heart governs blood; if the heart energy is stagnant, blood does not circulate, leading to abscesses. To relieve the heart fire, one should apply moxibustion at the acupuncture points related to the heart; urgent moxibustion should be done to drain the heart fire, and garlic can be used in moxibustion to draw out its toxins, then combined with detoxifying agents to achieve complete recovery.

The Ping family's servant experienced back pain and, after taking over twenty doses of detoxifying medicine, the condition worsened. 　　顾浩室年逾四十，患发背，治以托里药而溃。忽呕而疮痛，胃脉弦紧，彼以为余毒内攻。东垣云：呕吐无时，手足厥冷，脏腑之虚也。丹溪云：溃后发呕不食者，湿气侵于内也。又云：脓出而反痛，此为虚也。今胃脉弦紧，木乘土位，其虚明矣。予欲以六君子汤，用酒炒芍药、砂仁、藿香治之。彼自服护心散，呕愈甚。复邀治，仍用前药，更以补气血药，两月而愈。大抵湿气内侵，或感秽气而作呕者，必喜温而脉弱；热毒内攻而作呕者，必喜凉而脉数，必须辨认明白。亦有大便不实，或腹作痛，或膨胀，或呕吐，或吞酸嗳腐，此肠胃虚寒也，以理中汤治之；如不应，加熟附子二三片。有侵晨作泻者，名曰肾泻，以二神丸治之。有食少渐瘦者，为脾肾虚也，尤宜服二神丸，是又治梦遗生肌肉之要药也。尝治饮食少思，吞酸嗳腐，诸药不应，惟服理中汤及附子理中丸有效。盖此证皆因中气虚寒，不能运化郁滞所致，故用温补则中气温和，自无此证矣。[205p]

Gu Haoshi was over forty years old and suffered from a back ailment, which he treated with a medicinal powder that led to an abscess. Suddenly he began to vomit and experienced pain from the sore; his stomach pulse was tight and wiry, which he believed to be internal toxicity attacking him. Dongyuan stated that vomiting at any time, along with cold hands and feet, indicates a deficiency in the internal organs. Danshi noted that if vomiting occurs after a sore has burst, it signifies internal dampness. Additionally, if pus is discharged but pain returns, this indicates deficiency. His tight and wiry stomach pulse, with wood overpowering earth, clearly indicated deficiency.

I intended to use the Six Gentlemen Decoction, with wine-fried peony root, cardamom, and patchouli to treat him. However, he took Hu Xin San on his own, which worsened the vomiting. When he sought treatment again, I continued with the previous prescription but added tonifying herbs for qi and blood. After two months, he recovered.

In general, if dampness invades internally or if there is a response to contaminated air that causes vomiting, the patient will prefer warmth and have a weak pulse. If heat and toxicity attack and cause vomiting, they will prefer coolness and have a rapid pulse; hence, clear differentiation is necessary. There may also be issues like unsatisfactory bowel movements, abdominal pain, bloating, vomiting, or acid reflux, which indicate a deficiency of cold in the intestines and stomach, requiring treatment with Li Zhong Tang. If the condition does not improve, adding two to three slices of processed aconite may help.

If diarrhea occurs in the early morning, it is termed kidney diarrhea and can be treated with Er Shen Wan. If there is a gradual loss of appetite leading to weight loss, it indicates a deficiency of the spleen and kidneys, and it is particularly important to take Er Shen Wan, as it is also a crucial remedy for nocturnal emissions and to build muscle.

I once treated a patient who had little appetite, was preoccupied with thoughts of food, and experienced acid reflux and belching, but none of the medications were effective except for Li Zhong Tang and Fuzi Li Zhong Wan. This condition arises due to deficient and cold middle energy that cannot transform stagnation, hence using warming and tonifying methods will harmonize the middle qi, eliminating such symptoms.[205p]

　　一男子渴后，背发疽未溃，脉数无力，此阴虚火动，用加减八味丸(口父)咀，二剂稍缓，次用丸剂而愈。[206p]

　　刘太宰紫岩太夫人发背，元气不足，用托里药而起。王安人发背正溃时，欲速效，俱敷草药，即日而死。
　　刘大尹年将五十，陆路赴京，兼丧子，患发背盈尺，中六寸许；不痛，发热口干，恶寒自汗，少食，大便不禁，且气促，脉浮大，按之空虚。余用补中益气汤加半夏、茯苓四剂，又以隔蒜灸之。彼云：背重已去，形气少健，但吞酸，前日所进饮食，觉仍在腹。又以前药加姜、桂服二剂，饮食少进，吞酸已止，始得睡，疮且不痛不溃，疑为阴证。余曰：此阳气虚，不能营于患处，故所患肉死而不痛不溃也。若胃气回，饮食进，死肉即溃矣。仍服前药六剂，饮食渐进，患处渐溃，脉有力。余曰：此阳气回矣。后惑于他医云：必服飞龙夺命丹，出汗为善。遂进一服，汗大出，三日不止，复请治。余曰：汗多亡阳，无能为也。强曰：诸书云汗之则疮已，岂能为患？后果死。[207p]

　　东垣先生云：疮疡因风热郁于下，其人多怒，其疮色赤肿高，结硬而痛，左关脉洪缓而弦，是邪客于血脉之上，皮肤之间，故发汗而通其荣卫，则邪气去矣。
　　宜兴徐符卿年逾四十，患发背五日不起，肉色不变，脉弱少食，大便不实。予以凡疽未溃，脉先弱，难于收敛，用托里消毒散二剂方起发。彼惑一妪言，贴膏药，服攻毒剂，反盛，背如负石，复请予治。遂以隔蒜灸三十余壮。彼云：背不觉重，但痒痛未知。更以托里药知痛痒。脓清，仍以前药倍加参、芪，佐以姜、桂，脓稍稠。又为人惑，外用猪腰子，贴抽脓血，内服硝黄剂，遂流血五六碗许，连泻十余行，腹内如冰，饮食不进，不得已速予诊之。脉尽脱，已不可医矣。盖其证属大虚不足之甚，虽一于温补，犹恐不救，况用攻伐之剂，不死何俟！[208p]

Mr. Dongyuan says: The sores and ulcers arise from wind and heat stagnating in the lower part of the body. Such individuals are often prone to anger, and their sores are red, swollen, elevated, hard, and painful. The pulse is weak and slow, with a tense quality in the left guan position. This indicates that the evil energy has invaded the blood vessels and resides between the skin layers. Therefore, inducing sweating to circulate the defensive and nutritive Qi will eliminate the pathogenic energy.

Xu Fuqing from Yixing, over forty years old, suffered from a back sore for five days without improvement. The color of the flesh did not change, the pulse was weak, he had little appetite, and his stools were loose. I found that generally, if the sore had not yet burst, the pulse would be weak first, making it hard to gather and contain the condition. I prescribed two doses of the Tuoli Xiaodu San to help initiate the process. However, he heeded an old woman’s advice to apply a medicated plaster and take a toxic-clearing medicine, which made the condition worse; his back felt as heavy as carrying a stone, prompting him to seek my treatment again.

I then performed moxibustion with garlic for more than thirty sessions. He reported that while his back felt heavy, it was merely itchy and painful without any other sensations. I continued using the Tuoli medicine to alleviate the pain and itchiness. The pus became clearer, and I increased the original formula with more ginseng and astragalus, along with ginger and cinnamon, causing the pus to thicken slightly.

Yet, he was misled again by others, applying pig kidneys to draw out the pus and blood, while internally taking a salt and sulfur mixture, which resulted in a blood loss of about five to six bowls and continuous diarrhea for over ten instances. His abdomen felt like ice, and he could not eat or drink. Reluctantly, I hurried to examine him. His pulse had become faint and weak; he was beyond medical help. His symptoms indicated extreme deficiency and insufficiency; although warm tonics could still be considered, I feared they would be ineffective. How could it be that using aggressive remedies would not lead to death![208p]

　　邝进士患痈将痊，大便秘结，服大黄等药，反废饮食。余用补气血之剂加桃仁、麻仁，未效；更以猪胆汁深纳谷道，续以养血气而愈。
　　王太守宜人患发背，脓熟不开，昏闷不食，此毒入内也，断不治。强之，针脓碗许，稍苏，须臾竟亡。大抵血气壮实，脓自涌出，老弱之人，气血枯槁，必须迎而夺之，顺而取之。若毒结四肢，砭刺少缓，腐溃深大，亦难收敛。痛结于颊项胸腹紧要之地，不问壮弱，急宜针刺，否则难治。[209p]

Kuang, a successful candidate in the imperial examination, was suffering from a carbuncle that was beginning to heal, but he had severe constipation. He took rhubarb and other medicines, which caused him to lose his appetite. I used a remedy to replenish his qi and blood, adding peach kernels and sesame seeds, but it was ineffective. I then administered pig bile deeply into the gastrointestinal tract, and continued with tonics for his blood and qi, leading to his recovery.

Governor Wang's wife was suffering from a carbuncle on her back that was festering and not breaking open, causing her to feel lethargic and unable to eat. This indicated that poison had entered her body, which could not be treated easily. I forced the issue, using a needle to open up the abscess slightly, and she showed some signs of improvement, but soon after, she passed away. Generally speaking, when a person's blood and qi are robust, pus will flow out naturally; however, in the elderly and weak, the qi and blood become depleted, making it necessary to confront and expel the pus, to follow the natural order in treatment. If the poison becomes lodged in the limbs, requiring more gentle needling, or if it has festered deeply and extensively, it will be difficult to contain. When there is painful swelling in critical areas such as the cheeks, neck, or abdomen, it is urgent to employ acupuncture, regardless of whether the patient is strong or weak; otherwise, treatment will be challenging.[209p]

　　汪夫人发背，用敷药，冷彻胸内，欲呕，急令洗去，用托里药而愈。
　　张侍御发背，专用敷药；疮黯不起，胸膈痞闷，气不能呼吸，自分不治，余用托里辛温药而愈。
　　王通府患发背十余日，势危脉大，先以槐花酒二服，杀其势退；更以败毒二剂，再以托里药数剂，渐溃；又用桑燃艾灸患处，每日灸良久，仍以膏贴之；灸至数次，脓溃腐脱，以托里药加白朮、陈皮，月余而愈。
　　邓大尹发背，六七日满背肿痛，势甚危，与隔蒜灸百壮，饮槐花酒二碗，即睡；随服托里消毒药，十去五六；令将桑燃艾灸患处而溃；不数日愈。
　　太监刘关患发背，予奉旨往治。肿痛紫色，诊其脉息沉数。陈良甫云：脉数发热而痛者，发于阳也。且疮疡赤甚则紫，即火极似水也。询之，尝服透骨丹半载，乃积温成热所致，遂以内疏黄连汤，再服稍平；更用排脓消毒散，及猪蹄汤、太乙膏而愈。经曰：色与脉当相参应。治之者在明亢害承制之理，阴阳变化之机焉耳。[210p]

Madam Wang suffered from a back boil, applied medicine, which coldly affected her chest, causing nausea. She urgently ordered the medicine to be washed off and was cured with a warming remedy.

Assistant Zhang had a back boil and used only external medicine; the sore did not appear dark, but there was chest distension, making breathing difficult. Believing he could not be cured, he was treated with a warming remedy and recovered.

Wang Tongfu had a back boil for over ten days with a serious condition and a strong pulse. Initially, two doses of sophora flower wine were given to reduce the severity; then, two doses of detoxifying medicine, followed by several doses of a warming remedy, gradually led to the boil breaking. He applied moxa on the affected area for a long time daily and continued with ointment; after moxibustion several times, pus burst out and decayed. A warming remedy with white atractylodes and dried tangerine peel was used, and after over a month, he recovered.

Deng Dayin had a back boil. After six or seven days, his back was swollen and painful, the condition serious. He received moxa treatments with garlic paste for a hundred times, drank two bowls of sophora flower wine, and then slept; subsequently, he took a detoxifying remedy, and after ten doses, he felt relieved. He was advised to apply moxa to the affected area, leading to his recovery in a few days.

Eunuch Liu Guan suffered from a back boil, and I was ordered to treat him. The swelling was painful and purple, with a pulse that was deep and rapid. Chen Liangfu said: a rapid pulse with heat and pain indicates an external yang condition. Moreover, if the sore is very red and purple, it signifies extreme heat resembling water. Inquiry revealed he had taken Bone-Penetrating Pill for half a year, resulting in accumulated heat. Therefore, a cleansing Huanglian Decoction was given, followed by more balanced medicine. He was then treated with pus-dispersing detoxifying powder, pig’s hoof soup, and Taiyi ointment, achieving recovery. As the classics say, color and pulse should correspond. The practitioner should understand the principles of excess and deficiency, and the mechanisms of yin and yang transformations.[210p]

　　一儒者背肿一块，按之则软，肉色如故，饮食如常，劳则吐痰体倦，此脾气虚而痰滞，用补中益气加茯苓、半夏，少加羌活，外用阴阳散，以姜汁调擦而消。后因劳头运作呕，仍以前药去羌活，加生姜、蔓荆而愈。
　　陈逊妇卧床十三年矣。嘉靖癸卯遭回禄，益加忧郁。甲辰三月，右肩下发一块，臖肿如瓯，中赤外白，先用凉药一剂，不解；次用十宣散四剂，加痛略红。迎徐南楼视之，连投参、芪、丁、桂、防、芷之剂，脓溃。徐云：无恙矣，辞。后眩运呕逆，恶寒战栗，顶陷脓清。偶检予《外科发挥》至发背门云：若初起一头如粟，不肿不赤，烦躁便秘，四五日间生头不计其数，疮口各如含一粟，名曰莲房发，云云，始骇为恶证，治法虽详，不谙于行。迎予至，诊云：辛凉解散，气血两虚者忌之。连投参、芪、归、朮、地黄、姜、附大剂，肿高脓稠，纴乌金膏，数日果腐落如脂膜者数片。人参每服加至八钱，日进二服，逾两月平复。[211p]

A scholar developed a swelling on his back, which was soft when pressed, with the normal flesh color. His diet remained unaffected, but he felt fatigued and coughed up phlegm when laboring. This indicated a deficiency of the spleen and stagnation of phlegm. I treated him with a tonifying formula to replenish the center and benefit qi, adding Poria and Pinellia, with a little Qianghuo, and applied a medicine called Yin-Yang Powder externally, mixed with ginger juice to aid in absorption. Later, due to fatigue and brain strain, he experienced vomiting. I used the previous formula but omitted Qianghuo, adding fresh ginger and Vitex to achieve recovery.

Chen Xun's wife had been bedridden for thirteen years. During the Jia Jing period in the year of Gui Mao, she became even more melancholic due to misfortunes. In the third month of the year of Jia Chen, a lump formed under her right shoulder, swollen like a bowl, red on the inside and white outside. First, I prescribed a cooling medication, which did not resolve the issue; then, I used a formula called Shi Xuan San for four doses, which caused slight redness and pain. Upon the visit from Xu Nanlou, I prescribed a combination of ginseng, astragalus, angelica, cinnamon, and ligusticum, leading to the formation of pus. Xu said: "No longer ill," and took his leave. Later, she experienced dizziness and vomiting, foul chills and shivering, and the pus had cleared.

By chance, I referenced my "Surgical Treatise," which states: "If at the initial stage there is a small nodule resembling a grain, with no swelling or redness, accompanied by restlessness and constipation, within four or five days, numerous nodules can form, each like a grain, named 'Lotus Flower Nodules.'" This initially seemed like a severe condition; although the treatment methods were detailed, I was not well-versed in practice. Xu came to me for diagnosis and I stated: "Spicy and cooling dispersal should be avoided if there is deficiency of both qi and blood." I then prescribed large doses of ginseng, astragalus, angelica, atractylodes, rehmannia, ginger, and dang shen. The swelling increased and the pus thickened, requiring the application of a black ointment. After several days, the discharge resembled pieces of greasy film. Each dose of ginseng was increased to eight taels, taking two doses a day, and in over two months, she returned to a stable state.[211p]

　　郑挥使年逾五十，患发背，形证俱虚，用托里药而溃。但有腐肉当去，彼惧不肯，延至旬日，则好肉皆败矣。虽投大剂，毒甚，竟不救。古人谓坏肉恶于狼虎，毒于蜂螫，缓去之则戕贼性命，信哉！
　　舍亲居宾鸥，仲夏患发背，黯肿尺余，皆有小头，如铺黍状，四日矣。此真气虚而邪气实，遂隔蒜灸，服活命饮二剂，其邪顿退；乃纯补其真气，又将生脉散以代茶饮，疮邪大退。予因他往，三日复视之，饮食不入，中央肉死，大便秘结，小便赤浊。予曰：中央肉死，毒气盛而脾气虚也；大便不通，肠虚而不能传送；小便赤浊，脾虚而火下陷，治亦难矣。彼始云：莫非间断补药之过？予曰：然。乃急服六君子加当归、柴胡、升麻，饮食渐进，大便自通，外用乌金膏涂中央三寸许，四围红肿渐消，中央黑腐渐去；乃敷当归膏，用地黄丸，与前药间服，将百剂而愈。[212p]

Zheng, the envoy, over fifty years old, suffered from a back ailment, his form and evidence both weak, and he used a topical remedy that caused a rupture. However, there was decayed flesh that needed to be removed, but he was afraid and refused, prolonging it for ten days, resulting in all the good flesh rotting. Even though strong doses were given, the poison was severe, and ultimately, it could not be saved. The ancients said that rotten flesh is worse than wolves and tigers, more toxic than bee stings; if left untreated, it can indeed threaten life, truly!

In the guest quarters away from family, in mid-summer, there was another who suffered from a back ailment, swelling over an inch, with small heads resembling the shape of millet, for four days. This was a case of true qi being deficient while evil qi was real, so garlic moxibustion was employed and two doses of a life-saving drink were taken, leading to an immediate retreat of the evil qi; then there was pure supplementation of the true qi, and Shengmai Powder was used instead of tea, greatly diminishing the sore evil. I went elsewhere and returned after three days; he could not eat, the central flesh was dying, his bowel movements were blocked, and his urine was red and turbid. I said: The central flesh is dying, the toxic qi is strong and the spleen qi is deficient; the bowel not moving indicates the intestines are weak and cannot transport; the urine being red and turbid shows spleen deficiency causing fire to sink down, making treatment difficult. He initially wondered if the interruption of tonics was to blame? I said: Yes. Therefore, he urgently took the Six Gentleman Decoction, adding Angelica, Bupleurum, and Cimicifuga; food intake gradually increased, bowel movements resumed, and an external application of black ointment was used on the central area for about three inches. The surrounding redness and swelling gradually subsided, and the central black rotting began to diminish; then Angelica ointment was applied, and Rehmannia Pills were taken alongside the previous medicine, until after a hundred doses, he was cured.[212p]

　　职方王的塘背疽，溃后小便淋漓，或时自遗，作渴引饮，烦热不寐，疮口焮赤，时或如灼，时或便遗。余曰：此肾虚之恶证。用加减八味丸加麦冬，数剂而痊。
　　太守朱阳山患背疽，漫肿色黯，微肿作渴，疮头数十，左尺脉洪大，按之无力，此肾虚之证，先用活命饮二剂以杀其毒，午前以参、芪、归、朮之类壮气血，午后以加减八味丸料，固肾气喜其未用败毒之药，元气未损，故数日脓出肉腐而愈。
　　驾部林汝玉冬不衣绵，作渴饮冷，每自喜壮实，哂予衣绵。诊其脉数大无力。予曰：至火令，当求予也。三月间，果背热，便秘，脉濇，用四物加芩、连、山栀数剂，大便稍和；却去芩、连加参、朮、茯苓二十余剂，及前丸半斤许，渴减六七，背热亦退。至夏背发一疽，纯用托里之剂而敛。[213p]

Zhi Fang Wang had a back sore that, after bursting, caused his urination to be dribbling and at times involuntary. He experienced thirst and often sought to drink, felt feverish and could not sleep. The sore was red and burning, sometimes feeling like it was scorched. I said: This is a severe case of kidney deficiency. I prescribed the modified Eight Herb Pill combined with Maidong; after a few doses, he recovered.

Governor Zhu Yangshan suffered from a back sore that was swollen and dark in color, slightly swollen with thirst. There were dozens of sores, and his left pulse was strong but weak upon pressure; this pointed to kidney deficiency. I first used two doses of the Lifesaving Decoction to eliminate the poison, then in the morning, I used ginseng, astragalus, angelica, and poria to strengthen the qi and blood. In the afternoon, I gave the modified Eight Herb Pill, as the kidney qi was still strong enough to bear the poison-clearing medicine, and the original qi had not been depleted. Thus, after several days, pus emerged and the flesh healed.

Lin Ruyu of the Driving Department did not wear cotton in winter and drank cold beverages, boasting of his robustness and mocking my cotton clothing. Upon examining his pulse, it was rapid and strong but lacking force. I told him: The heat must be addressed urgently. During March, he indeed developed heat in the back and constipation. His pulse was thin, so I prescribed the Four Substance Decoction with additional herbs like scutellaria, coptis, and gardenia for several doses, which slightly eased his constipation. I then removed scutellaria and coptis and added ginseng, angelica, and poria for over twenty doses, alongside about half a pound of the previous pills, which reduced his thirst by six or seven and also alleviated the back heat. By summer, he developed a sore on his back, and I used topical ointments to treat and contain it.[213p]

　　一男子背疮出血，烦躁作渴，脉洪大，按之如无，此血脱发躁，用当归补血汤二剂，少愈；又以八珍加黄芪、山栀数剂全愈。
　　南仪部贺朝卿，陛山西少参，别时，予见其唇鼻青黑，且时搔背，问其故？曰：有一小疮耳。予与视之，果疽也。此脾胃败坏，为不治之证。予素与善，悲其途次不便殡殓，遂托其僚友张东华辈强留之，勉与大补，但出紫血，虚极也。或谓毒炽不能为脓。乃服攻毒药一锺，以致呕逆脉脱，果卒于南部。
　　一县尹背疮，竟背腐溃色黯，重若负石，甚危。喜饮食颇进，用桃红散，色渐赤，负渐轻；再用而肌生；更服托里药而愈。盖此亦大毒证，非此峻药莫能治。此亦用砒，故用攻毒有效。然有气血虚不能腐溃，宜补养血气。[214p]

A man with a back ulcer bleeding, feeling restless and thirsty, had a pulse that was strong yet felt absent when pressed. This indicated a loss of blood and restlessness. I prescribed two doses of a blood-replenishing soup with angelica, and he improved slightly; later, I added astragalus and gardenia to the Eight Treasures Decoction for a complete recovery.

He Zhengqing from the Southern Yi Department, a junior minister in the western mountains, when I saw him at another time, I noticed his lips and nose were dark blue-black, and he often scratched his back. When I asked why, he said he had a small sore. I examined it, and it turned out to be a carbuncle. This indicated a severe failure of the spleen and stomach, a sign of being untreatable. Since I had a good relationship with him, I felt sorrowful about his inability to manage his burial arrangements. I thus entrusted his colleague Zhang Donghua and others to strongly persuade him to take restorative measures, but he only excreted purple blood, a sign of extreme deficiency. Some suggested that the toxicity was too severe to allow for pus formation. He then took a purging poison medicine which caused vomiting; his pulse weakened, and he ultimately passed away in the southern region.

A county magistrate had a back ulcer that had turned dark and decayed, feeling as heavy as carrying a stone, which was quite dangerous. He had a good appetite and progressed well with food intake, so I used the Peach Blossom Powder, which gradually turned red and alleviated the heaviness. After another dose, flesh began to grow; I then prescribed a medicine to dispel toxins, and he recovered. This was also a severe toxic condition, and only such potent medicine could treat it. Arsenic was used here, thus the detoxifying treatment proved effective.
