　　《赵氏医贯》曰：一园丁患发背，甚危，令取金银藤五六两捣烂，入热酒一锺，搅匀，取汁酒温服，滓罨患处，四五服而平。彼得此方，凡有患疮者，即以治之，百发百中。即得养身成家，遂弃园业。
　　《外科正宗》曰：一男子年五十余，背心生疽，十三日矣，汤水全然不入，坚硬背如负石，烦闷不语，请予视之。疮势虽重，皮色亦紫，喜其根脚交会明白，毒尚结局于此，未经入内，故可治之。须行拔法，使毒气外发，不致内攻为要。随煮药筒，提拔二次，共去恶血碗许；又以其脉实便秘，以内疏黄连汤及猪胆汁导法，大便通利二次，使内外毒气皆得通泄，随夜睡卧得宁，背重失其大半；次用托里排脓之药与服，外以桑木灸法，肿硬渐腐，脓毒渐出；换服十全大补汤加麦门冬、五味数服，腐肉自脱，饮食渐进，疮口渐合，调理两月余而愈。[215p]

"The Zhao Family Medical Canon" states: A gardener suffered from a troublesome back ailment that was quite severe. He was instructed to obtain five or six taels of gold-silver vine, pound it into pieces, mix it with a small cup of hot wine, stir well, drink the warm juice, and apply the residue to the affected area. After taking this remedy four or five times, he was cured. Finding this method effective, he began to use it for anyone with sores, achieving a successful treatment every time. He then gained health and stability in his family, eventually abandoning his gardening work.

"The Essence of External Medicine" mentions: A man over fifty had a sore on his back for thirteen days, unable to consume any food or drink. His back was hard like carrying a stone, and he remained silent with discomfort. He requested a consultation. Despite the severity of the sore, the skin was purple, but I observed that the roots and foot of the sore were clearly defined, suggesting that the poison had not yet penetrated deeply, indicating it was treatable. It was essential to draw out the toxic gases without allowing them to attack internally.

Herbal medicine was prepared and administered twice, resulting in a significant amount of evil blood being drawn out; additionally, due to his firm pulse leading to constipation, I administered a mixture of Huanglian decoction and pig bile to help relieve the internal pressure. After passing stool twice, both internal and external toxic gases were able to be expelled, allowing him to sleep peacefully at night and relieving most of the heaviness in his back.

Next, I provided medications to eliminate pus and used the mulberry wood moxibustion technique externally. The swelling and hardness gradually began to decompose, and pus started to emerge. After switching to a tonic such as the Fully Nourishing Decoction, supplemented with Mai Men Dong and several doses of Wuyuan, the necrotic tissue detached on its own, and his appetite steadily improved. Over the course of two months of careful regulation, he eventually recovered.[215p]

　　一老妇年近七旬，背疮，已过半月，形势全然可畏。彼家俱置不治，怆惶整备后事。召予看童稚疮恙，见问其故，举家大小，咸言待死朝夕。予强借观可否，视之疮形半背皆肿，疮虽不高，亦不内陷，以手按之，外实而内腐。老年内虚，脓毒中隔，不得外发故也。虽饮食不餐，且喜脚根两无混杂，脏腑又无败色，乃有生之证也。病家固执不信，又言签龟命卜，俱断必死，治岂生乎？予嗟：可惜也！再三四日不治，内膜穿溃，必死。此命陷于无辜矣！次日，予心不服，自往讨治。[216p]

An old woman nearing seventy suffered from a sore on her back for over half a month, and her condition was utterly alarming. Her family had given up on treatment and were in despair, preparing for her final affairs. They summoned me to examine the child's ailments, and when I inquired about the situation, the entire family, young and old, expressed that they awaited death at any moment. I insisted on examining her condition; I saw that her sore covered half her back and was swollen. Although the sore was neither elevated nor sunken, when pressed, it felt firm on the outside yet rotten within. The elderly woman's internal weakness and the pus and toxins trapped inside prevented it from expelling outward. Despite her lack of appetite, I noted that her feet were unaffected and her internal organs had no discoloration, which indicated a possibility of life. The family was stubborn and skeptical, claiming that divination with turtle shells had foretold her inevitable death, so how could treatment possibly save her? I lamented: What a pity! If left untreated for three or four more days, the internal membranes would rupture, and she would surely die. This fate was unjust! The next day, feeling compelled, I went to seek treatment for her.[216p]

喟然叹曰：予非相强，实见其有生，不忍舍其待死，因欲强之，医药金分毫不取，直待患者果愈，随其酬补何如？彼众方肯。先用葱艾汤淋洗疮上，外面俱是不腐顽肉，随用铍针利剪，正中取去二寸顽肉，放通脓管，以手轻重之间，捺净内蓄脓血，交流不住约有三碗，旁视者无不点头失色。待脓血稍尽，仍用前汤洗净，用膏封贴，内用回元大成汤三服，以接补真气；后用人参养荣汤倍人参、白朮、加香附，早以八味丸、八仙糕相兼调理，欲其脾健食进腐脱肌生。况此妇谨慎调理，并未更变，不过百日，疮愈身健而安。自后方信予言无谬也。[217p]

Heaving a deep sigh, he said: "I am not forcing him; I truly see that he is alive and cannot bear to abandon him to death. Thus, I desire to treat him, offering medical care without accepting any payment, waiting for the patient to heal and seeing how they compensate me afterward. The crowd is willing to agree.

First, I used an onion and mugwort soup to wash the wound. The surface was covered in rotten, stubborn flesh, so I used a fine needle and sharp scissors to carefully remove two inches of this stubborn flesh and opened the pus channel. Gently pressing with my hands, I drained the collected pus and blood, estimating about three bowls. Those watching could not help but nod in distress.

Once the pus and blood were somewhat drained, I washed the area again with the same soup and sealed it with an ointment. Internally, I prescribed three doses of the Great Restoration Decoction to replenish the vital energy. Later, I used a Ginseng Nourishing Decoction with double the ginseng and white atractylodes, adding peony to it. I also mixed in Eight Flavor Pills and Eight Immortals Cake for nutritional balance, aiming to strengthen the spleen so the patient could eat and the necrotic flesh would regenerate.

Moreover, this woman was diligent in her care and made no major changes; within a hundred days, her wound healed and her body was healthy and stable. From then on, I was believed, with no one doubting my words."[217p]

　　一监生年过五旬，素有渴证，身躯又肥胖之极，背生一发，约有尺许，至十二朝后，请予往治。视其疮势微肿，色淡微红，根脚半收半散，此阴阳相等之证也。况肥人内虚，疮势又大，非大为补托，疮必难起，毒必内陷，恐后不及事也。初服，便以托里散调其内。候至十五日，外用铍针，小小从顶放通三孔，庶使内毒有路而出。势大不可过放，走泄元气，恐脓难成。内用参芪内托散，倍加人参、黄芪各三钱，服至二十日，大脓将发，日至升许。早以参朮膏，午用十全汤加参、芪各四钱，麦冬、五味子各一钱，服至月余，肉腐通溃，脓似涌泉，间用圣愈汤、八仙糕，兼服调理，保助脾胃，增进饮食。后恐前药不胜其事，于药中加熟附子一钱，喜其脾健脓稠，色黄而正。至四十日外，疮势方得微退。[218p]

A candidate for the position had passed his fifties, and had a chronic thirst; his body was exceedingly stout, and he had a hair growing from his back, about a foot long. After twelve days, he requested treatment. Upon examining his wound, it appeared slightly swollen, with a pale red color, and the edges were both contracted and dispersed; this indicates a balance of Yin and Yang. Moreover, with a stout person who harbors internal weakness, the wound is large, and without significant nourishment and support, it would be difficult for the wound to heal, and the poison would likely penetrate deeply, which could be too late to address.

At first, I administered a remedy to invigorate his internal health. After fifteen days, I used a fine needle, making three small punctures at the top, to allow the internal toxins a path to exit. Since the condition was severe, I was cautious not to let too much out, lest it exhaust the vital energy and impede the formation of pus. I prescribed a combination of ginseng and astragalus, increasing each to nine grams as an internal remedy, and continued this for twenty days, at which point the pus began to develop.

In the morning, I used a ginseng and angelica preparation; at noon, I prescribed a Ten Complete Decoction with additional ginseng and astragalus totaling twelve grams, with a touch of ophiopogon and schisandra each at three grams. This continued for over a month, as the flesh began to necrose and discharge, with pus flowing like a gushing spring. Occasionally, I used a Holy Recovery Decoction and Eight Immortals Cake for supporting and regulating his condition, bolstering his spleen and stomach to improve his appetite.

Later, concerned that the previous medicines might not be sufficient, I added cooked aconite at three grams to the mixture, pleased that his spleen was strong and the pus was thick and yellow. After forty days, the situation of the wound began to slightly improve.[218p]

时值仲夏，天气酷热，患者生烦，快饮冷水二碗，至晚，疮随下陷，忽变为阴，不痛无脓，身凉脉细，腹痛足冷，彼觉请视。疮形软陷，脉亦细微，此疮因寒变之故也，非辛热不可回阳。急用十二味异功散，倍人参、熟附各三钱，不应，此药力不胜其寒也；换用生附、人参各五钱，早晚二服，方得身温脉起，疮高复痛；又二服，脓似前流。大脓出至一月之久，约有百余碗，竟不减少，外皮红退，亦不腐烂。此肥人外实而内虚，故皮不腐而内溃也。又用玉红膏擦于绵花片上，推入患内，膏盖之，其内腐渐脱渐出。又十日后，出大腐一块，约有六两。自后肿消身便，脓少，渐长生肌，百日外，方得平复。人参服过五斤外，附子亦用十余两，方得全安。此证设用解毒伤脾宣利等药，不用辛热峻补，岂有得生之理？[219p]

It was mid-summer, and the weather was scorching. The patient was very restless, quickly drinking two bowls of cold water. By evening, the sore began to sink, suddenly changing to a dark state, without pain or pus. The body felt cool, and the pulse was thin; there was abdominal pain and coldness in the feet, prompting them to request a consultation. The sore appeared soft and sunken, and the pulse was also faint. This sore had changed due to cold; it required warmth, not spicy heat for restoration.

I urgently prescribed the Twelve Flavor Disperse Formula, doubling the dosages of ginseng and prepared aconite to three qians each. It was ineffective; the medicine could not overcome the cold. I then switched to fresh aconite and ginseng, each five qians, to be taken in the morning and evening. This would warm the body and raise the pulse, making the sore higher and painful again. After two more doses, pus began to flow as before.

Large amounts of pus continued to exit for about a month, totaling over a hundred bowls, without decreasing. The outer skin became red but did not rot. This fat person was externally robust but internally weak, hence the skin did not rot while the inside deteriorated. I then applied Yu Hong ointment on a cotton pad and pushed it inside the sore, covering it with the ointment, which gradually helped the inner decay to peel away.

Ten days later, a large piece of rotten flesh, weighing about six liang, was expelled. After that, the swelling reduced, the pus decreased, and new flesh gradually grew. It took over a hundred days to finally restore health. More than five jin of ginseng and over ten liang of aconite were used to achieve complete safety. If detoxifying and spleen-harming medicines were employed, along with harsh spicy heat for nourishment, how could one hope for recovery?[219p]

　　一乡宦年逾七旬余，发疮右背，已经八日外。视之，疮虽微肿，色淡不红，势若龟形，根漫不耸，此老年气血衰弱之故也。诊其脉带微数而有力，此根本尚有蒂也，虽老可治。随用排脓内托散加皂刺，以溃脓托里为要。服至十三日后，疮渐肿高，色亦渐赤，但不能腐溃为脓，此食少脾弱不能培养之故也。又用十全大补汤数服，脓亦渐出，不能快利。凡脓濇滞者，内膜中隔不通故也，不可惜其老而悞其大事。随用铍针当头取开二寸许，捺通脓管，果脓随出，以猪蹄汤洗净膏盖，后用照药，每日一次，外肉渐腐为脓，患者形色枯槁不泽，更用人参养荣汤，倍加参、芪托里，腐肉将脱者取之，新肉欲生者培之。但老年气血不能速效，又加服参朮膏，早晚二次，以后新肉方生，饮食顿倍，调理七十五日而安。[220p]

A local official, aged over seventy years, developed a sore on his right back that had persisted for eight days. Upon examination, the sore, though slightly swollen, was pale and not red, resembling a turtle's shape, with its roots spreading without being elevated. This was due to the elderly's declining vitality and blood. The pulse was slightly rapid but strong, indicating that there was still some foundation present; although old, it could still be treated.

I pursued treatment to drain the pus and enhance internal absorption, using medicinal herbs combined with a topical application to promote the formation of pus. After thirteen days, the swelling increased and the color turned more red, but it failed to properly rupture and expel pus, likely due to weak digestion from inadequate nourishment. I prescribed Shenqi Dabu Decoction over several doses, resulting in gradual pus production, but not yet swift or efficient. The stagnation of pus was evidence that the internal membranes were not communicating properly; one must not lament over age but treat more crucial matters.

I then employed a fine needle to open the sore approximately two inches deep, facilitating the drainage of pus. After clearing it with pig's trotter soup, I applied topical medications once daily, causing the outer layers to gradually degenerate into pus. The patient appeared emaciated and dull, so I administered Ren Shen Yang Rong Tang, increasing the quantities of ginseng and astragalus substantially. Any decaying flesh was removed, and care was taken to nurture any new flesh that desired to form. However, due to age and low vitality, the recovery process was slow. Additionally, I provided ginseng and atractylodes paste for him to take twice daily until the new flesh formed, and after adjusting his diet significantly for seventy-five days, he finally stabilized.[220p]

　　一庠生年六十余，患背疽，十日外，视其疮形，坚硬，色亦黯紫，头发甚多，含若螺子，坚长尺许，根横半背，且喜其高肿光亮，发热焮痛，脉得洪数而有力。此疮得于膏粱醉酒湿热交蒸之故也，虽重不妨。随用照药三条，相应照毕，其头内含螺子，尽欲吐出，亦用抿脚括去，又流恶血锺许，葱汤洗净，擦上敷药，用纸盖贴，周围根脚，用吸毒散敷之，收其毒气，庶不开大。次日仍照仍傅，三日后，外肉渐腐，内加托药，培助脾胃，解毒为脓，早服八味丸以滋肾水，换洗蹄汤，仍将膏贴，候其腐尽，深入寸许，随用玉红膏，日渐日长。但此公素性好饮，虽在恙中，不能相忌。两月后新肉虽平，娇嫩不能结皮完口，因而戒饮，复将浮嫩之肉，尽行剪去，用膏贴数日，待肉老平，换用珍珠散掺上数次，方结老盖，八十日而安。[221p]

A scholar, over sixty years old, suffered from a carbuncle on his back for ten days. Upon examining the sore, it was hard and dark purple in color, surrounded by abundant hair, resembling a snail, and about a foot long, with roots extending across half his back. It was high, swollen, shiny, hot, and painful, and his pulse was strong and rapid. This sore was likely caused by the combination of rich food, alcohol, and damp heat. Despite its severity, it was manageable.

He was treated with three types of medicinal applications, which were accordingly administered. The center of the sore, resembling a snail, was meant to be expelled, so a method was employed to draw it out. Additionally, it released foul blood, which was washed with scallion broth, then cleaned and treated with medicine. Paper was applied over it and around the roots with a detoxifying powder to absorb the toxic gases and prevent further expansion.

The following day, treatment continued as before. After three days, the outer flesh gradually began to decay, and additional medication was applied to support the spleen and stomach and to convert the toxins into pus. Early on, he took an eight-herb pill to nourish his kidney water, and the hoof broth was changed. He continued to apply a soothing plaster, waiting for the decay to complete to a depth of about an inch. Gradually, he used Juhong ointment, applying it daily. However, this man had a tendency to drink, and even in illness, he could not restrain himself.

Two months later, although new flesh had formed, it was delicate and could not properly close over the sore. He was thus advised to refrain from drinking. Subsequently, the tender flesh was all cut away, and a plaster was applied for several days, waiting for the flesh to mature and become even. Pearl powder was introduced in small amounts several times until a layer formed over the wound, and it was stabilized after eighty days.[221p]

　　一老年人患疽半月，其疮贯脊，遍背皆肿，上至肩髆，下至腰胁，肿若瓜形，头计数百，彼家以为势重不治。予诊其脉，微洪而不鼓，又兼肿臖外发，询问饮食知味，其年虽老而根本尚有余也，虽老何虑？先用托里消毒散二服，其势稍定；外用桑木灸法，助力腐溃，根以铁筒膏箍之，更服排脓内托散，候正脓渐出。但年老气血衰弱，肉不易腐，视其肉色相变，不能腐化者，随用针钩利剪，徐徐剪去，其形腐凹寸余长，低尺许。凡见红肉，便用膏涂。[222p]

An elderly man suffered from ulcers for half a month, with the sores running along his spine and swelling throughout his back, from his shoulders down to his waist, resembling a melon shape. The count of sores reached hundreds, and his family believed his condition was too severe for treatment. Upon checking his pulse, it was slightly strong but not forceful, and combined with the swelling that had spread outward. After inquiring about his appetite and tastes, I found that despite his age, he still had some foundational strength. Even in old age, there was no cause for concern.

I first prescribed two doses of a detoxifying powder to help with his situation, which stabilized somewhat; then, I applied the mulberry wood moxibustion method to assist in the decay and drainage. The area was reinforced with an iron tube and bandaged. I also administered a purging powder internally to promote the gradual expulsion of pus. However, due to his age and weakened blood and qi, the flesh did not decay easily. As I examined his flesh and noticed color changes indicating it could not decompose, I carefully used needles and hooks to gradually trim away the decayed tissue, which was about an inch deep and a foot long. Whenever I encountered healthy red flesh, I applied a medicinal ointment.[222p]

其新肉已生将半，时值隆冬，患家自行开疮洗看，未燃柴炭之火，又兼盖护未暖，外被寒侵，次后疮色淡白，脓反清稀，饮食减少，气体不舒。请视之。此不遵调养爱护，而被寒气侵入也，虽变不妨。因疮原禀于阳，故能不失阳矣。房中不燃柴火烘熏，则无暖气以逼除其寒，即开疮相看而致之也。随用浓葱汤乘暖淋洗，将玉红膏烘化擦上，外用膏贴，以熟绵软绢，覆迭数层，绷盖甚密；内用神功托里散，早晚连进二服。次早复看，其疮自回阳矣。已后遵法调理，百日而安。[223p]

The new flesh has grown to about half, and it is the height of winter. The patient opened the wound to wash and examine it themselves, without lighting a fire for warmth, and was additionally covered inadequately, allowing cold to invade from outside. Subsequently, the wound turned pale white, the pus became thin and clear, appetite decreased, and there was difficulty in breathing comfortably. Please observe this. This is due to not following proper care and allowing cold air to invade; the condition could change. Since the wound inherently belongs to Yang, it has not completely lost Yang. If there is no fire in the room to provide warmth, then there is no heat to expel the cold, thus leading to the condition of the open wound. Immediately use a strong scallion soup to warmly wash it. Melt and apply jade-red ointment, and use soft cotton and silk, layered several times, to cover it tightly; internally take Shen Gong Tuo Li San, two doses morning and evening. On the following morning, observe again; the wound will have regained Yang. Afterward, adhere to the prescribed regimen, and within a hundred days, it will be stable.[223p]

　　一老人年过六旬，患背疽十二日矣。视其疮形，半肿半红，微疼微热，其患发于背心之下，肾俞之上，高低平等，广开八寸，根脚泛肿，色若水喷，顶软无神，似腐非腐，脉浮而大，重按而虚，此疮利于肿溃，不利于收敛。辞不可治。彼家哂然而笑，复请里中老医视之。见患者起居平和，言语清利，举动如常，饮食有味，言此为五善具，是安若泰山之证也，何必相虑？彼家得此，欣跃万态，随用其药，日渐有功，脓溃肿退，腐尽肌生，彼此以为万安之象也。予尝对患家亲族言：此病不可待，必死于收口至钱大时也。众若以予为妄言。后问收口只有钱许未合，予曰：不久居也，急备后事，恐不及矣。不数日，变证一出，不四朝而死。后里人始信始信　原作「群谓」，据《外科正宗》卷一改。予之前言是矣。[224p]

An elderly man, over sixty, had been suffering from a back sore for twelve days. Observing the sore's appearance, it was half swollen and half red, slightly painful and warm. It appeared on the lower back, above the kidney area, evenly raised, about eight inches wide, with the root swelling and a color akin to water. The top was soft and lacking vitality, resembling rot but not entirely rotten. The pulse was floating and large, weak upon heavy pressure; this sore was prone to bursting and not conducive to healing. Therefore, it should not be treated.

The family laughed dismissively and sought the opinion of an old local physician. He noted that the patient’s daily routine was peaceful, his speech clear and sharp, his movements normal, and he found food enjoyable. He declared this a manifestation of the five virtues, a sign of stability like a mountain, and questioned why there should be concern. The family, encouraged by this, eagerly used his prescribed medicine, and gradually there was improvement: pus drained, swelling decreased, necrotic tissue cleared, and new flesh grew. They believed it was a sign of complete recovery.

I once advised the patient’s relatives, saying this illness should not be postponed; recovery would lead to death when the sore was forcibly closed. The crowd viewed me as speaking rashly. Later, when asked about the closure, I estimated it would only be a matter of time, urging them to prepare for the worst, fearing they might run out of time. Within a few days, a change occurred, and he died within four days. Only then did the villagers begin to believe me, and I affirmed my earlier words.[224p]

　　一男人六旬有二，发生右搭，先用艾灸，次渐形势高肿，坚硬木痛，十五日后，尚未溃脓，日生烦闷。恐其毒陷，先用针通，随行拔法，拔出恶血锺许，已后稍得轻便，搽上化腐之药，膏盖，用至三日，其疮渐作腐溃，至二十日亦出正脓，坏肉渐脱，新肉渐生，此外治之法尽矣。因病家与内科一医平交甚切，托彼用药内服，而不遵外科补托之法，自执己见，不听予言，失于峻补，每日人参不过二钱以为足用。予曰：不及。[225p]

A man, sixty-two years old, developed a right tumor. Initially, he used moxibustion, but gradually the condition worsened, becoming high, swollen, hard, and painful. After fifteen days, it had not yet ruptured to discharge pus, and he was feeling increasing discomfort. Fearing the poison had penetrated deeper, he first used a needle to puncture it and then employed cupping techniques, extracting approximately a pound of foul blood. After that, he felt somewhat relieved. He applied a medicine to dissolve the necrotic tissue and covered it with an ointment. After three days, the wound began to decay and rupture. By the twentieth day, proper pus was discharged, the rotten flesh gradually sloughed off, and new flesh started to grow. The methods of treatment beyond this were concluded. However, as the patient and an internal medicine doctor had a close relationship, he entrusted his medication to him without adhering to the surgical remedies I suggested. He insisted on his own views and did not listen to my advice, resulting in excessive and harsh remedies. He took no more than two qian of ginseng daily, believing that was sufficient. I remarked: "That's not enough."[225p]

法当五钱，兼熟附二钱，方为称病。不然，必生变矣。彼亦不信。后果肉色淡白，疮口散大，脓水清稀，饮食减少，此败证具矣。后虽强投温中健脾大补之药，终不能应，至于形体消削，脓水臭秽，延至六十日，沥尽气血而亡。然后方自懊悔。殊不知大疮每日脓出一碗，用参必至三钱，以此为则。况此病出脓，日有三碗，用参二钱，谓之大损小补，岂不归死？又外科乃破漏之病，最能走泄真气，如损补两不相敌，往往至于不救，此为不信于补而执俗见，自取败亡者也。[226p]

The treatment should consist of five coins of medicine, along with an additional two coins as a supplement, to properly address the illness. Otherwise, complications are bound to arise. However, they do not believe this. As a result, the patient’s flesh becomes pale and white, the wounds widen, and the pus is thin and watery, leading to decreased appetite; these are clear signs of decline. Even if they later aggressively administer warming and spleen-strengthening tonics, it ultimately proves ineffective, leading to emaciation and foul-smelling pus, extending for up to sixty days, draining their vital energy and blood until death ensues. Then they only regret their choices. They do not understand that for a large sore, producing a bowl of pus each day, three coins of ginseng are essential as a standard. Given that this condition produces pus yielding three bowls daily, administering just two coins of ginseng is considered a major loss with minimal gain—doesn’t this lead to death? Moreover, external medicine often deals with conditions where a breach leads to the leakage of true vital energy; if loss and supplementation conflict, it frequently results in irreparable damage. This stems from a disbelief in tonics and clinging to common misconceptions, ultimately leading to self-destructive outcomes.[226p]

　　一男子年近六旬，时值仲夏，背生热疖二十余处，彼家邀请视孙疮恙，见彼坐于堂，满背皆疖，予略视之，内有一疮，比疖甚小，其毒甚大。予曰：此疮非疖比也，一发势不可及。彼笑而答，以为无恙也。乃郎送至门庭，予又嘱曰：可急请他医治之，不可缓待。俱不听信。又至十日，形势稍发，命里中一医治之，又曰：是疖也。又十日，形势内陷，败证齐出，稍信前言，方央亲友邀予相视。其入睡卧于堂，帛覆疮上，登堂未进二三步即退。人曰：何也？予曰：败气满前，死期速矣，何必视疮，急备后事，再七日死。后果如言，不差时刻。此为讳疾忌医，自取败者也。[227p]

A man nearing sixty in age, during the peak of summer, had over twenty hot sores on his back. His family invited me to look at his grandson's illness, and when I saw him sitting in the hall, his back was covered with sores. Upon closer inspection, I noticed one sore that was much smaller than the others, but contained a much greater poison. I said, "This sore is not merely a boil; once it erupts, it cannot be managed." He laughed and replied, thinking there was no serious issue. Later, as he was escorted to the door, I urged him again, saying, "You must quickly seek another physician for treatment; do not delay." They did not believe me.

Ten days later, his condition slightly worsened, and one doctor treated him, again stating, "It is just a boil." Another ten days passed, the situation deteriorated, and symptoms of decay emerged. Only then did they start to somewhat believe my earlier words and sought my opinion again. When I entered the hall, he was lying covered with cloth over the sore, and after taking only two or three steps, I turned back. Someone asked, "Why?" I said, "The decay is rising; his death is imminent. There is no need to inspect the sore; prepare for the aftermath instead; he will die in another seven days." Ultimately, the result was just as I predicted, not off by a moment. This illustrates the folly of avoiding medical attention while ignoring illnesses, which leads to one's own downfall.[227p]

　　《景岳全书》曰：向予长男，生在癸丑，及乙卯五月，甫及二周而患背疽。初起时，背中忽见微肿，数日后按之，则根深渐阔，其大如碗，而皮色不变，亦不甚痛，至十余日，身有微热，其势滋甚，因谋之疡医。或云背疽，或云痰气。咸曰荤腥温补，一毫不可入口，乃投以解毒之药一剂，而身反大热，神气愈困，饮食不进矣。予危惧之甚，因思丹溪有云：痈疽因积毒在脏腑，当先助胃气为主，使根本坚固，而以行经活血佐之。又曰：但见肿痛，参之脉证虚弱，便与滋补，气血无亏，可保终吉。是诚确论也。[228p]

The "Comprehensive Book of Jingyue" states: My eldest son was born in the year of Gui Chou. In the fifth month of the year of Yi Mao, at just two years old, he developed a back abscess. At first, there was a sudden slight swelling in his back; after a few days, upon pressing it, the root deepened and grew wider, becoming as large as a bowl, yet the skin color did not change and it was not very painful. After more than ten days, he experienced a slight fever, and the condition worsened. Therefore, we consulted a sore doctor. Some claimed it was a back abscess, others called it phlegm and qi. They all said to avoid all rich foods entirely; thus, we administered a detoxifying medicine. However, this resulted in an increase in fever, and he became more spiritless, unable to eat. I was greatly alarmed and remembered that Danxi said: abscesses arise from accumulated toxins in the organs; one should first strengthen the stomach qi to solidify the foundation and then engage in blood circulation to assist. He also said: when swelling and pain are observed, coupled with weak pulse signs, one should fortify and nourish; if the qi and blood are not deficient, one can ensure a favorable outcome. This is indeed a sound analysis.[228p]

因却前药而专固元气以内托其毒，遂用人参三钱，制附子一钱，佐以当归、熟地、炙甘草、肉桂之属，一剂而饮食顿进，再进而神彩如旧。抑何神也！由是弛其口腹，药食并进，十剂而脓成，以其根深皮厚，复用针出脓甚多，调理月余而愈。向使倾信庸流，绝忌温补滋味，专意解毒，则胃气日竭，毒气日陷，饮食不进，倘致透隔内溃，则万万不保矣。且此儿素无虚病，何敢乃尔？盖以其既属阴证，又无实邪，见有确真，故敢峻补脾肾，方保万全。呜呼！医之关系皆是类也。因录此案，用告将来，以见肿疡溃疡，凡虚证未见而但无实热壅滞可据者，便宜托补，如此则其受益于不识不知，有非可以言语形容者。
[229p]

Due to previously disregarding the medicine and solely fortifying the vital energy while hosting its poison, three qian of ginseng, one qian of prepared aconite, alongside angelica, cooked rehmannia, roasted licorice, and cinnamon were used. After one dose, the appetite significantly improved, and after another, his spirit was as before. But what spirit was this! Thus, he relaxed his dietary restrictions, and both medicine and food were taken together. After ten doses, pus formed; given the depth of roots and thickness of skin, using needles extracted a great deal of pus. After a month of regulation, he recovered. If trust had been placed in common practitioners, with strict avoidance of warming and nourishing flavors while focusing solely on detoxification, his stomach qi would have daily diminished, the toxic energy would have increasingly invaded, leading to an inability to eat. If it had resulted in internal ulceration, it would have been utterly perilous. Moreover, this child had no signs of deficiency diseases; how could one act carelessly? It was because he presented a yin condition without actual pathogens, but with clear causes present, that he dared to vigorously nourish the spleen and kidneys, ensuring a thorough preservation of health. Alas! The relationship of medicine is always about categorization. Thus, this case is recorded to inform future practitioners. In cases of swelling and abscesses, whenever deficiency signs are absent but there is no evidence of real heat blockage, it is advisable to nourish. In this way, the benefits from those who do not know cannot be adequately expressed in words.[229p]
